—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to age pensions and to the Minister's article in the Australian newspaper on Monday entitled 'The Swelling Pension Burden'. I ask about statistical claims in that article. It is claimed that the number of people aged 65 years and over as a proportion of the total Australian population is expected to increase from 9.8 per cent this year to 12.2 per cent by the end of the century. However, the Year Book of Australia, published this month, indicates a much smaller increase of only 10.4 per cent. This figure represents only one quarter of the increase claimed in the article. Even the source cited in the article-that is, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs Review of Demographic Trends-estimates the proportion of people aged 65 years and over to be about 10.4 per cent, not the 12.2 per cent claimed. How can it be that the Minister has exaggerated four-fold the expected increase in age pensioner numbers? Does this exaggeration suit the purpose of the policy thrust of that article? How can that bias actually be justified with reference to published facts? Finally, will the Minister immediately withdraw the figures and correct the misleading information that has been published?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not able to withdraw the figures referred to by the honourable senator in his question, but I welcome the fact that he has raised the matter and I thank him for the fact that he gave me some little notice that he intended to ask the question. Quite frankly, without notice I would merely have been able to say that I had sought and obtained the figures from my Department and had asked its officers to ensure that they were carefully checked before I decided to publish them. In fact, the projections which I have used are those prepared by the Australian Bureau of Statistics for the Department of Finance and are used by the Department in preparing its forward estimates of expenditure. The projections also have been included in the ABS publication Social Indicators 1980 at page 8.

ANSWER.PARA: The principal difference between the projections I have used and the other projections contained in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs Review of Demographic Trends and in the Year Book referred to by the honourable senator is that in those I used mortality rates are projected to decline for the rest of the century. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs projections quoted by the honourable senator assume constant mortality to that time and the assumption of constant mortality is not consistent with trends during the 1970s. Of course, in all of this we are dealing with prediction. Estimates are made on the basis of the best information available at the time and there is, of course, room for differences. The paper to which the honourable senator referred in his question makes note of the point that I have just made. A footnote at page 24 of the paper states:

It seems likely that mortality will in fact decline throughout the projection period, thus adding to the estimates of both the total population, and more significantly, the number of aged persons. This would accentuate trends in the ageing of the population.

Indeed, in the text of the publication elsewhere, as opposed to the diagrams which are in the same publication, the Department refers to population projections in which the numbers of aged persons will increase by about two-thirds over the next 20 years. That reference is contained at page 3 and it relates to the projections that I have used which are based on the assumptions of improvements in mortality. For the information of the honourable senator-I hope it is of interest to the Senate generally-the projections of the population in the next 20 years are as follows: The numbers of persons aged 65 or more will increase from 1.45 million to 2.37 million-that is, by about two-thirds-while those aged 75 or more will increase in number from about 0.5 million to more than one million-that is, the numbers will double. I observe that in terms of the future welfare and health responsibilities of Commonwealth and State governments the latter figure relating to the growth in the number of older persons in the community is probably particularly significant. I also refer the Senate to a report prepared by Professor Myers for the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat which is entitled 'Population and Public Welfare Policy in Australia'. Professor Myers, in his conclusion, stated:
. . . strange indeed is the fact that many experts in Australia still cling to the notion that the A-C Series (constant mortality assumptions) should be viewed as the preferred projections.

In light of the fact that declining mortality rates are likely to exert significant pressures on the health and welfare services provided by both the Commonwealth and the States I think it is important that there be debate on and consideration of the projections. I acknowledge that differences of opinion can exist because questions on not only mortality rates but also birth and immigration rates have to be taken into account. A series of factors do require estimating.

One consistent feature of the material which I have seen since I have held this portfolio is that the further one goes along the track with respect to population projections the more it appears that earlier but relatively recent projections have been conservative with respect to the number of aged Australians. There appears to be a lengthening or an enhancement of the age to which one is likely to live. I suppose that most of us, since we seem to be ageing very rapidly in this place, can welcome the fact that we seem to have increased chances of mortality. I can assure the Senate that the figures from which I have quoted were very carefully examined to try to ensure that they presented the most accurate picture possible in the light of current information.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a brief supplementary question. In the light of the good answer by the Minister, will he acknowledge that official estimates are in the range from 10.4 per cent to 12.2 per cent?

—I certainly acknowledge that one can have a range of estimates, but I think the initial figure given by the honourable senator is unduly low. He thinks my figure is unduly high. I acknowledge that there is an element of estimation in whatever figure is used and that a range, therefore, can be chosen. I suspect that one could look at slight variations in mortality, life expectancy, birth and immigration rates and come up with figures which would suggest even higher rates of growth. Again, that is a matter open to debate.

—Is the Minister for Social Security aware that his Department is in breach of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal legislation in failing to provide reasons for the rejection of an invalid pension within 28 days of the request being made? Is he aware that there has been an average of 53 days in the time taken to provide reasons, with some cases taking considerably longer? As there is a backlog of several hundred appeals relating to invalid pensions, will the Minister move urgently to review the staffing in his appeals section and on Appeals Tribunal support so that the law can be observed and invalid pension claimants can receive attention as soon as possible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My Department recognises, as it must and as I must, the prescribed period of 28 days for the supply of the statement and associated documents pursuant to the requirements of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act. The Department is doing its utmost to meet the requirement. Honourable senators will be aware that the appeal procedures are relatively new. They were announced last year. Since 9 September 1980, when the jurisdiction of the Tribunal was extended to include applications relating to medical matters, many more applications have been received than were originally anticipated. Delays have resulted in supplying section 37 statements and documents. New positions have been created within my Department to meet the additional workload, and action is being taken to fill the positions. The situation is constantly under review. I have had a number of questions in this place from Senator Grimes, from some Government senators and from Senator Colston about delays in different parts of the appeal system and as recently as last week, I think, I approved an increase in the number of appeal tribunals in New South Wales to meet some of the difficulties in that State.

ANSWER.PARA: It is perhaps worth noting that the 28 day period to which the honourable senator referred is not a mandatory requirement. It is a directory one. The matter has been raised and the Tribunal itself, I think, has indicated that section 37 is not mandatory. We certainly accept that we should try to meet that time limit and currently efforts are being made to ensure that we can do so. As the honourable senator indicated in his question, we have not been able to do so in all cases in the past.

—Has the Acting Minister for Health seen the allegation made in the September issue of Choice magazine concerning contaminated milk? Choice claims that the milk supplies in the three State capitals sampled have been found to have high levels of bacterial contamination. Choice found all the brands of pasteurised milk it tested were contaminated in excess of the levels recommended by the National Health and Medical Research Council. Is the Minister able to confirm or deny these disquieting allegations? Are the NHMRC standards realistic? Is there a danger to national health at these levels of contamination and what can be done immediately to solve the problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the recent article published in Choice. The honourable senator in his own reading of the article will have noted that the National Health and Medical Research Council has already developed a standard for milk, including microbiological standards. It has recommended that these be adopted by States and the Territories. The standard applies to milk as it leaves the processing factory and milk at the wholesale level. It is more difficult to develop a standard to apply at retail levels. Indeed, the standard which has been presently developed does not so apply. It applies at the processing and wholesale levels. The reason it does not apply at the retail level is that there is a scarcity of microbiological data. Because of that, people do not know what the proper standard should be. The NHMRC has undertaken to gather appropriate data on the microbiology of milk at retail level. I understand that it has collected data on both cow and goat milk recently. This will form the basis of the development of a microbiological standard in the future.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not reasonable to compare milk taken at the retail level with microbiological standards based on data obtained at the processing factory level. It is not possible to make such a comparison. I believe such a comparison was made in the Choice article. Choice may need to look at the methodology it used. The microbiological standards recommended by the NHMRC are, indeed, realistic standards if they are applied correctly. I am advised that the NHMRC recommended that unpasteurised milk not be sold for direct human consumption. Indeed, as a doctor I endorse that view. Unpasteurised milk, particularly goat milk, is a cause for concern. However, there is no danger to national health from pasteurised milks provided proper methods of handling and distribution are employed. Consumers should be discouraged from consuming unpasteurised milk. The NHMRC is already developing microbiological standards to apply to milk at the point of retail sale. In addition, it is also formulating a standard for goat milk.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is it correct that disabled people employed in sheltered workshops can earn only $20 a week before losing 50c from their pension for every dollar earned over $20? Is it also correct that the $20 limit has not changed since 1972 when the pension level was also $20? Given that the then Minister assured pensioners that 'this equality of value will be a principle for the future', how does the Government justify its stated view that the needy members of society should not be penalised?

—It is true, as the honourable senator has indicated in his question, that the income test free area for invalid pensioners is at the level he has indicated-$20. It is some years since that level has been adjusted. The honourable senator concluded his question with words asking in effect: How, therefore, can we justify saying that we should be helping those who need assistance? I direct the Senate's attention to the fact that the operation of the income test is specifically an instrument designed to ensure that available resources are directed to those who have least. In other words, people who are without income receive the full pension and people with some levels of private or other income still continue to receive the full pension but after certain limits-in the case of the single person the $20 limit with respect to the invalid or age pension-there is a withdrawal of pension at the rate of 50c for each dollar of non-pension income. Although it is true that that income limit has not changed it is also true that each time the pension is adjusted, which is, of course, twice a year under the automatic indexation provisions introduced by this Government, the range of income over which a part pension is received does expand. In other words, if the pension rises by $3, as it will in November, the position is that there will be an additional $6 income range over which part of the pension will be payable. To that extent there is a widening of the range of incomes over which a part pension will be payable to an invalid pensioner or to an age pensioner to whom the same income test applies. I am aware of the concern felt among pensioners, invalid and otherwise, that the limits have not been changed. That is a matter which, of course, is considered annually in a Budget context. I note the concern which is evident in the honourable senator's question. This matter will be before the Government again next year.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. When the Government accepted an export complementation program for the motor vehicle industry, did it envisage a Nissan-type scheme whereby shaved aluminium cylinder heads would be exported in return for receiving export credits for equivalent value imports involving, I might say, tremendous difficulties in transfer pricing? Further, since this Nissan operation did not require a massive capital injection, the introduction of a new technology or a substantive input component, as with the General Motors 'J' series car engine, if this test case scheme of the Japanese, as I call it, is allowed to proceed, what will be the effect on the employment opportunities of thousands of people employed in the automotive parts industry in Australia.?

—The honourable senator's question relates to the export complementation program which was introduced by the Government to encourage manufacturing in Australia and to encourage the export of manufactured material from Australia with the exporter gaining the right to import offset material and thereby producing a more efficient manufacturing arrangement. The scheme, which has been operating for some years, leaves the manufacturers free to determine which products they see as being commercially viable for export and which products they would wish to source from overseas while still meeting their local content obligation; so they are matters which have been left primarily to the commercial judgment of companies. I think it is well known to many honourable senators, as manufacturers have been making representations in this building over the past month on the area Senator Watson has raised, that some manufacturers are concerned that the present scheme enables people to manufacture components which have a relatively low level of technological input, a relatively low labour content and so on and to import the more sophisticated manufactured items that go into the motor cars. That is a matter which has been put before the Government. I will refer the honourable senator's question to the Minister for Industry and Commerce for his consideration. I stress, in giving this answer, that the Government has not sought in this program to date to dictate what elements of a vehicle should be manufactured in Australia; rather, that is a matter which has been left to commercial judgment.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Finance, refers to the horror Budget which was handed down in the South Australian Parliament yesterday. Can the Minister tell the Senate what the Federal Government's attitude is to a State Premier who siphons off funds from Loan Council allocations to pay for recurrent expenditure? In the last financial year Mr Tonkin diverted a record amount of $37.3m from the capital works Loan Council allocations, and in the Budget he handed down yesterday the new amount to be diverted is a record $44m. As the South Australian Premier blames the Federal Government for the state of South Australia's finances, despite the fact that Federal moneys paid to South Australia are growing at a faster rate than the revenue raised by the South Australian Government, has the Tonkin Government any real credibility as a financial manager?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not able to deal with the detail of the question raised by the honourable senator regarding the recently announced Budget of the South Australian Government. I am not aware of the figures that he relates to the capital works Loan Council allocation. The only thing I can say about this matter is that the last time it was discussed with me it related to the State of New South Wales, where there had been some transposition of capital works funds into recurrent funding for, I think, education. If we were to go through the State Budgets we may find that the States had decided to transpose figures. If there is any fact in the question that has been raised, I will see what comment can be made on it. It might be profitable to look at other State Budgets to see whether the same sort of thing occurs there.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. It relates to the study by Mr Arnold Grimwade, funded by the Technical and Further Education Council, on the capacity for sharing resources in TAFE external studies and, in particular, to Mr Grimwade's recommendations on the need to develop a structure and strategy for a national catalogue of TAFE external studies courses with a view to improving the capacity for sharing resources. Is the Minister aware of the enormous duplication which presently exists in the courses and subjects taught at TAFE colleges in various States? Whilst I recognise that the initiative to implement a national catalogue of subjects offered at colleges rests with the States, I ask the Minister: Firstly, what action will be taken by the Federal Government to obtain a commitment to the completion of the catalogue from TAFE directors of all States; secondly, will the Federal Government make funds available to assist in financing the project; and thirdly, will consideration be given by the Government to integrating the project with the TAFE clearing house now in operation so as to ensure that full subject information is available and that duplication of resources is avoided?

—I am not familiar with the study carried out by Mr Grimwade which concerns the sharing of resources among the various external study units of the State technical and further education authorities. As I understand it, each State TAFE authority has an external studies unit. These units offer many of the courses available to external students but it should be remembered that the content of these courses is directed at meeting particular States' needs including those which spring from requirements of local industry or in some cases from State licensing authorities. For this reason there may appear to be overlap of courses. But this overlap could well be more apparent than real because of the necessity to meet particular needs. Having made those preliminary comments, let me take aboard the three specific parts of the question and seek more particular information upon them for the honourable senator.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In view of the Government's decision, announced yesterday through the Reserve Bank of Australia, to allow banks to lend slightly more money this year, I ask: What steps will the Government take to ensure that these funds are lent to job creating industries, such as the building industry or small business, and not wasted on anti-competitive takeovers by large or foreign companies that seek only quick profits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — It is true that the Reserve Bank of Australia has varied the guidance given to trading banks about the rate of growth in their advances outstanding and that each bank is now requested to limit the growth on advances for the time being to a rate of 12 per cent. This contrasts with the previous figure of 10 per cent per annum. It is probably fair to say it is not a relaxation of monetary policy which continues to be to restrain the growth of the availability of money and credit. Indications are that the growth in this coming year of the liquidity base for the financial sector generally will be less than in 1980-81. Against this background rather less need is seen for quantitative restraints on bank lending. I am sure that the effect of the guidance variation of the Reserve Bank will flow through to the trading banks and that a variety of funds will be available for a number of sources. I will seek a comment from the Treasurer regarding the particular question that was raised by Senator Childs. But I think we would assume that a variety of sources will be able to be funded through any increased advances which now will be available in the banking financial structure. If the Treasurer wishes to make any further comment I will see that the Senate is advised as soon as possible.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. I refer to an article in todays Australian headed 'Illiterates in computing' by Professor Michael Birt. Is the Minister aware that there are almost 900 companies associated with computers in Australia and that they employ some 18,000 people? Is the Minister aware that the current imports of computer equipment into Australia are worth about $500m per annum and are increasing by about 30 per cent per annum and yet, with support, much of this equipment could be designed and built in this country? Will the Minister set up a board of suitable college and university personnel with some industry representation not financially associated with the computer industry to administer grants to some Australian computer companies to enable them to increase their research and development with obvious benefits to the country both in peace and war time? Finally, will the Government consider amending the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act so that grants can be made to software computer companies?
—I shall refer that question to the Minister and seek an early answer.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS CONVENTION ON THE ELIMINATION OF ALL FORMS OF DISCRIMINATION AGAINST WOMEN

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Attorney-General, relates to the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women, which was signed on behalf of the Australian Government at Copenhagen in July 1980 on the occasion of the Mid-Decade for Women Conference. I understand that earlier this year a meeting of all State Ministers responsible for human rights was held to discuss ratification of the Convention. At the time it was implied that there appeared to be no serious impediment to ratification. I ask: Are any of the States totally opposed to ratification and, if so, upon what grounds? Is there any danger of parts of the Convention being qualified so that a consensus may be reached with all States? Is there any possibility of the Government using its treaty powers to ratify the Convention in its original form?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of the ratification by Australia of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women was referred to the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General because a great many of its provisions concern State laws. We followed the precedent established in dealing with the ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. As the honourable senator says, the Convention was signed in July of last year at the meeting in Copenhagen. Shortly thereafter the question of ratification was referred to the Standing Committee, whose officers have been working on it assiduously ever since. At the last meeting of the Standing Committee in Cairns at the end of July of this year a considerable report on the subject was made to the Committee of Attorneys-General. They were meeting as a committee of Ministers responsible for human rights rather than strictly as Attorneys-General. Certainly, a good deal of progress has been made towards the final consideration of the matter by the Committee. The Commonwealth Government is anxious to reach a consensus with the States.
—The lowest common denominator.

—Not necessarily at all. We are anxious, as far as is possible, to reach a consensus on this matter because, as I have said, it involves State laws as well as Commonwealth laws. Unlike members of the Opposition, we are not prepared to impose upon the States the full rigours of what some constitutional lawyers believe to be the external affairs power. That is why we are engaged in this exercise. Senator Evans knows that perfectly well. I am sorry that I have been diverted by him from answering the honourable senator's question. The honourable senator asked whether any States are totally opposed to ratification. I am not aware that any States are. They have engaged in this exercise with genuine goodwill and in an effort to reach a consensus as far as that is possible. The honourable senator asks whether it is likely that any qualifications would be imposed on the Convention, that is, whether Australia would be likely to have any reservations. I think it is a bit early yet to answer that question. Obviously, whether there should be some reservation in respect of certain aspects of the Convention, particularly in relation to the question of the federal system, is one of the matters that has to be considered. It is too early yet to say whether there would be any qualification of that kind.

ANSWER.PARA: The other question the honourable senator asked was whether the Commonwealth would be prepared to ratify the Convention in its full terms, presumably regardless of any objections from the States. Again, it is too early to answer that question. As I said, the Commonwealth Government's policy is to endeavour to reach a consensus. In the end, however-the States recognise this-it is solely the decision of the Commonwealth Government whether it ratifies and on what terms it ratifies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport to media reports indicating that Australia is losing air traffic controllers faster than the ability of the Department of Transport to recruit with the result that some airports-for example, Brisbane Airport-are being forced to close during night hours due to lack of staff. It has been reported that controllers have rejected a Public Service Board proposal for a more flexible rostering system and increased penalty rates. With these reports in mind, can the Minister advise whether the standard of air safety in Australia is deteriorating and what effect the shortage of controllers will have on general efficiency in the airline industry, including international flights and outback aircraft operators? Also, what action has been taken to endeavour to remedy the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has given me considerable information on this matter but I am not sure I can give Senator Kilgariff all the information he seeks in relation to outback areas and so on. I will seek that information from the Minister for the honourable senator. The Minister can assure Senator Kilgariff that the shortage of air traffic controllers in Australia does not affect standards of air safety, although obviously it causes some inconvenience. It is true there is a shortage of air traffic controllers in Australia, as there is generally throughout the world. The shortage in Australia is expected to be of the order of 110 controllers by the end of this year. The Minister has pointed out that the Department of Transport now has more air traffic controllers than it had in previous years. Also, the Department's training school is operating to its fullest capacity.

ANSWER.PARA: Because there have been 18 unscheduled retirements or long term illnesses among controllers in Queensland over the past year, as compared with a normal annual attrition rate of four, the effect of the shortage has been felt more in that State than in any other. Most of the air traffic controller losses in Queensland have been from the senior terminal area control position. It will take some months before 17 permanent and 7 temporary controllers transferred to Brisbane provide sufficient trained controllers in the senior positions to return that airport to normal operations. The effect of the closure of Brisbane Airport on airline operations will be alleviated when daylight saving starts in southern States in approximately five weeks time. Discussions are still taking place with airlines as to the requirements for additional flights in the period leading up to Christmas so that coverage for them can be provided. Furthermore, the three hour closure of Brisbane Airport affects one Qantas flight northbound to Tokyo. Qantas is arranging to ferry the passengers to Sydney for that flight.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SALES TAX ON PET FOOD FOR GUIDE DOGS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. It expresses my concern for blind people. Will blind invalid pensioners be forced to pay the full sales tax on pet food for their guide dogs or is any provision being made for them to claim exemption?

—The question raised by the honourable senator is one which has been raised with me by other members of the Parliament. Don Cameron put a proposition to me, in the same sort of terms implicit in the honourable senator's question, that there should be some specific exemption for guide dogs. I think he costed that at about $13,000 a year. I have that member's suggestion under consideration. I will also place the honourable senator's question under consideration. I imagine there might be administrative difficulties in exempting a very narrow segment of the market from a particular sales tax provision. I understand the purport of the question. I will examine it further and let the honourable senator have a more considered reply in due course.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is it a fact that recent moves by the Government of Mr Mugabe of Zimbabwe have turned the white people of that country into economic prisoners? If whites do leave Zimbabwe from now on, will our Government move that the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees recognise these people as refugees from political persecution, firstly, because they must leave behind properties such as refrigerators, freezers, washing machines, et cetera; secondly, because their foreign exchange--
—Did Eric Butler write this for you?

—Is limited to $2,300 a family, and a second hand car-I might mention that all this was in the papers-thirdly, because the recent Budget which soaks the rich to pay the poor, boosts property transfers and abolishes certain business concessions; fourthly, because of the recent State takeover of 40 private schools for blacks and whites so that they can be more integrated; fifthly, because of the loss of dual passport security against the declared stateless, as happened to Lieutenant-General Peter Walls; and sixthly, because of the raising of special North Korean trained armoured brigades of 5,000 crack troops to act as an internal police force without normal police constraints?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — A number of detailed points are raised in the question asked by Senator Bjelke-Petersen. I think it would be appropriate to suggest that the question be placed on notice so that the points could be dealt with by the Minister for Foreign Affairs. If he wishes to give any ready response, I will see that she is advised. If the question were placed on notice, I think all the detailed matters could have the response from the Minister.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. I refer the Minister to a reply which he forwarded to me in relation to invalid pension appeals. Part of that reply reads:

QUESTION.PARA: Where an invalid pensioner lodges an appeal with a Social Security Appeals Tribunal within three months of having been advised that it is proposed to cancel his pension on the ground that he can no longer be regarded as permanently incapacitated for work, it is the existing practice to continue the payment of the pension until the outcome of the appeal is known.
I reiterate that part of the reply which is particularly pertinent. It states:
. . . it is the exising practice to continue the payment of the pension until the outcome of the appeal is known.

I ask: Was the word 'existing' inserted in the reply to indicate that a revision of this practice is being contemplated? If not, can invalid pensioners be assured that no revision of the current practice is contemplated?

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in Question Time I indicated that Senator Colston, among others, had asked me questions about this matter, and that comment appears to have sparked another question. My recollection of the letter which I sent to Senator Colston is that in fact the expression 'existing practice' was used because in the not very distant past there in fact had been varying practices in the different States. Honourable senators would understand that the administration of my Department is substantially decentralised through State and regional offices and it is possible for differences in practice, which we try to avoid, of course, to creep in but given the large number of people and offices that can occur. Speaking from memory, I think there were some variations from State to State but the uniform practice has now been established around Australia in the terms set out in that letter, namely, that an invalid pensioner who has had the pension removed on the basis that he is no longer 85 per cent incapacitated will continue to receive the pension until the appeal is determined, notwithstanding that may be longer than three months after the decision is taken. I will have that reply checked but that is my recollection of the matter and I think that is why the words 'existing practice' were used in that letter.
—I ask the Minister a supplementary question. When he is having it checked, will he check to see that invalid pensioners can be assured that there will be no change to the current practice?

—I am sorry. That was a major part of the original question. I think that my answer, by implication, sought to reassure the honourable senator on that point, but I will check that matter again expressly for him.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Communications: Is it a fact that in order to provide television services to the Eyre Peninsula in South Australia and thereby to complete a three-year program started in 1979 Telecom Australia needs at least 12 months lead time in which to make arrangements for the necessary receiving and transmitting equipment to be ordered and delivered? Has the planning section of the Minister's Department contacted Telecom in Adelaide informing it of the equipment required to complete the three-year program and also the specifications for the facilities required? I refer in particular to the equipment needed to provide television services to the Wudinna area. If not, will the Minister guarantee that adequate time will be provided for the necessary equipment to be obtained so that the Government's promise under the three-year program can be fulfilled?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The work already undertaken by the Fraser Government in the Eyre Peninsula region is a practical example of the Government's commitment to improving communications and television services for people in non-metropolitan Australia. I welcome the honourable senator's acknowledgment that the program to which he referred has been in progress since 1979. I understand his concern, as a South Australian senator, that the program should be completed in the shortest possible time. The honourable senator asked about the lead time. I am able to advise him that the lead time for the supply of equipment for a television service is at least 12 months for the provision of capital equipment, at least 18 months for the provision of program input equipment when a microwave bearer is involved and at least two years when land purchases are involved because of the processes which have to be undertaken. Such lead times commence when Telecom is instructed to proceed with a project.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asked whether there had been contact with the South Australian office of Telecom. The Department of Communications does not deal directly with the State offices of Telecom in matters concerning the planning and provision of new television services. The details required to enable Telecom to proceed with an installation are provided to Telecom's head office following Government approval for a project and the provision of funds in the Budget context. There are two stages in the development of any major broadcasting project: The preliminary planning stage, which involves field surveys, and the implementation stage, which is dependent upon financial approval and which includes such things as forward ordering authorisation and, of course, the provision of funds in the Budget.

The 1981-82 Budget provides funds for the preliminary planning of several major projects, including the Eyre Peninsula project about which Senator Jessop, as a South Australian senator, asked his question. When preliminary planning is complete and full details of the project are available, the project will be considered again in the Budget context against the priorities of competing proposals. At this time it is not possible to give a firm commitment to my colleague on when the establishment of the service in that area will be completed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Is it a fact that the Queensland Government has challenged the validity of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975? Is it also a fact that that action is in response to a complaint of racial discrimination by an Aboriginal group in north Queensland? Is it also a fact that the Commissioner for Community Relations has referred the details of the Queensland Government's decision to the Commonwealth Attorney-General? Will the Attorney-General please inform the Senate whether the Federal Government intends to bring that matter before the High Court; if so, when?

—The details outlined by Senator Jones in his question are correct. The matter has been considered by me and I have decided that it should be referred to the High Court because it does raise a constitutional issue and the High Court is the appropriate body to decide such questions. I am not quite sure what stage has been reached in implementing that decision, so I cannot say when the case will be heard in the High Court.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. I remind the Minister of his second reading speech on the Christmas Island Agreement Amendment Bill. He said that provision had been made for an adequate habitat for the Abbott's booby bird, a cause which he would know was supported by such diverse people as Prince Philip, as a royalist and Senator Georges and myself as republicans. When will we get a final decision about the actual habitat that will be set aside? In conjunction with that promise, the Minister indicated that the New Zealand Government had to be consulted. I wonder whether Prime Minister Muldoon is proving difficult on this aspect.

—I well remember the debate on the Christmas Island Agreement Amendment Bill. I well remember the concerns expressed for the Abbott's booby bird. Indeed, how could anyone forget when the bird attracted such wide support from all sides of the Senate? The honourable senator may recall that I advised at that time that the moratorium on further jungle clearing in certain areas on Christmas Island-the central and western areas-would be extended until 31 August to permit further consideration of the options which had been recommended. As the honourable senator will recall, these options were recommended in a report on the Abbott's booby bird on Christmas Island brought down by Professors Ovington and Cullen and Dr Nelson. The consideration of those options has not yet been finalised but is expected to be finalised shortly. Because of this and because it is after 31 August, it has been decided--
—You are playing injury time.

—We are playing injury time; I accept that. It has been decided to extend the moratorium for the present so that the Abbott's booby bird will be protected and there will be no further jungle clearing on Christmas Island. I know of no impediments which are being put in the way of a resolution of which options there should be. I will refer that matter to the Minister for Administrative Services in case there is further information he can give to the honourable senator.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance in her own capacity and as Minister representing the Treasurer. Will the Minister tell the Senate that the consumer price index increase estimated by the Treasury for June 1982 on June 1981 is 11.9 per cent, as I stated in the Senate on 26 August and as the Business Review confirmed last week? Is it also correct that the planned sales tax increases account for more than one per cent of that CPI rise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have amongst my papers accurate figures on the Sales Tax Amendment Bills with which we will be dealing this evening. They show that over the period mentioned the estimated increase is slightly more than one per cent. It is something like 0.75 per cent for the period of the Budget. I will give the accurate information to the Senate later on. As far as the other matter is concerned, I will gain information and provide it as soon as I am able to do so.

—I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the release this week of the latest statistics on the building industry which show that private sector dwelling construction approvals in July were at their lowest monthly level since September 1980. Is this not clear evidence that the Government's economic policies are depressing the building industry in Australia? Is the Minister aware that rising interest rates have widened the gap between approvals and commencements? Is this Government at all concerned about the effect its restrictionist policies are having and will continue to have on the thousands of Australians whose livelihood depends on the building industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government is concerned about all the matters raised by the honourable senator which affect the interest rates and the possibility of home ownership in this country. Indeed, the Budget that is before the Parliament at present is cast in such a way that the Government will do whatever is possible to restrain the public sector borrowing requirement as it affects interest rates. It needs to be said again that the general level of interests rates is ultimately determined by market conditions. These in turn are influenced by the demand for funds in the economy, the market expectations and overseas developments at any particular time. There certainly have been substantial increases in interest rates over the last 12 months or so. I think, as has been said by the Treasurer and certainly by me, no one would wish to see interest rates at a level that makes it difficult for people to own their own homes or for the building industry to be able to be in a healthy state.

ANSWER.PARA: However, given the importance that we have placed on achieving the appropriate restraint in the growth of monetary aggregates as a prerequisite to reducing the rate of inflation, the Government has had no choice but to respond to these market realities and to allow the rates on Government securities to increase. The Budget that is before us makes a very limited public sector demand on the finances that would be affected by interest rates and I think what has been done by the Government in this Budget is to try to assist those who are in the market for home loans by restraining the demands that the Government makes on financial requirements.

As far as the latest statistics on the building industry that were referred to in the question are concerned, I have not those available to me. I could seek some response from the Minister for Housing and Construction on the particular statistic that was released. But I think that the question in general related to whether the Government was concerned about the level of interest rates and about the availability of home finance for those who are seeking home loans. As I have said, the Government is very concerned about this and has taken whatever action it is able to take to restrict its own demands.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Missen asked me a question without notice regarding a report in the Age of 14 September, concerning some alleged action in the Department of Science and Technology about the implementation of the freedom of information legislation. The branch in question has ceased making such copies, but this in no way destroys the official record which is on file, or reduces the Department's ability to respond quickly to requests.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Ryan asked me a question concerning some allegations which had been made in a book to be published called Greed and relating to what is, I think, fairly familiar territory now regarding relationships between the Mr Asia syndicate and other people, including allegedly former officers of the Federal Narcotics Bureau. But as I have been accused of evading the question by the author of this book in a paper I saw today, I have refreshed my mind further by reference to the terms of reference of the Stewart Royal Commission. ANSWER.PARA: I will quote the terms of reference. The Commissioner has been asked to inquire into a number of matters and I will refer only to those terms which are relevant. They state:
(b) whether, in the course of, or in connection with, activities of a kind in paragraph (a)-

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON PARLIAMENT'S APPROPRIATIONS AND STAFFING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to correct some serious misunderstandings relating to the report of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing. I refer to pages 1 to 12 of the Hansard record of the House of Representatives Estimates Committee A proceedings for 8 September 1981. When the Estimates for the Parliament were being considered Mr Chris Hurford was valiantly attempting to gain the support of House Estimates Committee A for the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee and moved a motion to that effect.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Speaker, seemingly also eager to assist, then moved an amendment to Mr Hurford's motion which was agreed to and which called for a 'separate single-line Appropriation Bill' and noted the support of my Select Committee for such a procedure. As Sir Billy was one of the star witnesses, I am delighted to have his support, but unfortunately the Committee did not recommend that which the Speaker suggested. The Select Committee in its deliberations realised that, if the Parliament had its own separate Appropriation Bill, a single line appropriation would be unnecessary.
