DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Ryan proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Federal Government's failure to carry out its constitutional responsibility to ensure fair and just conditions for Aboriginal Australians.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise this matter of public importance today because I and the Australian Labor Party find the situation faced by Aboriginal and Islander people in this country intolerable. We find that that situation grows increasingly more intolerable. We find that there is a deteriorating situation with regard to Aboriginal health, housing, employment, their rights under the law and many other basic areas. What is most inexcusable in this whole situation is the inaction of the Federal Government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is simply not good enough at this stage, when not only the eyes of Australia but also the eyes of the world via the World Council of Churches report have been turned towards the extraordinary disadvantage and oppression of Aboriginal and Islander people in this country, for the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to say that he has nothing to be ashamed of, that he has nothing to be embarrassed about. After he has gone to enormous lengths to prevent the whole issue of Aboriginal Australia being mentioned during the forthcoming Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne, he is now saying that, if the matter is raised, he will be quite happy about it and he is unembarrassed about the situation that his Government is reponsible for. He may be unembarrassed. He may have no difficulty defending the present situation. But the Opposition is embarrassed. The Opposition finds the present situation intolerable and indefensible.

All we can conclude is that at this stage we have a very weak government when it comes to Aboriginal matters. We have a very weak Prime Minister in the form of Malcolm Fraser. We have a very weak Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume. If all they can say is that enough is being done to solve the problems and that, in any case, most of these matters are matters for State governments, that is a weak response to an urgent and critical situation. It is a response from which we on the Opposition side resile completely.

Why is the Prime Minister so weak when it comes to dealing with Aboriginal matters? Why is it that he allows the likes of the Premier of Queensland to go about the country saying that the matter of Aboriginal citizens of Queensland is a matter for the sovereign Government of Queensland? That statement is constitutionally wrong. It is not a matter for the sovereign State of Queensland. It is a matter for the Federal Government and it has been a matter for the Commonwealth Government of Australia since the 1967 referendum.

Why is it that the Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, and his Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume, remain silent when the Premier of Queensland makes these outrageous claims? They know that the constitutional responsibility rests with the Federal Government. Why do they allow his assertion that it is simply a matter for Queensland to go unchallenged? They do so because they are weak and because they are not prepared to face any unfavourable political consequences that might arise if they were to challenge the Premier of Queensland and carry out their Federal Government responsibilities in opposition to what the Premier of Queensland wants.

How long are we to go on allowing this to happen in this country? How long are Aboriginal and Islander people in this country to put up with the Fraser Government's weakness in the face of the likes of the Premier of Queensland and, I must say, the Premier of Western Australia, Sir Charles Court? How long is their situation to remain unaddressed because the Fraser Government is too weak and too politically embroiled in the wrong way to take the steps that must be taken? I think it is timely to remind Government senators of their constitutional responsibilities as a result of the 1967 referendum. It is timely to remind them that the purpose of the referendum was:

to remove any ground for the belief that the Constitution discriminates in some ways against people of the Aboriginal race, and, at the same time, to make it possible for the Commonwealth Parliament to make special laws for the people of the Aboriginal race, wherever they may live, if the Commonwealth Parliament considers this desirable or necessary.

Those words are taken from the official pamphlet entitled Referendums which was published by the Government at the time of the constitutional referendum in 1967 and which set out the case for Yes. A case for a No vote on that referendum was, I am pleased to say, not presented. The pamphlet, referring to the proposed constitutional changes, stated:
We-
That is, the House of Representatives and the Senate-
have yet to learn of any opposition being voiced to them from any quarter.
If that referendum were put today, I imagine that a great deal of opposition would be voiced and we know from which quarter it would come-the Premier of Queensland.

The legislation proposing the constitutional amendments was adopted unanimously in both the House of Representatives and the Senate. The constitutional amendments were not opposed by the States. The Aboriginal referendum was the first and, I understand, the only reference in Australian history to be carried in every constituency in the House of Representatives. Its majority was the most massive in Federal history. Why was the referendum held? Why was there a need for constitutional change? For a long period leading up to the 1967 referendum, criticism of the way State governments treated their Aboriginal citizens was met with complaints by the States that they did not have the money for adequate Aboriginal programs. The Commonwealth Government claimed that it did not have the constitutional power to assist. The States welcomed the decision in the 1967 referendum which allowed for Federal financial input and shifted the responsibility for Aboriginals on to the Commonwealth. The massive Yes vote in the 1967 referendum left the States, the general public and, particularly, the Aboriginal people looking expectantly towards the Federal Government. They were bitterly disappointed.
I remind honourable senators of how long these issues have been going on. In an editorial entitled 'What Aboriginal policies?' the Australian Financial Review of 2 June 1967 stated:
The people have stood up and been counted . . .
Now the testing time has come for the Federal Government.

It has been given an overwhelming mandate from the electorate to improve the lot of the first Australian settlers. If it does not act and act quickly it would be failing that mandate which was implicit in the referendum.
That was in 1967. The Age of 15 June 1967 in an article written by John Jost entitled 'Taking the Responsibility' stated:
When more than 4 million Australians voted at last month's referendum to give the Federal Government power to legislate for Aborigines, most thought the Government had legislation in mind.
But at the present time the only plans the Government has for Aborigines is to count them in the next census.

Despite the fact that the Government has been given the most overwhelming mandate yet given in Australia it already is apparent that the present division of Aboriginal responsibility which exists between the Commonwealth and the States will be perpetuated.

Unfortunately, they were prescient words written in 1967 as it is still the case that this unfortunate division, so deleterious to the welfare of Aboriginal and Islander people, between State and Commonwealth governments has been maintained by coalition governments. The Liberal-National Country party Federal Government between 1967 and 1972 failed to take the necessary steps to improve the living standards of and bring justice to Aboriginal and Islander Australians. That Government made promises to the Aboriginal people which it did not keep.
I quote from an article appearing in the Brisbane Courier-Mail of 14 November 1970 written by Wallace Brown which states:
The Prime Minister--
At that time, Mr Gorton-
Yesterday pledged that all State discriminatory legislation against Aboriginals would be repealed in the next two years.
He also indicated the Commonwealth was likely to take a hard line on this against Queensland, if necessary.
He said: 'I promised in my policy speech last year that this would be done in the lifetime of this Federal Parliament and I see no reason why this will not happen'.

John Gorton said that in 1970. We know that it did not happen. We still have State discriminatory laws. In fact, just last week the Senate failed to eradicate one of them with regard to voting rights for Aboriginals in Western Australia. So it did not happen.

For the huge infusion of funds, the development of a comprehensive policy on Aboriginal affairs and the upsurge in Federal activity to assist Aboriginals, we had to wait for the election of a Labor government in 1972. During the Whitlam years, Aboriginal affairs ceased to be peripheral to the affairs of state, a thorn in the side of a government that it would rather forget, and became an important area of Federal Government concern and activity. It was during this period of the Whitlam Administration that the majority of Aboriginal affairs programs, which the present Prime Minister has recently upheld as being demonstrative of Australia's concern and of the progress that is being made, were conceived and started.

Since the election of the Fraser Government, the area of Aboriginal affairs has been down- graded in terms of importance and financially. In real terms the allocation for Aboriginal affairs has dropped $213m under the current Government despite an election pledge that the level of funding would be maintained. I remind honourable senators that the allocation in this year's Budget was only $147m. There are plenty of figures with which we could contrast that pitiful sum. The one which is perhaps pertinent at this stage is the figure of $20m which has already been allocated to the forthcoming Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. At least $20m will be expended on a meeting which will last a week. For 200,000 Aboriginal Australians, $147m has been allocated for a year. The Prime Minister, in the face of this, says that he has nothing to be ashamed of. If so, why has he been so desperate to keep the issue of Aboriginal Australians off the conference agenda of the forthcoming Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting?

The current Government has failed Aboriginal people in two major ways: It has failed to protect the human rights of Aboriginal and Islander citizens, particularly against racist State governments, and it has failed to redress the gross disadvantage suffered by Aboriginal Australians. Both areas were highlighted in the recent report of the World Council of Churches entitled 'Justice for Aboriginal Australians'. What I have seen, particularly in Queensland, in the Kimberley region of Western Australia and in parts of the Northern Territory, confirms the findings of that report. The living standards and, particularly, the health of Aboriginal people are becoming notorious world wide as one of the most blatant examples of discrimination and deprivation in any free, democratic and affluent Western nation.

I need hardly remind the Senate of statistics which show a drastically reduced life expectancy for Aboriginal Australians. In some States the average life expectancy for Aboriginals is 20 years less than that of the non-Aboriginal population. Infant mortality rates for Aboriginals were, in 1978, three times as high as those for non-Aboriginals and perinatal mortality rates are worsening in many areas. Aboriginal children are 10 times more likely to have ear diseases than non-Aboriginal children and a much higher percentage of Aboriginal children suffer some degree of hearing loss. Trachoma, which in Aboriginal people often leads to blindness, is 15 times greater for Aboriginals than for non-Aboriginals, and in parts of the Northern Territory and Western Australia 77 per cent of the Aboriginal people are affected. Aboriginal people in northern Australia suffer one of the highest strike rates of leprosy in the world. Syphilis has increased amongst Aboriginals to 27 cases in every 1,000 and is increasing. Yet the Prime Minister tells us that he has nothing to be concerned about and nothing to be ashamed of in these circumstances. Surveys over a number of years in parts of the Kimberleys-for example, the Fitzroy Crossing school-have shown that the health of Aboriginals in those areas is deteriorating. This will continue to be the case while unhealthy living conditions, poor nutrition and poverty prevail.

I remind the Senate that when I visited the Kimberleys in April of this year I saw living standards in Aboriginal communities that were worse than the conditions prevailing in refugee camps on the borders of Thailand and Kampuchea, which I visited some 18 months ago. That sort of situation ought to be intolerable to all fair-minded Australians. Even in places where the Aboriginals had secured their own pastoral leases, such as Lake Gregory, Billiluna or Noonkanbah, the degree of material deprivation was severe. The Aboriginals from--

TALK.START.PARA: —Billiluna? Have you ever been there, Senator? Were you really there?

—Senator Peter Baume interjects in a most inappropriate way. Because he will have the opportunity to defend the indefensible when I have finished speaking, I will continue with my remarks. The material deprivation of people living in places such as Lake Gregory, Billiluna or Noonkanbah was not as bad as that of the people in the community which had been expelled from Gordon Downs, whom I met while they were living in a shack on the outskirts of Halls Creek. Many of the old people of this community were blind or ill. The ears, eyes and noses of the children ran and the eyes of many of the adults were obviously diseased. They had their few possessions loaded on the back of a truck and they could not go out to the piece of land they had been allocated at Ringers Soak until they could somehow find enough money to buy provisions. These are circumstances that I have seen. These are circumstances that I could not believe existed in this affluent, modern country, until I saw them with my own eyes. Yet I presume the Minister, carrying out the task of his master, the Prime Minister, will be prepared to defend them.

SPEECH.PARA: When faced with the desperation and hopelessness of such people, one cannot help but realise that the Federal Government has the power to prevent such occurrences. What can the Federal Government do? I remind the Senate that the Federal Government can secure land for Aboriginal people. This is the first and foremost obligation that it has, because it has become clearer and clearer to all of us interested in the Aboriginals and islander people that the secure possession of land is basic to any consequent improvements in their living standards. The Federal Government has inarguably the power to do that. In my view, and in the view of my party-the Australian Labor Party-the Federal Goverment inarguably has the moral responsibility to do it. If the Federal Government acts to do it, it will have the wholehearted support of the Federal Opposition and, I believe, the Australian Democrats in this place.

Further, the Federal Government can act to prevent discrimination against Aboriginals by State governments. It can support, rather than impede, its Commissioner for Community Relations, Mr Al Grassby, in his attempts to enforce the Racial Discrimination Act. The Federal Government can restore funding for Aboriginal advancement programs to 1975 levels and, wherever possible, it can channel funds directly to Aboriginal organisations in line with its stated policy of self-management. However, the Fraser Government has, in the main, failed to do these things. If it believes that, by spending $147m out of a Budget of $41 billion on Aboriginal advancement programs, its responsibility to Aboriginals is discharged it is mistaken. This expenditure will still leave many Aboriginals in blinding poverty; victims of unemployment, homelessness, disease and neglect.

For example, I refer the Senate to information provided to me by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in answer to a question on notice of 4 March 1981. The Minister confirmed that on Napperby Station in the Northern Territory 300 Aboriginal people live in four multi-room shelters. Five more are to be erected this year. This year's expenditure will, therefore, mean that the 300 Aboriginal people on Napperby Station will have nine shelters to live in. There is no water reticulation system and the water is carried from Napperby Creek. The Minister informed me that the Northern Territory Government is studying the feasibility of a proposal to build a dam. In reply to my inquiry as to whether Aboriginals at Napperby are paid award wages, I was told that six Aboriginal pensioners are employed as part time domestics at Napperby and that there is no award for domestics in the Northern Territory. A similar iniquitous situation exists on some Queensland reserves where Aboriginals are permanently classified as trainees and paid half the award wage. On a visit to Palm Island on Monday of this week I was told that the so-called trainee baker had just retired. He had worked in the bakery for 35 years and for the last 15 years had been in charge, yet he was still classed as a trainee and paid less than award wages. The violation of human rights on Queensland reserves is widespread and well documented in books such as Beyond the Act by Malezer, Foley and Richards, which I urge honourable senators to read.

The time allotted to me for raising this matter of public importance in the Senate has almost expired. I urge the Federal Government to acknowledge that it has a very special constitutional responsibility in this matter. It is not good enough and it is not plausible or acceptable to say: 'Let us wait and see what the State governments are going to do. Let us leave it to the Northern Territory Government'. It is not constitutionally proper for the Government to say that and it is impractical because of the vast array of documentation, increasing daily, about the disadvantaged situation of Aboriginal people when left to the mercies of State and territorial governments. In my concluding words, I urge the Fraser Government and its Minister in this place, Senator Peter Baume, to acknowledge their constitutional responsibilities, to stop being conned and frightened by the cries of people such as the Premier of Queensland, to act on their responsibilities and to remove the disadvantage and discrimination that exists against Aboriginal and islander people in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance brought forward by the Opposition in this period prior to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. I believe that the case put by Senator Ryan was factually wrong and exaggerated and that she presented only part of what is a complex picture. One must wonder whether the article which appeared in yesterday's Adelaide Advertiser put stars in her eyes. This is the third Administration of the Fraser Government, each of which has had a commitment to Aboriginal advancement and each of which has pursued administratively the policies designed to improve and advance the welfare of Aboriginal Australians. In each of our policy speeches we have set out what we intend to do. We have pursued those responsibilities with vigour and determination. We are not complacent about the situation in which Aboriginals find themselves. We know how much needs to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: When the World Council of Churches report came out I acknowledged how much needed to be done. I indicated that the situation described in that report was an example of why we needed a Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, why we needed a Ministry of Aboriginal Affairs and why we needed the amount of activity that is going on at present. But it takes more than a few years to reverse the trends of nearly 200 years, especially when they have been 200 years as sorry as those we have seen in Australia. We should do everything we can to improve the conditions of Aboriginal Australians. I only wish the Opposition would be co-operative with our efforts rather than resorting to slogans, quickie nostrums and confrontation.

The matter of public importance calls on us to work to ensure fair and just conditions. The honourable senator who advanced this matter says that the Government has a constitutional responsibility to ensure fair and just conditions for Aboriginal Australians. Irrespective of any constitutional lessons the honourable senator wants to teach us, I have already said that this Government acknowledges what has to be done, and we are involved in trying to do that now. Any fair-minded Australian would support our efforts. But what does the honourable senator mean when she talks so glibly about fair and just conditions? Let us look at what the law and the Constitution now guarantee to every Aboriginal citizen of Australia, indeed, to every one of us. It guarantees voting rights. Voting is compulsory for Aboriginals who enrol. We are committed to making the enrolment of Aboriginal people compulsory as it already is for all other people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Big deal!

—The individual's rights under the common law are the same across Australia. I note the interjection of the Leader of the Opposition. He might reflect on conditions in Africa and note that some people are aspiring to those sorts of things. Aboriginals in this country have access to the whole range of social security benefits. They have access to pensions, the unemployment benefit, the family allowance, the supporting parents benefit and so on. They have a right to award or minimum wages according to the law. We recognise, of course, that Aboriginal people face difficulties in access to these rights and privleges. We do not run away from those facts. We are doing what we can to face up to them, to acknowledge them and to overcome them.

SPEECH.PARA: The World Council of Churches report-inaccurate perhaps at the margins-was nevertheless a reasonable catalogue of some of the difficulties in this field. But we have done a lot about those situations, and we are going to do more. I am sad that I have to keep reminding the Senate of what has been achieved in so short a time because these facts were so notably lacking in Senator Ryan's biased presentation. When will Senator Ryan get the message? Perhaps she does not want to. When will she be prepared to balance our achievements against the blemishes which we readily admit are still with us and which need to be addressed? Perhaps she does not want to acknowledge the achievements. Perhaps to do so is politically inconvenient.

I will repeat what we are already doing and point out just a few of the advances that our critics conveniently ignore. We have developed initiatives across a whole range of activities. We took up the thrust towards land rights. We introduced land rights legislation. We passed the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act through the Parliament in 1976. We have made that legislation work. My predecessor and I have accepted the findings of the Land Commissioner and we have granted land to Aboriginals in the Northern Territory. As a result, large areas of land in the Northern Territory are now in Aboriginal ownership forever. Aboriginals who represent one per cent of the population already hold 10 per cent of the land area of Australia, more than half of it in perpetual freehold. The process still goes on; it is still continuing. We are looking at ways to improve the present legislation. I am engaged now in examining the possibility of getting extra capacity for land tenure in the Northern Territory.

Let us look at self-management, a subject conveniently ignored by Senator Ryan. Nothing epitomises the Government's commitment to real and steady progress in Aboriginal affairs better than our firm policy of self-management. We established the National Aboriginal Conference. Successive Liberal Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs have developed strong ties with the NAC. I personally meet frequently with members of this body. This week already I have had at least one meeting and several communications with the Chairman of the NAC. We meet with members of the Conference formally and informally. The Liberal Government set up the Aboriginal Development Commission in the last couple of years. If one listened to Senator Ryan one would think that we did nothing and did not care. This Commission is the most exciting initiative in practical Aboriginal self-management in recent years. Does Senator Ryan deny that? Of course she does not. She cannot deny it. The Commission, which is attracting considerable international interest, is run by Aboriginals. It is Aboriginalised in terms of its staffing. This financial year the ADC has taken over new and expanded functions on behalf of Aboriginal people. The Commission now holds property worth over $300m. This property is being held by an Aboriginal commission for Aboriginal people. It administers an annual budget now running at more than $50m. Why did Senator Ryan not think that was worth mentioning? It is one of those inconvenient facts that she chooses to leave out. That is real self-management; real Aboriginal progress. We set this initiative in motion.

Surely I do not need to remind the Senate of our continuing support for Aboriginal Hostels Ltd, another all-Aboriginal body which again is a most successful Aboriginal-run enterprise. The staffing of this body is 93 per cent Aboriginal. It operates 2,500 hostel beds across Australia. Senator Neville Bonner is one of the directors of Aboriginal Hostels, and has been since the inception of this most successful Aboriginal enterprise. Perhaps that is not worth mentioning either. This year we are supporting Aboriginal Hostels to the extent of $8m.

We have another good record in the fields of health and social welfare generally. More than 11,500 houses have been provided for Aboriginals since 1968. As I have said, Aboriginal Hostels has a capacity of more than 2,500 beds. Over 240 independent Aboriginal housing associations are now operating. Over 15,000 Aboriginal children are now in secondary school and receiving support. Last year 138 Aboriginals were utilising Aboriginal study grants at universities, 184 were undertaking teacher training, 681 were undertaking other kinds of tertiary studies and 229 were undertaking technical studies. Charles Perkins, who entered Sydney University soon after I left, was the first Aboriginal to enter and complete tertiary studies. This happened a mere 15 years ago. More Aboriginals are graduating from tertiary institutions. This year my Department has allocated almost $11m by way of grants through the States or grants-in-aid to educational processes. The Government supports 19 independent Aboriginal medical services. New services are being supported this year and the extent of support is increasing. Why did Senator Ryan not mention this? She did not because it was inconvenient to do so.

We fund 40 Aboriginal alcohol rehabilitation programs. We are committed to providing $50m over the next five years to improving Aboriginal public health to overcome the very kind of problems to which the honourable senator referred. Our health funding is increasing. Infant mortality is dropping among Aboriginals and health figures are improving. But this was not mentioned by Senator Ryan. It was not convenient for her to do so. Eleven independent Aboriginal legal services operating from 46 locations around Australia handled more than 75,000 cases last year. My Department has allocated $6.5m on legal aid for this year. We have increased the allocation for legal aid by approximately 20 per cent this financial year. We have allocated about $11m directly for employment purposes this year. And so the list continues. In the remote areas of Australia we have introduced community development employment program schemes-CDEP schemes-which have provided work for about 1,300 people in the past year at a cost of about $7m. This was not mentioned by the honourable senator. It was not acknowledged because it is not convenient to do so, because a balanced view is the last thing she is going to present.

The Commonwealth Government this financial year has provided more than $228m for Aboriginal advancement. Some $147m was provided directly through my Department, another $82m through the Department of Housing and Construction, the Department of Education and the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs and smaller amounts through departments such as the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. Our record of achievement is real. It is something of which we can be, and are, proud. The evidence shows steady and continuing progress. The last decade has been one of improvement and of achievement. We do not propose to look back. We propose to look ahead to what we can continue to do. We accept that more can be done. However, here we part company to some extent with the Opposition. It seeks dramatic actions rather than steady progress. It seeks centralist controls. It seeks immediate and massive Federal intervention regardless of whether that is in the long term interests of Aboriginal people. The Opposition is always telling the Government to intervene, to confront, to emphasise disagreement rather than to build on consensus. It wants us to act in ways it thinks, in its innocence and inexperience in government, are decisive. We need only remember where that kind of thing led Australia between the period 1972 to 1975.

On the question of constitutional responsibility, I must again go over old ground. I will try to explain to honourable senators opposite what the Constitution says the Parliament can do in Aboriginal affairs. I shall try again to explain why confrontation may well be self-defeating. The Opposition would like us to think that the Constitution gives the Commonwealth wide and certain powers to do anything at all in the whole field of governmental activity relating to Aboriginal people. To imply that this Parliament has all-encompassing and unlimited powers is both misleading to the Aboriginal people and a misstatement of their legitimate expectations. Those honourable senators opposite who are qualified in law will know that placitum (xxvi) of section 51 has never been tested in the courts. Let us consider the situation prior to the 1967 referendum. The Parliament had power to make laws for the people of any race other than the Aboriginal people in any State for whom it was deemed necessary to make special laws. In introducing the Bill to amend the Constitution-Senator Ryan referred to that debate-the then Prime Minister, who was a Liberal Party Prime Minister, the Right Honourable Harold Holt, explained the position as follows:

An effect of omitting these words will be the removal of the existing restriction on the power of the Commonwealth to make special laws for the people of the Aboriginal race in any State if the Parliament considers it necessary. As the Constitution stands at present, the Commonwealth has no power, except in the Territories, to legislate with respect to people of the Aboriginal race as such. If the words-
He identified them-
Were deleted . . . the result would be that the Commonwealth Parliament would have vested in it-
I draw the following words to the attention of honourable senators-

A concurrent legislative power with respect to Aboriginals as such, they being the people of a race, provided the Parliament deemed it necessary to make special laws for them. It is the view of the Government that the National Parliament should have this power.

That refers to a concurrent power. The people approved that amendment and the restriction was removed. It does not follow automatically that the States lost any powers to legislate on this subject of Aboriginal Australians. The Commonwealth has, at best, concurrent powers with the States. Commonwealth law can override State law but only to the extent that it is a law with respect to Aboriginal people. Just how far that power goes remains a matter largely untested. The gamble is one in which the benefit of the Aboriginal people is at stake. The potential losers of any court challenge are the Aboriginal people-not the Australian Labor Party. They stand to lose if a court makes an adverse decision. They are likely to lose if a course which the courts do not support is taken. The people of the Torres Strait Islands, who are anxious to hold the land that they have held for thousands of years, will be the ones to lose if the Constitution is challenged and found wanting. I ask the Senate to consider that point seriously, but no matter the extent of the constitutional power, we know that the States retain some power and that our power is concurrent with theirs.

I remind the Opposition that we live and must work in a federation. The Government believes in seeking co-operation with the States rather than confrontation as a first step. Even if one stretches the Commonwealth power to the limit there are things that States and local governments must do if Aboriginal people are to enjoy the full range of government services. Provocation and confrontation are not in the best interests of Aboriginal people-which is what I am concerning myself with today rather than the leadership aspirations of Senator Ryan or the interests of the Australian Labor Party. The Aboriginal people, as a minority in Australia, could well become the victims in any confrontation with the States. If the honourable senator's idea of constitutional responsibility is to create a situation in which the losers could be Aboriginal Australians, that is not the Government's view of proper responsibility or proper administration.

This whole matter of public importance has been raised at this time for the least reputable of political motives. Why was today of all days chosen? I will tell the Senate the reason. The debate is merely a curtain raiser to what Senator Ryan would like to think of as her grand strategy of embarrassment of the Government. It is not a strategy which has anything to do with the advancement of the true interests and well-being of Aboriginal Australians, which is what she should be worrying about. Who does she think she will embarrass? She will not embarrass the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), whose record of achievement in the view of the distinguished international visitors who will soon be in Australia stands in the highest esteem. She embarrasses only herself and the Opposition by putting up such a shortsighted, naive, misinformed and mischievous case. I believe that I have answered her case, and I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
