DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND THE ENVIRONMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Science and the Environment: The use of phenoxy chemicals and chemicals containing dioxin, with particular reference to:
(a) their ecological effects; and
(b) their effects on human and animal health

In June 1978 the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment tabled the progress report on the continuing scrutiny of the problems of pollution entitled 'Herbicides, Pesticides and Human Health'. At that time, the Committee was concerned by allegations of a connection between the use of certain agricultural chemicals and the possible deleterious effects on human health. Of particular concern were the phenoxy herbicides 2,4,5-T and 2,4-D. As a result of that concern, the Committee held informal discussions with representatives of Commonwealth government departments and agricultural chemical manufacturers. Several reports available at that time were also examined.

The Committee noted in this report that some State governments had instituted inquiries into the use of pesticides. As a consequence, the Committee deferred recommending a formal Senate inquiry until such investigations were completed. However, as the situation in relation to the use of pesticides and other chemicals has not been systematically examined and as concern at the possible relationship between such chemicals and ill health is still being expressed, the Committee believes that a formal Senate inquiry is now warranted. The Committee will examine the use of herbicides such as 2,4,5,-T and 2,4-D, defoliants used in Vietnam and other phenoxy chemicals and chemicals containing dioxin which are used throughout the community. As this matter is one of immediate concern to many Australians, particularly veterans who served in Vietnam, the Committee intends to report to the Senate by 30 June 1982.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move an amendment to the motion moved by Senator Jessop. Copies of it have been circulated to honourable senators. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That after 'health', insert ', and that in considering this matter the Committee deal first with the possible effects on Vietnam veterans of exposure to herbicides and report to the Senate within eight weeks after this day on the desirability of an independent judicial inquiry into that problem'.

As Senator Jessop said in referring to a previous report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment, there is considerable concern in the community about the possible effects on members of the community and on animal life of these chemicals which were used in Vietnam as a defoliant to destroy crops and clear jungle to make warfare easier. Senator Jessop, in speaking to his motion, said that this is an urgent matter and is of great concern. It is of great concern in particular to the veterans who fought in Vietnam. I believe it was in February last year that I moved on behalf of the Opposition in this place, a motion stating that this was a matter of increasing concern and that in fact there should be an independent inquiry into the effects on Vietnam veterans and their dependants of the use of these chemicals in Vietnam. Since then-in fact, even before then-there has been considerable agitation in the community particularly amongst Vietnam veterans and amongst returned servicemen's organisations in general, including the Returned Services League and, since a few weeks ago, the combined conference of veterans' organisations. Throughout all this time it has been claimed by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) that there was no need for any inquiry at all; all that was needed was an epidemiological study which is being proceeded with by the Government.

After all this time we believe that it is no good the Senate Standing Committee looking at this matter and then have us wait for another 12 months before we get any sort of report on this important matter affecting the Vietnam veterans. It seems to us that everybody in the community, with the exception of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and the Government, believes that there should be at least an independent judicial inquiry. As a fallback, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats were willing to look at establishing a Senate select committee to examine the specific problems of Vietnam veterans and their dependants and the possible effects of exposure to herbicides. We believe that partly as a means of avoiding this Senate select committee inquiry that the desire to refer the matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment has cropped up.

We accept the fact that if the Senate Standing Committee is to look at the problems of 2,4,5-T and 2,4-D, then it would be a duplication and unnecessary burden on honourable senators to have a Senate select committee look at the matter as well. Equally, we believe that the problem of the Vietnam veterans is a special one and therefore that the Committee should look at this problem first. In particular, it should look at the overwhelming wealth of evidence to see whether, in fact, we should not have an independent inquiry into the veterans' specific problem. We believe that any investigation of this matter will conclude that in fact an independent inquiry is needed.

Above all, the problem facing Vietnam veterans is that of the sheer uncertainty of what is happening to them and their dependants. The problem relates to uncertainty about what effect on veterans exposure to chemicals in Vietnam will have. While we in this Parliament and people in the community continue arguing not on a basis of scientific fact or the evidence which has been produced overseas and in this place but on the basis of who is to be responsible for the payment of veterans' treatment, veterans will not receive justice. We believe they should receive justice. It is for this reason, in order to overcome this uncertainty and to clarify the situation, that we believe there should be a judicial inquiry. As the Government will not accept the establishment of a judicial inquiry, we have to accept initially, as second best, the fact that a Senate inquiry is to look into the matter. If a Senate inquiry is to look at the problem, it should first of all examine the specific problems of the Vietnam veterans.

It is for this reason that we have moved the amendment in order to get the Committee to do that promptly. I realise that the Minister wishes to discuss this matter with various people and that he intends to move the adjournment of this debate today. We will accept that adjournment today so that in the next few days we can discuss this matter and quickly get the reference to the Senate Standing Committee. We urge the Government to look at the matter seriously and to stop backing away from this very real problem which faces the Vietnam veterans. Only this week the Returned Services League at its national conference moved that this course of action be taken. In the past the League has been unwilling to take this action, but it now has. That makes the League unanimously on the side of the Vietnam veterans' organisations and on the side of political organisations in this country-with the exception of the Government and the Minister for Veterans Affairs-which say that this should be done. We urge the Minister to reconsider. For that reason I have moved the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I noted with interest the amendment moved by Senator Grimes. I will need a little more time to consider its implications. I am rather upset at the suggestion by Senator Grimes that it is only as a second best to a judicial inquiry that he would entrust the matter to my Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment. The history of judicial inquiries is quite interesting. They take a long time and cost a lot of money. If one compares the reports presented by Senate standing committees-having regard to the fact that every parliamentary party is represented so that the committees present reports reflecting the community interest in a constructive manner for government consideration-with, for example, some reports of judicial inquiries that I have examined since being in this place, I think one will agree that the reports we present here, with the resources available to us, will be seen to be quite extraordinary and extremely good.

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate what Senator Grimes said about the need to come to grips with the problems of people who served in Vietnam. I think Senator Grimes would agree that they are very complex matters. It is difficult to make a quick decision on matters related to the effects of these herbicides not only on the servicemen themselves but also, in an even more complex way, on the effects that they may have on their progeny. I can assure the Senate that my Committee is very concerned about the matter not only in respect of Vietnam veterans but also the possible implications of the use of these chemicals in Australia in their effects on the health of humans in the community at large. I remind Senator Grimes that we have a capacity to enlist the support and advice of experts in genetic and biological matters relating to the use of these pesticides, and that is the sort of action that I as Chairman of the Committee would take and would recommend to ensure that we satisfy the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eight weeks will be plenty of time-no worries.

—Being a medical man, you should know better than that because you would know how complex these matters are. Nevertheless, I would like to give further consideration to the proposed amendment before I resume my remarks. I seek leave to continue my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: QUEENSLAND ABORIGINALS AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDERS (SELF-MANAGEMENT AND LAND RIGHTS) BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 August, on motion by Senator Ryan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In debating the Queensland Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders (Self-Management and Land Rights) Bill 1981 the Senate has heard only the speech of the senator who introduced the Bill, Senator Ryan. I understand that the intention today is to allow time for one contribution from the Government and one from the Australian Democrats so that the first three speeches on this Bill will then be before the Senate. It is my further understanding that the debate will be continued at a later time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government welcomes the Senate's long standing interest in Aboriginal matters and welcomes the desire to examine and debate these matters. I welcome the chance today to add to the response which I gave to Senator Bonner in this place in Question Time on 19 August when he asked me about the Government's position in relation to the Queensland Acts. Of course, being a Queensland senator, he has a particular interest in this matter. It is unfortunate-and I said this earlier this afternoon-if the remarks made in this debate should be seen in some kind of an adversary situation because, I repeat, that what is of concern to us in the Government is that the interests of the Aboriginal and islander communities in Queensland should be protected and should be advanced. I will be sorry if the speed at which the Opposition wishes to pursue this matter leads us into some adversary position.

It is the belief of the Government that the Bill is poorly timed, to say the least. Firstly, we believe the timing has been dictated by a number of partisan and political motives and not really with the best interests of Aboriginals and islanders in mind. Our view is that this not a felicitous time for the Bill to come in. We believe too that the Bill, in the form in which it was introduced, was inadequately justified to the Senate by its proposer. We believe, thirdly, that the Bill is poorly drafted. It contains even proof-reading errors. I refer Senator Ryan to clause 37 (3) of her Bill where there are several references to a 'Land Trust' but then the Bill lapses into talking about a 'Land Council'. Members of the Opposition have not bothered even to proof-read their Bill properly. Further, we believe the Bill is based on an inadequate understanding of Queensland legislation.

I would like to develop those arguments in a calm way, emphasising again that our concern is the interests of the Aboriginal and islander communities in Queensland. Let me start with the timing of the Bill. Senator Ryan put forward two reasons for the introduction of the Bill in its present form at the present time. Indeed, the argument that the Bill should be introduced now is a central part of her argument. Senator Ryan-I think I quote correctly-said:
Queensland Aboriginals living on reserves are facing a crisis, a crisis which is likely to be resolved against their interests by the Government of Queensland.
She further said:
. . . the threatened degazettal of the reserves is now imminent.

What crisis? I repeat: What crisis? The long-term prospect that reserves would go was foreshadowed by the 1978 report on Aboriginal and islander communities. That report envisaged only residential leases for what were then called older residents. That was in 1978.

Since the election commitment of the National Party in Queensland in November 1980 to make possible the repeal of the Queensland Acts the Premier and his Ministers have been reassuring Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders-reassuring them-that reserve lands are not threatened. I refer the Senate to public statements by the Premier, by the Minister for Aboriginal and Island Affairs, Mr Tomkins, by the Acting Minister, Mr Wharton, when Mr Tomkins is away. They have all gone to some lengths to reassure the Aboriginal and islander communities. They have said that some form of tenure allowing Aboriginal and Torres Strait islander control of reserve land will become available. They do not have that available now. The Premier himself has proposed 50-year leases for the communities. Mr Tomkins, the Minister in Queensland, has talked of perpetual leases. All of them have indicated that Aboriginal and Torres Strait islander participation in community management will be increased. All of this is a considerable advance both on the propositions of 1978 and on the November 1980 election propositions as we heard them. Any crisis has been manufactured by those seeking confrontation between the Commonwealth and the States for their own political purposes.

It is simply not true to suggest that this is some kind of last chance to win recognition of land rights in Queensland. It is silly; it ignores the history of the last 20 years during which Queensland has been moving progressively, even if very slowly, in changing its legislation and its administration of Aboriginal affairs, largely, I acknowledge, in response to Commonwealth pressure. Queensland has not announced any firm proposals for the land tenure or self-management which it hopes to see with respect to Queensland reserves. It has not as a government announced what those firm proposals are. Further, it is unlikely that any such proposals will be known until the end of October, the middle of October, perhaps earlier-I cannot say when. Indeed, at one stage the Premier spoke of referring the matter to a parliamentary committee.

The Senate does not help by giving in to hysteria, to claims of urgency, when those concerned in Queensland have not even announced what it is they intend to do. It is very hard to condemn what has not been proposed. The Senate is likely to sit for some time yet, so what is the urgency? Senator Ryan claimed outside this place-in fact on a radio program on 1 September-that the Government would like to delay the matter and that if we delay we will be the ones to pay the political price. Surely by now she understands that it is the Aboriginal and islander communities who will have to pay the price. They will be the ones to pay the price if hasty, ill-considered Bills are rushed through. I urge her to stop thinking like a Federal politician and to start thinking of the constituents and the clients. Their interests should be dominant.

The Government is quite happy to discuss the matter. What discussion of the matter will reveal is that the Bill is ill conceived, poorly drafted and poorly timed. Perhaps Senator Ryan gives the clue in her second reading speech when she says that one reason for the urgency is:
. . . the imminence of an important international event to be held in this country.
And that is the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course. We acknowledge that.

—'Of course', the honourable senator interjects. It is a partisan Australian Labor Party political objective and not an Aboriginal and Islander objective. CHOGM has been meeting in different countries for a long time. It is not concerned with the domestic issues of member countries; it has never been concerned with the domestic issues of member countries. Senator Ryan's motive is to discredit the Government's standing and Australia's standing internationally for temporary political advantage. It is not a move which will work to the advantage or the advancement of Aboriginals or Islanders. What Senator Ryan in effect is saying is that this matter is urgent because the Australian Labor Party wants to make a big splash in relation to CHOGM. That is mischievous and indefensible.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the Commonwealth Government's position? On 19 August I told the Senate that four principles require to be encompassed in any settlement of the future of Queensland reserves. It is worth reminding the Senate of those principles. They were: That the integrity of the present reserve boundaries should be maintained; that there should be secure tenure for the occupants and preservation of their usufructuary rights, their rights to use the land; that local communities should play a significant role in the management of the reserves; and that there should be full consultation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people before any decisions are made. That sets out the Government's position. It is a very defensible position. It is a position which proposes a set of conditions which are to the advantage of Aboriginal and Islander communities. We are watching the situation closely in the light of those principles.

I am continuing to consult and to keep in touch with Queensland Government figures. I believe that they understand our position. Various ideas have been aired by Queensland Government spokesmen but nothing has been decided, nothing has been announced, in Queensland. How can it be urgent for Senator Ryan to override what has not yet been proposed in any firm form? The Aboriginal and Islander people are consulting each other now. They are consulting the Queensland Government. We are concerned to ensure that they have every opportunity to do so without distraction.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were down here.

—My colleague mentions that they have been down here. This week I saw a delegation from the Torres Strait and they presented a very reasoned and reasonable view. Their concern is for the future of their reserves. They do not have a party political concern.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to pick up some of the semantics which tend to confuse the debate. The term 'land rights' is capable of many interpretations. Land rights do not have the same relevance to a situation in which there is a tribal structure or in which attachment to the land in question can be demonstrated as they have perhaps to the situation in Queensland in which in many areas there is less tribal structure and in which attachment to the land could not be demonstrated. Let me be quite clear about that: If the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act applied in Queensland many of the communities there would not be able to claim and would not be able to succeed in a claim for land. The Northern Territory land rights model is inappropriate for Queensland. It is a different model in a different situation. The conditions of that model do not apply to much of Queensland. We need a different model for Queensland.

What we are seeking is adequate land tenure, secure tenure, and rights to self-management. Maybe that is what we should be talking about. Maybe we should be talking about the outcomes of tenure, security and management. Maybe they are the things that matter. The words 'land rights' have been confusing the debate and confusing the argument more than they have been helping it. Rights to land can be of an enormous range and variety. What is important is that a security of tenure is vested in the Aboriginal people in such a way that the land remains under the control of the community-it cannot be sold off-and Aboriginals can have self-management.

TALK.START.PARA: —It cannot be alienated.

—I accept my colleague's comment that it cannot be alienated. The essential element is security of land tenure. Of course, there is a whole variety of ways in which that can be achieved and in which we should approach the matter. At this moment the reserves in Queensland are not secure. The Aboriginals and the islanders do not have secure tenure today. They can be de-gazetted overnight. They were de-gazetted overnight a couple of years ago in one notorious example. Therefore, any form of tenure in the hands of Aboriginals themselves is likely to provide a better situation than that which we have now. It would be an advancement.

SPEECH.PARA: The question is: What is best for the long term interests of the Aboriginal people? Surely the Senate needs to see more of what is intended before we can really answer that question. We need to know what legal arrangements are proposed, just what legislation is to be repealed or amended. How can Senator Ryan suggest a pre-emptive strike before that is even known? We need to know something about the proposed administrative processes. We need to know that Queensland departments or agencies will have a part to play in any future arrangements affecting reserves and their residents. But at present we are being asked to take part in a shadow boxing match.

I turn to the justification for the Bill. I join Senator Ryan in that part of her speech which set out a recitation of the tragic history of Aboriginal dispossession and dispersal, particularly in the 19th century.

TALK.START.PARA: —No one can dispute it.

—Senator Bonner says that no one can dispute it. We certainly do not want to dispute it. The Queensland Acts for Aboriginals and islanders from 1897 were designed, in terms of the philosophy of that time, to separate and to control Aboriginal people. The announcement of the Premier of Queensland that the Acts would be repealed should really be welcomed by Senator Ryan because that would do away with those features. I can recall being told in this place over the years that the people in Queensland were moving around shouting 'Smash the Acts'. Those people should be welcoming the repeal of the Acts.
—I cautioned against it.

—Senator Bonner cautioned against it because in fact those Acts contain protection as well as disadvantage for Aboriginal people. It is very important that we know what is proposed. Nothing in Senator Ryan's outline of Queensland Aboriginal history really justifies intervention today; nothing, that is, apart from the partisan political elements of her speech. Senator Ryan listed a number of specific aspects of Queensland's Act which she said she wanted to correct. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: Aboriginal reserve councils do not have control over access to reserves.

That is not so. If Senator Ryan goes to section 17(2) of the Aborigines Act she will find that the councils or the Director of the Department of Aboriginal and Islanders Advancement has power to eject persons. She will find that under section 20 of that Act the councils and the Director may give permits for residence. She will find that under section 24 of that Act councils alone give permits to visit. In practice, the councils almost always determine such matters alone. She is wrong on that. She said that she wanted to correct the aspect whereby 'reserve managers retain veto powers'. That is not so. The councils have absolute powers over entry by visitors. They may also veto applications for residence. I note also that section 27 of the Act allows for appeals to a magistrate from decisions of either the council or the Director. Senator Ryan asserted that she wanted to correct the situation whereby 'residence on reserves is revocable at any time by the Minister'. That is not so. Residence permits may be revoked only by the council or the director. Again, there is provision for appeal to a magistrate.

Senator Ryan asserted that we had to correct the situation whereby 'Aborigines on reserves can still be required to work for token payment'. That is not so. A decision of Mr Justice Mathews on 29 May 1979 in the Queensland Industrial Court stated in effect that Aboriginals on reserves had to be paid at the award rate for work. Section 11 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Discriminatory Laws) Act 1975, passed in this Parliament, proscribes the employment of an Aboriginal or islander on terms less favourable than would apply if the employee were not an Aboriginal or islander. The legislative structure is there which indicates that that kind of statement of the honourable senator's is wrong. Senator Ryan said that we had to correct a situation where 'transactions entered into by Aboriginals may be varied or cancelled by the Director'. This is only partly true. It is applied only to Aboriginals who wish to have their affairs managed by the director. They can opt out of such arrangements at any time.

Senator Ryan asserted that we have to correct a situation where 'court proceedings for Queensland Aborigines on reserves are conducted according to different rules'. She is correct on that. Thank goodness she is correct on one of those things. An aggrieved person, of course, may appeal to a magistrates court. It seems, therefore, that Senator Ryan is unaware of changes made to the Queensland Acts in 1979. I want everyone in the Senate to note that the Commonwealth does not support what are collectively called the offensive provisions of the Queensland Aborigines Acts. That Commonwealth position is well known to Queensland authorities. The Commonwealth's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Discriminatory Laws) Act overrides the provisions of Queensland Acts which are incompatible with human rights conventions. The honourable senator should have known that. The Act provides a defence for any Aborigine charged under these provisions. She should have known that. In relation to the drafting of the Bill, the honourable senator, in her second reading speech, said that 'none of the principles of this Bill are radical or new'. The Bill empowers councils to make any law for conduct, discipline and the wellbeing of members without outside involvement or parliamentary scrutiny and in any manner the councils decide. This could allow extreme penalties for trivial conduct without the right of appeal. Is that not radical or new?

The Bill exempts councils, under clauses 10 and 14, from application of Queensland laws and inserts no Commonwealth laws to fill the void. Under clause 18 the Bill imports a new and peculiar definition of 'traditional Aboriginal owner' which is certainly inappropriate to many of the Queensland reserves. Few of the residents of the Cherbourg, Woorabinda, Palm Island and Yarrabah reserves would qualify under the honourable senator's definition, and that may leave the land without beneficial owners. Clause 28 reserves minerals to the Crown in right of Queensland but limits Queensland's access to them. Clause 28 (5) of the Bill purports to impose an obligation on a State officer to register a title granted by the Commonwealth. What the honourable senator may not know but should have known is that the High Court of Australia has previously held such provisions to be invalid. Clause 40 would preclude a State officer-for example, a policeman-who was acting in the performance of his duty from entering upon land vested in a land trust without the consent of the trust. The Bill makes no alternative provision for the preservation of law and order on land held by a trust. The honourable senator says that there is nothing radical or new. How radical can one get? The question is: Would it work anyway?

I need to address myself to the effectiveness or ineffectiveness of the Bill. I refer to the work done by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs under the chairmanship of my colleague Senator Missen. In 1978 that Committee, in talking about the Queensland situation, said that the Commonwealth response to Queensland should be flexible and that it should deal with the conditions on different Aboriginal communities as it found them-that is, that it would 'not consider that a single general statute . . . provides the best means' of achieving Aboriginal self-management of reserves. That is referred to in paragraph 77 of the Missen committee report. I believe a unanimous decision was taken on this. Labor senators were present. No doubt Senator Evans was a member of the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Indeed.

—As Senator Missen says, indeed. This Bill would set aside a principal, important and sensible finding of the Missen committee. Senator Ryan claimed that the course of action set out in the Bill was recommended by the report of the Senate Standing Committee. In fact, the Missen committee report recommended specifically against proceeding in this way. This Bill would not allow the flexibility envisaged by the Senate's own committee which examined the matter in depth only three years ago. The Bill's internal inconsistencies between the self-management provisions and the land acquisition provisions make it unworkable and anything but flexible.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at clause 42. Clause 42 of the Bill provides for a reserve to cease to be a reserve if land is acquired and vested in a land trust. Hence the first part of the Bill, which provides for self-management of reserves, would cease to apply. There would be no councils, no self-management -just a vacuum. Any government determined to frustrate the Bill could do so by tying it up in litigation. Who would win out of that? Certainly not the Torres Strait Island people or the Queensland Aboriginal people. We would be leading them to a road of litigation over years and years. The Bill asks the Commonwealth Government to acquire the reserves. The honourable senator knows that the Australian Constitution requires that this be done by payment of 'just terms' to the owners. The owners in this case would be the Queensland Government. Where would the money come from? How much would be involved? What other programs would the Senate wish to sacrifice for the Australian people to make way for this? How much better it would be if we could work to a situation of agreement and concensus whereby Queensland, the Commonwealth and the Aboriginal people could decide how the objectives we set out-security of tenure, self-management, preservation of the integrity of the boundaries, maintenance of the usufructuary rights and proper consultation-were implemented. If those things could be achieved by concensus how much better it would be for everyone-except the Australian Labor Party.

This Bill does not achieve its objectives. Perhaps the drafting deficiencies could be overcome in time, but that only emphasises once again the undue haste and the lack of thought that has gone into this and the need for more time to examine some of the deficiencies in the drafting of the Bill. The scheme simply will not fit together. The Bill is not urgent until the Commonwealth Government knows what Queensland's proposals are. The details of Queensland's proposals are not expected for some weeks yet. I would stress again the Commonwealth position-a position which sets out a defensible set of proposals and propositions for Aboriginal and islander people in Queensland. People know what it is the Commonwealth wants to achieve. We believe these things can be achieved by proper consultation with the Queensland Government. These principles have set down the fundamental Commonwealth position, namely, integrity of the reserve boundaries, security of tenure-the right to use the land-and self-management. These principles set down the Commonwealth's position. We wish to avoid confrontation if we can do so. We wish to act only in the best long term interests of Aboriginal and islander people. The consultations are proceeding. Let us see what comes from them. Then it will be time enough to consider the legislation.

Let me make it quite clear that the Government has grave reservations or doubts about this Bill for many reasons, not the least of which is that the Bill is premature, ill-considered, poorly drafted and based on the misapprehension that Commonwealth intervention is both necessary and desirable or that it is necessary now. However, I believe that no one can deny that we should wait and see. My colleagues Senator Missen and Senator Bonner have indicated to me-I am very grateful to them-their intention to move an amendment to the second reading stage of this Bill. I merely foreshadow the amendment. In brief the amendment which they intend to move will suggest a deferral of any vote on the second reading of the Bill until the Senate has more and better information about the intentions of the Queensland Government on this whole matter. The amendment also has the added safeguard of proposing the resumption of the debate, in any event, to the next sitting day after the end of October. It is always competent for the Senate to make other arrangements if it so wishes. I think all honourable senators should consider very carefully the advantages to Aboriginal and islander people of considering and accepting this amendment after it has been moved. It is being sponsored by the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs which considered the Queensland situation and came up with specific proposals, and also by the first Aboriginal Australian ever to sit in the Federal Parliament, an honourable senator from Queensland who understands what is involved.

I think the overriding concern of this place must be for the welfare, in the long term, of the Aboriginal and islander people. Therefore, when the Senate acts, it should be sure that it does so on the basis of all information. Information is not available to date; it will not be available for some time. It would be premature to move in now. It would not help consideration of the Bill and I hope that honourable senators will support the amendment when the debate is resumed in a week or so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Queensland Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders (Self-Management and Land Rights) Bill 1981 which has been brought forward by Senator Ryan has the support of the Australian Democrats. The points that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) has made are many and varied and will, I think, be answered as I proceed with what I have to say on this Bill. However, I take one point at the commencement of my speech. To counsel a non-partisan approach and then to make a partisan speech on an issue such as this I find not only incomprehensible but also in extremely bad taste.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill that we are debating we should not be debating. Indeed, it should not have been the responsibility of a private member of the Senate to introduce such a Bill. This Bill may have a series of weaknesses and problems in its drafting. I believe we will come to those matters in due course through the normal procedures in this chamber when we discuss the Bill item by item in the Committee stage, and that is as it should be. But if the Government had provided from its resources sufficient expert backup there would not be drafting problems. Indeed, the Government ought to have introduced such a Bill. Whilst the Minister says let us wait and see, I am quite sure that the Aboriginal people of Australia can only groan yet again. Have they not been waiting and seeing for the period of occupation of this country by white people? Has it not been their lot for over 200 years to wait and see? Yet we are counselled again: 'Let us wait and see'.

The Liberal and National Country parties, at least in the federal sphere, are by their policies committed to the principle that all Aboriginals and islanders should be as free as other Australians to determine their own varied futures. Their policy also states that they intend to respond to the basic claims by Aboriginals for self-management, land rights, additional funds and self-sufficiency. While the Minister may withdraw from his own party's commitment to land rights, the Australian Democrats hold very firmly that the notion of land rights is one from which we should not withdraw until it has been achieved. Giving all of the other points that the Minister spoke of will not give the Aboriginals what they want. They want handed back the land that was taken from them. It is as simple as that. As one Aboriginal from Palm Island said to me only a few weeks ago: 'All we want in Queensland is the little bit of land that we have left'. It is as simple as that. Surely this chamber and this Parliament can be generous to such an appeal.

I hope that as this Bill moves forward through all its stages, not with undue haste, not with attempts to sidetrack it or to put it away, everybody in this chamber-since every party in this chamber is committed to the principles contained in this Bill-will speak in support of its principles and that we may put aside, at least for once, our own partisan feelings on this matter. Let us all support the principles, and let us then talk about how they may be achieved. If this Bill is not good enough or sufficient enough to achieve those principles, let us amend the Bill until it becomes sufficient to achieve them. Let us do that now, and let us proceed on that course until the legislation is complete. Let us do it not only for Queensland but also for every State so that by the time we get to the bi-centenary of the white invasion of this country, the Aboriginal population will also have something to celebrate.

I go back some way into history because I believe that there are afoot in Australia many misconceptions in relation to Aboriginal land claims. I should like to put down basically what our position is in relation to these claims. I think there are no dissenters from the acknowledgement now that the Australian Aboriginals were Australia's first inhabitants and that they came to this country, probably over the land bridge from South East Asia, before the Ice Age, some 40,000 years ago. From that time until the white invasion there were many contacts between the Aboriginal population of Australia and other groups. Indeed, there was some fairly extensive trading between Aboriginals, particularly in the north of my own State and peoples from various South East Asian countries. What is not understoood is that when the white invasion occurred the Aboriginal population did not simply give in, as the history books read-at least that is how they read when I and probably other honourable senators went to school-but a bloody war was waged in Australia between the original inhabitants and the invaders. Unfortunately, in Queensland, most of the official histories are silent on the resistance, the battles and the massacres that took place. It is only now that the historians are starting to document some of these matters so that all people in Australia may come to understand a little better those years which were so vitally important. I refer here to works such as Harry Reynold's recent work 'The Unrecorded Battlefields in Queensland'. This and other works being written by historians will, I believe, lead the white population to a better understanding of the Aboriginal population and its place in this country.

By 1897 in Queensland we had reached the stage, despite this resistance, despite the battles, despite the massacres and despite many white settlements having to be abandoned because of the surprising strength of the Aboriginal resistance, where the Minister, that is the Home Secretary, was empowered under the Act to cause every Aboriginal within any district to be removed to and kept within the limits of any reserve in such a manner as he may prescribe. Also, the Minister was able to cause any Aboriginal to be moved from one reserve to another. In other words, by that time we had virtually reached a position of slavery in this country. We might wonder how we managed to get to that position when we discover that the instructions to Governor Phillip in 1787 were as follows:

You are to endeavour by every possible means to open an intercourse with the natives, and to conciliate their affections, enjoining all our subjects to live in amity and kindness with them. And if any of our subjects shall wantonly destroy them, or give them any unnecessary interruption in the exercise of their several occupations, it is our will and pleasure that you do cause such offenders to be brought to punishment according to the degree of the offence.

They were the official instructions given to Governor Phillip. Of course, they were ignored. They were ignored to such an extent that in 1834 a Select Committee of the House of Commons reported as follows:

It might be presumed that the natives of any land have an incontrovertible right to their own lands; it is a plain and sacred right which appears not have been understood. Europeans have entered their borders uninvited, and when there have not only acted as if they were the undoubted lords of the soil, but have punished the natives as aggressors if they have evinced a disposition to live in their own country.
I repeat: ' . . . if they have evinced a disposition to live in their own country'. In the report of another House of Commons committee in 1837, it is stated:

These people, unoffending as they were towards us, have, as might have been expected, suffered in an aggravated degree from the planting amongst them of our penal settlements. In the formation of these settlements it does not appear that the territorial rights of the natives were considered, and very little care has since been taken to protect them from the violence or the contamination of the dregs of our countrymen.

The land has been taken from them without the assertion of any other title than that of superior force, and by the commissions under which the Australian colonies are governed, Her Majesty's sovereignty over the whole of New Holland is asserted without reserve . . .
It is remembered that unsettled land has been sold by the Government of New South Wales . . .
Indeed, it was sold by other States. It was sold off as though its ownership was undisputed. Yet, the committee went on:
. . . every part of this territory was the undisputed property of the Aborigines.

I mention those items because what we have, and what we are looking at in 1981, is not the giving of land to Aboriginals but, indeed, acceding to land rights. I think that phrase should remain in use. The situation that we have in Australia is that the complex and unique relationship built up over those 14,000 years of Aboriginal occupation of the land of Australia means that they have a relationship to that land which was theirs-a relationship which was not, as it were, owned by them but which was part of them. I would like to quote from Father Pat Dodson's description of their relationship to the land because I believe it captures something that we cannot capture even in the four points that the Government has put forward. Those four points might settle white people's consciences but they will not settle the spiritual demands of the Aboriginal people. Father Dobson said:

'We heard land being described as a ''piece of dirt''. That would be the same as someone who considered St. Peter's as just a barnyard to the Catholics. But for the Aboriginal people land is a dynamic notion; it is something that is creative. Land isn't just bound up with geographical limitations that are placed on it by a surveyor, who marks out a plot and says: ''This is your plot''. Land is the generation point of existence; it's the maintenance of existence; it's the spirit from which Aboriginal existence comes. It's a place; a living thing made up of sky, of clouds, of rivers, of trees, of the wind, of the sand, and of the Spirit that's created all those things; the Spirit that has planted my own spirit there, my own country. It's something and yet it's not a thing; it's a living entity.

The Aboriginal people are not asking for security; they are asking for their land. They are not asking for usufruct; they are asking for their spirit. Let us not do what we are counselled against in our religious traditions-that is, when they ask for bread, give them stone.

I turn now to the position for which the Minister for Aborginal Affairs has argued in relation to this Bill, suggesting that it is ill-considered, ill-drafted and ill-timed. I believe it may be ill-timed because it is long overdue; and it may be ill-considered because all it does is give the Aborigines the land that is left. That it is ill-drafted is something with which we can surely deal here, with good will among all honourable senators. We are dealing specifically with land in Queensland. I think it is important to look at the position of the Queensland Government in relation to lands in that State. Let us allow the Queensland Government to speak for itself, and turn to the documents of that Government. I start with a statement made in 1977 by the then Minister for Lands, Mr Tomkins, who is now the Minister for Aboriginal and Islander Affairs. It is pertinent that we should look at a Minister for Lands because, as I am sure the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs knows, Aboriginal reserves in Queensland are not held under Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Acts but rather are held under regulations of the Lands Act in Queensland. Mr Tomkins said:

If this programme is extended . . . it would create a 'black state' across the whole of northern Australia-surely apartheid in extreme and an introduction of the South African Bantustan policy to Australia, a situation the Queensland Government will not tolerate. It concerns me not because they are black but because this area would be allowed to become a burden on Australian generosity.

If Archer River was sold to whites they would have to pay for it and run it on profitable lines. We refused to approve the transfer because we saw no evidence of Aborigines doing this. In fact, it would be harmful for them to be given it.

They're good employees, good horsemen and musterers. It just seems to me most are on unemployment relief. It's all very well to say Aborigines own Australia because they were here first, but we think that if they want to get hold of certain lands they should do it the same way as whites-
I am not sure whether he would actually suggest that they rob and pillage it as whites did, but he continued:
-work, make money, buy a block of land, and pay it off . . .
It was whites who developed Australia.

We find that the Premier of Queensland, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, is quoted in the Canberra Times in relation to Mr Tomkins latest suggestions that perhaps perpetual leases may be introduced. The Premier said 'no way'. He is reported as saying:
We've made them Queenslanders-let's take them further on the way.
He went on to say:
But no way will they be given land rights.
A media release issued a short while ago by the Premier stated:
Equality and progress for Queensland aboriginal and island people was the continuing policy of State Government, the Premier, Mr Joh Bjelke-Petersen, said today.
This policy will result in the successful integration of our indigenous peoples into the mainstream of our community . . .

He said the Queensland Government opposed the Commonwealth Government's ''old hat policies of the failed Whitlam era'' because they promoted separate development and isolation of our indigenous people from the rest of the community.
The media release continued in like vein until its conclusion:

What the radicals want backed by the Commonwealth is a land grab or just another version of the old ''cargo cult'' mentality. If the radicals got their way the aboriginals and islanders would be thrown into some type of socialist commune with the radicals skimming the cream off the indigenous cake. There are forces abroad trying to create a nation within a nation and these must be resisted in the interests of a greater Australia and a brighter future for all Australia in a peaceful, comfortable and equal society.

A peaceful, comfortable and equal society for whom? After those statements of the Queensland Premier, despite the sanguine gloss placed on the Queensland Government by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, I think I am not so sanguine that any position held so strongly by the Premier of Queensland will be overturned in the interests of the Aboriginal people. To put such a suggestion is to fly in the face of everything that the Queensland Government has done in relation to Aboriginal affairs. Indeed, it flies in the face of that Government's attitude to Acts passed by the Liberal-National Country Party Government.

In essence the Bill is seeking to do two things. It seeks to have the Commonwealth take over from Queensland approximately 2,287,000 hectares or 1.8 per cent of the total area of Queensland. It is then proposed that this land be given freehold title and be given to the Aboriginal communities to be governed by the Aboriginal communities. I suggest that whether we do that now, next year or in 10 years time there will be no end to the white problem of the Aboriginals until the Aboriginal people have that land. They must have the land and they must have control and ownership of it. I believe that then and only then will we see some start to a genuine integration of the white and black communities in Australia. It is then that they will be able to take their rightful place in Australia, we will be able to set about settling that racial hatred which has grown up for so many years in this country; and at last we will be able to settle our debts to the Aboriginal people.

This Bill asks no more than that. It asks no more than that we accede to all of those international treaties which we have signed such as the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, the United Nations Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide and the International Labour Organisation declaration concerning indigenous people and their relationship to their land. We accept all those treaties and we are currently in breach of all those treaties. The fact that the type of action envisaged in this Bill will lead to integration, I believe, is a matter not of wishful thinking but very much of hard political reality and, more importantly, economic reality.

I contrast the way people react to statements of the Northern Land Council with the way they react to statements of the National Aboriginal Conference and ask: Why? It is very simple. The Northern Land Council is an economic power to be reckoned with. It has land, mineral resources and money and those things speak in white Australia. The National Aboriginal Conference has the voice of only the dispirit peoples, the original inhabitants of this country, and it speaks with a very quiet voice, certainly in the Senate. I think that is why the land, if it is given back to the Aboriginals, will provide them not only with their spiritual desires but also with their economic base upon which to integrate into a broader Australian community as a power to be reckoned with in that community in a way in which it actually means something in the forums of this land.

Lastly, I ask honourable senators to think on a particular proposition-a hypothetical proposition, but one which I believe brings home, at least to white people in Australia, what Aboriginal people feel. Let us assume that during the last war the Japanese had, indeed, captured this country. I was born during that war and I am quite sure that my parents, in pointing to those people who had taken our land by invasion, would have said: 'This is your land; it is not theirs. They may be controlling it and they may be running it but it is yours'. I would say to my children, who are now growing up: 'This is your land; it is not theirs. It is yours to own'. I think I would have been devastated if they had said to me: 'That is in the past. Forget about that. That means nothing'. It does mean something. It means something to the Aboriginal people because that is the time span involved. A couple of generations is all that we are talking about. It is a couple of generations from the time when in my State people in fact went riding on a weekend to shoot Aboriginals for fun. That is the reality of this country. I have met someone whose parents were killed in that way. For us to say that that is in the past and means nothing now must be one of the most ungenerous, disgusting statements one could ever hear.

TALK.START.PARA: —It lives on in the memory of the descendants.

—It lives on in the memory of those people. It is their land and it remains their land. This matter will not be settled until they have the land. I appeal to all honourable senators in the interests of this country and the people of this country, to put aside their differences, at least for once. Let us work on this Bill in harmony and good will. It may not be everything but let us work with it until it is perfect and until we know that it will satisfy those people and those demands. If we did that, I think we could rest assured that at least the Senate had done something that would remain in the history books forever.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Jones, I inform the Senate that this is the honourable senator's first speech in this chamber, known as his maiden speech. I ask all honourable senators to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, Mr President, let me take this opportunity to congratulate you on your election to the high office of President of the Senate. As a new senator in this place, I hope your impartiality will allow all honourable senators to play constructive and worthwhile roles as representatives of their respective States. I wish you well in this important office. Secondly, but no less importantly, I congratulate Senator Doug McClelland on his elevation to the office of Deputy President. It is interesting to note that Senator McClelland's election was supported by the Australian Labor Party senators, the Australian Democrat senators, and the independent senator on this side of the House. I believe the Government's support of you, Mr President, and the support of this side of the House for the Deputy President, will build a worthwhile team that will serve this Senate well. I would also like to congratulate other senators who have made their maiden speeches.

SPEECH.PARA: As a senator representing Queensland in this place, I take this opportunity to thank the electors of Queensland for the support they have given to the Australian Labor Party Senate team, to myself and to the other members of that team. Since arriving in this place, I cannot help but be affected by the manner in which the Parliament is conducted-the remoteness of the proceedings from the people of Australia. This remoteness and the added secrecy of the Government are shown clearly in the Review of Commonwealth Functions in 1981. The Budget brought down last month further removes the Government and the Parliament from the people.

The Budget is a document that isolates the Government from the people. It shows that the Government has no feeling for the plight of the small man It is a Budget that widens further the division that has developed in our society between the haves and the have nots. On housing, the Government has decided that the young intending home buyer should be placed on the rental treadmill, and that he should never be able to get off. It has crushed the Australian dream. The Government has abolished the Community Youth Support Scheme. The announcement was made in the Budget. It stated:
The Government has decided to terminate the Community Youth Support Scheme on October 31, 1981.

This Government has said to the youth of Australia: 'Because you are unemployed, we do not want to, or need to, assist you in any way-not even to find employment. We are only a government of the haves'. But what did the Government do to employed people? It increased the amount of tax payable. Sales tax increased-a value added tax by another name. Students, single parents, pensioners and war veterans-few people have been left untouched by the ruthless actions of a government that has pitted itself against the people of Australia.

Before I take some points in relation to the Budget, let me return to the booklet 'Review of Commonwealth Functions' the razor gang's bible. I turn to page 22 of this booklet under the heading 'Home Affairs and Environment', sub-heading 'Uranium'. I was totally shocked by the following entry in this infamous publication:

Responsibility for the regulation and control of nuclear activities in Australia to be implemented as far as possible by the States and Northern Territory, with the Commonwealth maintaining a co-ordinating role.

That is a rather clear and concise statement under the name of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson). Responsibility for control of nuclear activities is to be implemented as far as possible by the States. Let us take a moment to reflect on who controls the States of Western Australia and Queensland-Premier Court and Premier Bjelke-Petersen. I note that Mr Bjelke-Petersen could scarcely get to his telephone quickly enough to applaud the concept.

But the matter is not so clear and concise. Following a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, the first point that confused me was that the Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Carrick, stated that the question more primarily concerned his portfolio. Either the Minister for Home Affairs could not answer the question or there was a misprint in the booklet on the razor gang cuts, or the item referring to the control of nuclear activities being handed over to the States should have appeared under the portfolio of Senator Carrick. It would now appear that, according to Senator Carrick in answer to my question:
Matters that largely affect the States are health matters.

I would not like to entrust my health to the two Premiers mentioned. Senator Carrick stated further that a Commonwealth code had been sought from the States and was 'substantially obtained' in the code of mining as it concerns the mining and milling or uranium. If this is the case, if the States do have a code that covers mining and milling, why have accidents such as the reported spill of an overflow or radioactive material from the Queensland Mines Ltd uranium development in the Northern Territory not been reported? In a report dated 21 August 1981, the Office of the Supervising Scientist-A Federal watchdog and research body-is concerned at the implications of an alleged failure to report on the matter.

If, as the Minister claims, the matters that affect the States, such as health matters, have been covered, why are the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, which is responsible for the Kakadu National Park, and the Northern Territory Land Council also critical of the company's monitoring program? Where is the code of mining concerned with the mining and milling of uranium that should have stipulated conditions that would not allow any spill to occur? But the health hazards do not end there. What of the report of radioactive material having leaked from a stockpile of uranium ore at a mine in Queensland? The Queensland water control council is concerned at radiation levels in a creek near Charters Towers. Radiation at Ben Lomond Australia Ltd's uranium mines in North Queensland was double the acceptable health level.

During the wet season in February 1980, tests undertaken by the water control council of the seepage from the ore stockpile showed radiation of 120 times the acceptable level. If honourable senators were to read some of the material available on the leaks and seepage from the Ben Lomond mine they would realise that no mining should take place in this area because of the danger to the people of Charters Towers and surrounding areas. The rural Press has played down the spill dispute, despite the fact that 60 cattle properties and 6,000 head of cattle line the water course. Next we will be able to export radioactive beef to America! Water is a very contentious issue since pumps feeding the town proper broke down in January, forcing locals to rely on rain water for their water tanks. If the pumps had not broken down, what might have been the result to the people of Charters Towers, the town near the mine?

The company engaged in this project at Ben Lomond is Minatome (Aust) Pty. Ltd-a company 100 per cent foreign owned. This company intends to spend some $60m in developing an open cut underground mine and treatment plant. Full scale production is due to begin in 1985. The company has to produce somewhere in the vicinity of 200,000 tonnes of ore per year. This would produce 400 tonnes of uranium per year. Three thousand five hundred tonnes have already been stockpiled in what one could consider a makeshift arrangement. Because of this stockpiling the trouble began. Late last January the normal heavy rains started to fall in the Ben Lomond area. This tropical downpour is normal for Northern Queensland each year. Following 20 days of such rain a leak developed in the sealed covers over the ore allowing a build-up of water in the stockpile, then an overflow from the tanks. As well as the overflow of radioactive water, cracks appeared in the concrete wall. Leakage seeped into the perimeter drains leaving dark brown stains and yellow stains on the concrete. Grass around the area is dying and has turned black.

The company's report stated that this water would probably contain dissolved radom-uranium and radium-which is one of the reasons why the grass is dying around the area covered by seepage. The fact that the company's own report contains this information is quite frightening. What steps are being taken by the Federal Government or the State Government to protect the water supply of such towns as Townsville and Charters Towers? Any overflow of material from the storage area into Keel Bottom Creek could mean in the new wet that occurs in this coming January-February that the whole Burdekin River could be contaminated as a result of mining the Ben Lomond site. This fear is more profound because it has been pointed out by Frank Stacey, Professor of Applied Physics at the Queensland University, in a statement under oath in the Mining Warden's Court of Charters Towers, that uranium mining would put at risk the safety of a dam proposed to be built in the Burdekin catchment area. Surely no government would be insane enough to allow the uranium mining or the extension of uranium mining in the Ben Lomond area without first making sure that no risk was attached to the proposed mining or any further development of underground mining and enrichment.
What of the miners working in the mine? In a further report to the Warden's Court, Charters Towers, it was stated:

Underground miners working a French-owned uranium deposit in North Queensland may have been exposed on occasions to levels of radio-active radon gas as much as 60 times the recommended level, according to documents lodged in a Queensland court.
The report further stated:

According to documents produced in the Charters Towers Mining Warden's Court, high levels of exposure may have occurred at intervals over a period of about 8 months from mid-1979 at the Ben Lomond mine.

I suppose compensation will be paid to the miners if they have some problem in relation to their work. Should these matters not be settled before consideration of further mining occurs or, for that matter, before any sale of uranium takes place? I believe the Government should look closely at the operation of the company here and elsewhere in Australia. One can only ask what action has been taken, or is proposed to be taken, under the code that Senator Carrick thinks has been 'substantially obtained' about the State's concern in relation to the mining and milling of uranium. I respectfully suggest that the Senate's Science and Environment Committee seek all relevant information so that it can be given to the Government, to the Parliament and, most importantly, to the Australian people. Surely the secret methods of this Federal Government must cease. It should allow for the complete list of all safeguards-whether for the development or the sale of uranium-to be made public. All environmental reports and impact studies should be made available to all electors to peruse. People can then assess the dangers to themselves, their children or to the town in which they live.

I now return to the Budget and refer to the demise of home ownership-the destruction of the dream of young marrieds of owning their own home. Political leaders should realise that the average Australian's expectations from increased prosperity are twofold. They are increased employment opportunities and increased opportunities for home ownership. This Government will be judged on its performance in achieving these expectations. Let us look at the overall reduction by this Government in regard to funds for housing. There has been a reduction in the Federal Budget's expenditure on housing from a total Budget outlay in 1974-75 of $1,413m, or 3.9 per cent of the total Budget outlay, to $399m in 1981-82, or one per cent of the total Budget outlay. This in itself shows that the Government has not provided money for housing in this country.

In the major cities the increase in the price of houses and land has been brought about by speculation in the market, rising interest rates and the unreal and unfair increase caused by the application of the new sales tax legislation which means that commodities that were taxed are now taxed at a higher rate and those commodities that were not taxed prior to the Budget are now to be taxed. This alone will increase the cost of houses for young couples by at least $500 to $600, to say nothing of the increases in land development costs for house blocks brought about by sales tax on road building materials. In spite of growing housing needs, the public housing stock has been eroded and the building industry has now begun to stagnate. The dream of every Australian family to own their own home is rapidly becoming a nightmare.

The Federal Government's policy of continuing interest rate hikes is turning Australia into a society of rent dwellers. I think time precludes me from going through the increases in rental rates that have occurred in the metropolitan area of Brisbane. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) should mitigate the crippling effects of this latest Budget by providing a full income tax rebate on housing loan interest for first home buyers. Cosmetic approaches to this fundamental problem are simply not good enough. A government that obliges businessmen with a 100 per cent tax rebate on borrowings to consolidate their business activities has a moral responsibility to guarantee similar security for the family-the unit that used to be regarded as the vital backbone of our society. Each time there is a rise in interest rates the Government reaps a bonanza from the interest declared on savings accounts and investments. This extra revenue could be used to offset the tax rebate to first home buyers and to generate a dramatic boost in the housing and construction and ancillary industries which employ about a quarter of the Australian work force.

The increase in interest rates over the last 18 months shows the cost burden carried by home purchasers. The overall effect will be to polarise Australia into a society of landlords and tenants. The Government is not only satisfied with causing this polarisation but also is creating a position where it is starting to push for a program of transportable homes to overcome a shortage of homes on a short term basis which, of course, it considers a long term basis. This means that the 'have nots' will finish up in cheap housing estates which will be erected on the outskirts of metropolitan areas where they will suffer from inadequate services and high transport costs.

Let us look at what has happened to one home buyer's dream. To understand the problems of high interest rates in our society and the problems facing young couples let me take the case of a young married couple who live in Brisbane. This couple is well known to me. The couple I will use to explain this position are Mr and Mrs Douglas Smith, who purchased a house in a close city suburb of Brisbane called Ashgrove. Mr and Mrs Smith signed a contract to buy their first home, the purchase price of which was $35,500. The Smiths were successful in receiving a loan for $30,835 over 25 years. The interest rate from the building society they borrowed from has risen from 11 per cent to 11.25 per cent, to 11.75 per cent to 12 per cent and by 1 April 1981, to 12.5 per cent. Next month it will rise to 13.5 per cent. But those facts are not the end of the story. The Government's policy of forcing up interest rates has left Mr and Mrs Smith with a house that originally cost $35,500 now costing, after 25 years, $93,500. With the extra one per cent rise in interest rates they will be left with the cost of their home moving to the astronomical sum of $101,100. I believe that Mr and Mrs Smith will not forget this Government for at least 25 years. I believe that unless the Government can reduce the burden of interest on first home buyers, Mr and Mrs Smith, and for that matter Mr and Mrs Australia, face an impossible task of paying for their $101,100 home.

Let me touch on another point, namely, the changes to the health policy brought about by the Government in Brisbane and throughout Australia on 1 September 1981. The changes in the health policy from 1 September have caused profound problems that this Government and, indeed, much of the community, do not yet fully realise. The ramifications of the Government's actions can be seen in the chaos at the Greenslopes Repatriation General Hospital in Brisbane. A decision has been made to introduce fees at this hospital from 1 December. The fee for inpatients was lifted to $125 a day. The fee for outpatient consultations was lifted to $15. If that is not enough, intensive care will cost anything up to $1,000 a day. The infirm at Greenslopes were notified of their sudden financial liability in a letter from the Department of Veterans' Affairs dated 21 August 1981-ten days before the new charges took effect. They had only 10 days in which to make arrangements to pay up or get out. Ten days were given these mostly elderly people, who are ill and confined to a hospital bed, to find $125 a day. For the desperately ill in intensive care 10 days were given to find $1,000 a day. This is an awe-inspiring display of compassion by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner). People have deluged the medical staff with requests for clarification of the new measures. The medical staff have offered no help. They have not been notified by this Government. Doctors asked the Chief Medical Officer whether he would please notify the medical staff what the changes meant. He replied: 'What can I tell you when I don't even know.' Every day he received different directives from Canberra. The medical staff were not able to give one iota of information about the changes-nothing.

Doctors and staff at this hospital are justifiably proud of the high standards of health care that have resulted from professional dedication and the interaction of specialist medical personnel, entitled veterans and non-entitled patients from the general community, who form the bulk of patients attending the excellent specialised units, particularly that concerned with hypertension, and a number of others that I could name.

Whilst pensioners, disadvantaged people and entitled veterans can still obtain free treatement, the loss of a substantial number of non-entitled patients will reduce the clinical mix of patients and restrict the wide variety of clinical material available at this hospital. The specialist units will no longer be highly regarded and specialist staff will be attracted to other hospitals where their skills can be more fully utilised. An inevitable consequence of reducing the number of community patients will be the loss of accredited registrar teaching posts. If a patient were admitted with a complaint covered by a veterans' entitlement, he would receive free treatment. But if the same patient developed complications, such as cardiac arrest, and was unable to meet the new charges, he would have to be carted around in an ambulance until some hospital that would take him for free treatment, or somewhere where he could at least find the money to pay, could be found. It is yet another example of this Government's myopic approach to economic decisions without any regard for the consequences, only this time it is placing human lives in jeopardy-lives that were once offered in defence of the principles of this very Parliament, principles that this Government so wantonly lacks.

It is improper for the Government to give an undertaking to provide a community service-to enter into a social contract to provide a patient with free treatment-and to renege halfway through that treatment without warning. It is inhumane to permit a patient who has been anaesthetised under the impression that he is undergoing free treatment, to awaken from his operation and be presented with a bill for $125 a day for as long as it takes him to recover. No doubt this Government gives a whole new meaning to the term 'post-operative shock'. Hypertension from a kidney abnormality is not an uncommon complaint. In the last 12 months, Greenslopes has developed a technique to relieve such hypertension by opening up renal arteries without operating. The doctors introduce a catheter, attached to a balloon, into the artery. The balloon is inflated, expanding the artery to improve the flow of blood to the kidneys. All of the local free hospitals refer patients to Greenslopes for this particular treatment, which cannot be performed anywhere else in Brisbane. The endocrine clinic at the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital also is the only one of its type in Brisbane and took years to develop. Other hospitals will now have to develop this expertise and that will not be easy.

Earlier this year rumours about the possible changes gathered momentum at the hospital as staff began to see the writing on the wall. Seven full-time specialists have resigned already this year and at least an additional six senior doctors have accepted appointments at other hospitals as a direct result of this Government's attitude to the health care needs of veterans in Queensland. The mass exodus of medical staff is due to a deep ethical concern that the high standards they have established at Greenslopes can only deteriorate after these severe cutbacks begin to take effect. The medical staff feels that it has been betrayed, that while it has been led to expect a modern, progressive and respected hospital, the effects of imposing fees there-alone of any hospital in Queensland-will act to the detriment of the hospital, of entitled veterans, of other patients and of the medical and nursing staff.

The Deputy Commissioner, Mr Gray, has assured that staff that he supports everything it has said about the crisis at the hospital. The Minister must acknowledge that the position in Queensland, which has an established free hospital system, is different from that in other States. As the responsible Minister, it is his moral duty to protect the interests of veterans in this country. If he is not prepared to exercise that duty, in all conscience he must impose a moratorium on fee introduction at this hospital until the full consequences of the decision can be more closely examined and patients allowed adequate time to prepare for any financial changes. If he will not, if he considers the opinions of his Deputy Commissioner regarding the problems at this hospital to be irrelevant, he must institute an inquiry into the effects of the introduction of those fees.
