TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the dinner break I spoke on a number of points in relation to the Budget. One other point I will deal with is that of lone parents, yet another area of family neglect in this Budget. The lone parent family is chronically ignored by this Government. The Australian Bureau of Statistics released figures in May 1975 which indicated that at that time there were 164,800 single parent families living in cities and towns, or 9 per cent of all urban families in Australia. In 1979 the number of lone parent families rose to 272,000 or 12.8 per cent of all urban families. These are the latest figures available to date. If that rate of increase were sustained, there must now be more than 300,000 lone parents in Australia struggling to support their families.

SPEECH.PARA: This growing number of people is displaying extraordinary courage in the face of severe emotional and financial stress. Most of them are desperately trying to hold on to their jobs and care for their children at the same time. The added pressure associated with raising a family forces many of these people into part time employment. The decrease in the availability of part time employment has had a marked effect on single parent families forcing many of them on to social security pensions and placing them at a far greater risk in terms of poverty. I will quote from the ministerial statement of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) presented after the Budget. He unashamedly declared:
The Government is committed to enhancing the position of all families. Australian families bringing up children are perhaps the greatest beneficiaries of sound, responsible economic management.
That is splendid. Further on in the statement we also learn:
. . . the Government has been very mindful of the difficulties facing single income families.

A little further down the page, however, we discover just how mindful this Government really is with the sublime announcement that the income tax rebate for sole parent families would be increased by a whopping $21 a year. Mr Deputy President, $21 a year is about 40c a week; that is assuming these people have incomes. Those lone parents with three or more children will get some relief through family allowance adjustments. If we disregard the increase in the income tax rebate-it is not difficult to disregard this increase-these lone parents with some employment and one or two children will get nothing from this Budget.

A significant number of the 300,000 lone parent families exist below the poverty line and include some whose incomes are slightly too high to qualify for public housing. Like so many others, these people will never realise the Australian fantasy of home ownership but will be committed to rental roulette for the rest of their lives. So much for this Budget's enhancing the position of all families. The reality of the increased hardships these people must face betrays the blatant hypocrisy in the Minister's attempt to defend this brutal Budget.

The abolition of the Community Youth Support Scheme is yet another indication of the Government's disregard for the misery it is creating in its enthusiasm to adopt the recommendations of the razor gang. It is disgraceful to think that a government guilty of nurturing the conditions that have forced so many kids on to the streets now plans to remove the last avenue of hope that thousands of teenagers have of finding a meaningful place in our society-'our society', not theirs. This is a society that constantly surrounds these people yet remains at a distance, often quite beyond their grasp. What is the point in struggling towards single digit inflation, a Budget surplus, a neat balance of payments and other nebulous economic goals if the quality and very meaning of life itself vanishes in the process? It is vital to reassure the young generation, and for that matter other generations, that governments care about our future society. For these kids, that future society will be theirs.

There is no valid reason to fear a book entry expansion in a Budget deficit if the money released is used to underwrite the community's confidence in its own worth. However, today there is a diminishing confidence in the direction this country is taking under the throttle of the Fraser Government. Nowhere is that confidence more eroded than in the legion of unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. Before calling on Senator Crichton-Browne of Western Australia to speak, I inform the Senate that this is the honourable senator's maiden speech in this chamber. In the circumstances I ask honourable senators to accord Senator Crichton-Browne the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I join with other honourable senators in congratulating you on your election to the office of Deputy President of the Senate. If I may presume to say so, I am sure you will fulfil your duties with impartiality, competence and dignity.

SPEECH.PARA: As I deliver my maiden speech, I am mindful of the fact that Western Australia was the only State in Australia to return three Liberal senators at the last election. While I gather Senator Chipp might be inclined to take a different view, I believe the result was very much a reflection of the Western Australian voters' attitude towards the federal system of government and the continuing belief in State rights and the preservation of State governments. I venture to suggest that such a proposal put by way of a referendum to abolish States and their parliaments would be ignominiously defeated by the people of Western Australia.

We are, I believe, fortunate to have a federal system of government and I do not agree with those who think that the forming of the Commonwealth out of six colonial governments was an unfortunate concession to the political reality of parochial loyalties and a crippling disadvantage to the unity of the nation. On the contrary, I think that the Federation has been a great advantage to Australia and a circumstance that lends itself to better government. The importance of State governments is too often underestimated and even deliberately maligned. I am well satisfied that the majority of Australians and certainly the great majority of Western Australians, are opposed to the centralising of power in Canberra. The express condition upon which Western Australia entered the Federation was on the basis of equal representation in the States' House-and this vote was only carried due to an overwhelming vote by eastern States goldminers prospecting in the Kalgoorlie goldfields.

Had there been no States' House with equal representation and with its present powers built into the Constitution to protect the less populous States like Western Australia and Tasmania, there would have been no Federation as we know it at that time. In fact, notwithstanding, Western Australia felt so dissatisfied with the central decision-making of the Federal government in the 1930s that it voted to secede. Because I do believe in Federation, because I do believe in the federal system, because I have been elected to the States' House and because I have the honour to represent Western Australia, I believe it is proper that I talk about what is special to Western Australia and what Western Australia has to offer the Federation of Australia. One cannot help but note that over the years those in this chamber who have spoken most forcefully on behalf of the States they represent have invariably come from the States with small populations and modest numerical representation in the House of Representatives. New South Wales and Victoria combined have the capacity in the House of Representatives to out-vote the combined members of every other State.

I am sure there is a temptation for members in this chamber to see the Senate as a States' House in direct inverse proportion to the number of members their States have in the House of Representatives-at least on this side of the chamber. When we consider that Western Australia has 12 members in the House of Representatives out of a total of 125 members, honourable senators can see why Liberal senators from Western Australia take a special interest in matters before the chamber which affect our State. There is of course no basic incompatability between support for the principles of a party which is committed to federalism and a determination to defend the best interests of your State, when those interests are clearly threatened.

Turning to the great State I have been elected to represent, I will just reflect upon that which has been achieved. Western Australia has come from the Cinderella State of Australia in the 1950s to a model of growth for the future. Geographically, it covers one-third of the Australian continent. Its land surface extends over 2.5 million square kilometres, making it as big as India and four times the size of Texas. Beyond our 12,500 kilometres of coastline, Western Australia reaches out to the new international off-shore limit, embracing a further 2.5 million square kilometres of economic territory. Although we have only 8.7 per cent of the nation's population, we earn 20 per cent of Australia's export income and, by 1990, we expect to have 10 per cent of Australia's population and to earn 40 per cent of the nation's export income. By the end of the decade, we will have overtaken the population of South Australia, the first time one mainland State's population has overtaken the population of another state since Federation.

Resource development over the past 20 years has expanded our work force by 300,000 people and, with their families, the number of people affected rises to 600,000. This type of development and growth in Western Australia over the past 20 years has put Western Australia in a position in which it provides: one tonne in eight of world alumina, one tonne in ten of world iron ore, one tonne in twelve of world nickel, one tonne in five of world mineral sands, one bushel in three of Australia's wheat, and one bale in four of Australia's wool. As I said earlier, our exports contribute $1 in $4 of Australia's overseas earnings. The economic performance shows up in indicators such as housing. With one in 12 of the State populations, we build more than one in eight of the nation's homes. In education, we have one in eight of the entire population undergoing post-secondary study. During the last year, Australia's employment grew by 2.6 per cent while Western Australia's grew by 4.5 per cent.

Regrettably, there are those on the eastern side of Australia who do not seem to understand the benefits that flow to them. It should be understood that, of the 600,000 people I have just referred to, 200,000 are on the eastern side of Australia. In fact, one can extend that figure further. Taking into consideration what Western Australia as a whole purchases from the eastern States, over 500,000 people in the eastern States are employed directly due to Western Australia's purchasing power. By 1990, if our growth continues according to plan, this number will reach nearly 800,000. Or, to translate that statistic into another figure, Western Australia bought $2,300m worth of goods from the eastern States last year.

It goes without saying that the principal beneficiary of this wealth and growth is the Federal Government which in turn redistributes it throughout the Australian community. Of every $5 of taxes raised through the resource sector in the west, $1 remains in Western Australia and $4 of the $5 goes directly to Canberra. If one is to look at nationwide figures, it will be seen that the States retain 15.6 per cent of total industry taxes and the Federal Government receives 79.1 per cent. Taking a constant group of companies within a survey for the Australian Mining Industry Council, we find that sales revenue increased by 31 per cent over the previous year but income tax payable to the Commonwealth rose by 73 per cent compared with the previous year. If the question of what benefit this development has for all Australians is asked, I suggest that it is self-evident.

The growth that has taken place in Western Australia is not the result of good luck, chance, or manifest destiny. It is a growth geared to the development of resources. Over the last two decades, this has occurred only because leaders of industry and finance have had the courage and foresight to make courageous and long term decisions and because the elected leaders have sought to attract this investment. Whilst the growth of Western Australia and its contribution to Australia over the past two decades have been impressive, the future growth will overshadow all past investments. Within the next six years, some $13 billion worth of resource projects will take place in Western Australia and by the end of the 1980s, notwithstanding what I have heard in recent days, that will rise to somewhere between $30 billion and $40 billion. This expanded development will create for us a further 150,000 jobs. However, all this development may well be at risk if the fragility of the resource sector is not clearly understood.

If insensitive economic decisions are made without a clear understanding of the implications to the resource industry, much of Australia's future prosperity could be lost. Whilst a tight monetary policy may be desirable as an instrument to hold down inflation and as an incentive to place some restraint upon wage demands, it will, of course, have the effect of holding interest rates at a dangerously high level and place considerable restrictions upon the ability of the private sector and the public sector to provide services and infrastructure vital to the viability of many projects. Until the Government is prepared to grapple with the problem of two competing economies in this country, I do not believe we can look forward to Australia receiving the full benefits from the potential that our mineral wealth offers us.

Much has been spoken of the damaging effects that the large capital inflow into this country will have upon our economy. It has been argued that unlimited infrastructure borrowings from overseas or raised domestically have the effect of crowding out and will lead to an increase in interest rates. As long as we have a tight monetary policy and a highly protected secondary industry, that is a fair proposition. It can also be properly claimed that, in itself, a high monetary inflow associated with the investment stage of the boom is likely to be followed by high monetary inflows associated with exports of the production from the boom sector. As a result there will be upward pressures on the value of the Australian dollar. There are, of course, mitigating arguments against these propositions but, in broad principle, they are a fair statement of the position.

I think it is an elementary proposition that there are two obvious solutions to overcome the inherent difficulties that large capital inflows into this country cause. The first is to ensure that there is a compensating outflow of capital and the second is to provide a sufficient capacity within Australia to provide a greater share of available funds for these projects. The first case calls for lower tariffs and the second requires that there be less competition for funds from governments seeking money for non-productive purposes. If one wonders about the cost of tariffs in Victoria alone Australian taxpayers provide $2 billion a year to protect inefficient industries-$139m more than the Western Australian Government's total Consolidated Revenue Fund this year. Protection loads the costs in Australia by $1 in every $20 in the economy. Yet we often lavish more concern on these takers than we do on the givers.

Take the case of the motor industry which is currently spending a huge amount of money telling Australia that it has a right to contribute more minuses to the economy. Last year, even though real economic recovery is far from here, employment grew by 140,000 jobs-140,000 in one year-which is more than all the jobs associated with the motor industry put together. I have heard it said that, if we put all the motor workers on a pension, closed their factories, and imported all our cars, we would make a handsome profit as a nation. Now, of course, I am not against an Australian motor industry. I am in favour of an Australian motor industry-provided it goes about its business with the idea of producing a plus, not a minus. And the same goes for a great many more that are in the same boat. If it is good enough for the motor industries of the major countries to start working together on an international basis in order to be more competitive in competing for the consumer dollar, it makes sense for the Australian motor industry to get with it and stop living in the past.

We hear a lot of rhetoric about consumer protection but we do not see much practised in the big protected sector of Australian industry. The fact that there are many successful and competitive Australian industries-industries which are building up Australian export earnings-demonstrates that we can succeed without protecton if we move our industrial efforts in the right direction. Regrettably the burden of protection does not fall only on the consumer. It falls heavily on the competitive producer and especially on the cost structure of that producer. Of course again I speak of the farmers and miners who earn three-quarters of our export income in competition with the world. These are the people who prime the pump of the economy. These are the people whose plus contribution and whose multiplier impact spreads real benefits through the community. Yet we hear the clamour for more taxes-special taxes and punitive taxes-against the successful. And we hear the same wisdom urging massive support for the failures who already receive $1 out of every $20 note circulating in Australia. It is part of the cult of punishing success that we have a duty to reward failure. Yet the punishment of success surely reduces the rewards for everyone-including the failures.

Turning again for a moment to the problem facing us of skilled and semi-skilled labour which is vital to the commencement of these major resource projects, I point out that, if there is not a movement out of the inefficient sector of industry into the competitive sector, no tight monetary policy will begin to succeed to dampen down wage demands. I have no doubt there is going to be a blow-out of wages in certain sectors and it is inevitable that there will be flow-ons throughout the rest of the work force. This, of course, will certainly lead to rising inflation and company failures in the sectors that cannot match the wage rises. It is quite clear that economic manipulation will not control wage inflation especially as income tax is already expected to rise by 22 per cent due to the very inflation we are supposed to be controlling.

The other major factor retarding development in this country is the demand that is made on available money by the Federal Government to fund programs in no way related to stimulating the economy or the nation's prosperity. In fact, quite the reverse! This Government has to make up its mind whether it believes in big government or small government. Words do not take the place of deeds. There seems to be an absolute faith that if you have said it you have done it. One example this year was the razor gang. Its long labours led to a list of cuts representing about one-eightieth of the Budget. But the increase in Budget outlays was eight times the size of the alleged cuts. Worse still, whilst the Federal spending was expanding, just about the whole of the razor gang cuts involved money to be taken from the States. In fact Federal taxation, which took 24 per cent of the economy before Whitlam and 25 per cent after Whitlam, took 28 per cent after the latest Budget. As a consequence, total public sector spending, as distinct from taxation, which soared from 32 per cent to 38.2 per cent of the economy under the Whitlam influence and fell back a little after the change of government, is now back to 38.1 per cent, mainly due to central government spending programs. During the past six years, in real terms, State expenditures have fallen slightly-about 1.2 per cent-and Federal outlays have expanded enormously.

The answer to the problem in simple terms is to give priority to encouraging people to create new sectors of the economy-the people who take risks by having a go-and not to give priority to people who simply consume, who do not take risks but simply take money. In the past, the great difference between the dead economies of socialism and the live economies of capitalism and enterprise was the risk taking difference. If we go on having too little regard for those who take risks and want to bleed them to death the moment they succeed while having absolutely no pity for them if they fail, we will destroy the difference. It has been truly said that the entrepreneur, in taking risks, gives without being sure of getting and the socialist takes without being sure of giving, often not caring whether he gives. To put it bluntly, I see evidence of Liberals in government worshipping the graven images of socialist idolatry, expressing a sordid belief that sterile gods can work real miracles to save an indolent people from the horrors of working for a living.

Much has been spoken about the resource boom, mirage or fact. In truth, if the private sector is not given encouragement and incentive it will quickly evaporate into a mirage. Given the right economic environment, it will flourish. Let us not for a moment believe that development is inevitable. Of every 1,000 possible projects, 100 are studied, 10 are drilled and only one becomes a project, at an average proving cost of more that $30m and rising.

Mineral earnings bear a 60 per cent tax burden and, after the last Budget, mining companies have been devastated by new depreciation provisions. Anyone who has any practical knowledge of running a business knows that the depreciation write-off has been grossly unjust for years. A company buys something for $1m and is allowed to write-off $1m. It might cost $3m to replace it, so it has been done out of $2m of depreciation write-off to replace its asset. Worse than that, it has been taxed on money that was not a real earning at all, but was needed in effect to repair the asset financially by replacing it.

This situation has never been equitable but it became inequitable almost to the point of destruction when Whitlam inflation struck the economy and thousands of enterprises went to the wall, along with a quarter of a million jobs. I saw one assessment done by a Melbourne share broking house during this period which demonstrated that at that time corporate Australia could well have been taxed at the rate of 120 per cent of what would eventually have been seen to be its true earnings after real depreciation multiplied by inflation. In the Budget just brought down the write-off period in the mining industry has been doubled from five to 10 years. This slashes the benefit of the write-off by one-third on a discounted cash flow basis. It now literally means that two-thirds of the investment cannot be written off in real terms, and the cost of financially repairing it by replacing it will be treated as income and taxed accordingly.

Perhaps one of the greatest threats to the immediate expansion of the resource sector is the restriction placed upon States in the borrowing for essential investment in infrastructure. This is having a domino effect right around Australia. Let me give just one example. One of the major benefits this country has over its competitors is its potential to generate relatively cheap power. The Victorian Government had intended its overseas borrowings to provide generating capacity to the Portland aluminium smelter. However, its borrowings have been significantly reduced and it has had to increase its power charges to get money from revenue for its investment program. Suddenly these charges for Portland power increased by what the Victorian Government said was 25 per cent, what Alcoa said was 33 per cent but what, when the sums were done, in fact turned out to be 40 per cent. As a result, the Portland project is back in the melting pot.

Half of the output of the Wagerup alumina refinery being built in Western Australia is dedicated to Portland. Any delay or deferment of Portland means a delay or deferment that could affect half the capacity of this new alumina refinery. But that is not the end of the potential domino effect. Wagerup is planned as a user of North West Shelf gas and its demand helped to reinforce the Western Australian State Energy Commission in making a base commitment to one-fifth of the Shelf's gas to help to get the project on its way in a very difficult earlier stage. The net result could be that the Western Australian Government could be put in a position of having to pay for gas which it is unable to sell, to say nothing of the enormous cost of the Dampier to Perth pipeline. Portland is not the only smelter to be affected in such a way. So far, four smelters have been deferred or shelved.

The ironic part of it is that there was once a fairly common agreement that Australia wanted to be something better than a quarry for the world and to get the benefit of processing and making metals of its minerals. The great tragedy for Australia is that successive governments have given the Australian people to believe that we have a divine right to wealth and prosperity; that notwithstanding the frailty of human nature there will always be an abundance of everything and affluence is a birthright. Governments have taught the modern generation to believe that government action will cure all ills and government intervention and support are the panacea to all problems. The debilitating effect has been to create the level of expectation far above that which governments can provide. The net result, given that we have three-year parliaments, is governments lurching from one poor economic decision to another in the vain hope of filling the voters' unobtainable expectations.

Long term economic strategy has been the casualty and the real losers are the Australian people. One of the strong arguments for extending the term of the Parliament is to provide governments with the opportunity to take tough decisions and to stick with them. This country has a unique opportunity now in the world community to grow and prosper in a way rarely available. Let us have courage and grasp it before it passes us by and competing countries take part of our future as part of theirs. I thank the Senate for its indulgence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before calling on Senator Giles of Western Australia to speak, I inform the Senate that this will be the honourable senator's first speech in this chamber. In the circumstances, I ask honourable senators to accord her the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy President. May I add my formal congratulations on your election. I cannot attempt to match the lacerating wit and debating skills of my predecessor from Western Australia, Senator Wheeldon. My strengths and my modus operandi are different from his, but I take reassurance from the fact that difference does not necessarily denote inferiority. That is for the electorate to judge. I am deeply conscious of my privilege and my obligation to represent the people of Western Australia to the utmost of my ability. I pay tribute to the Australian Labor Party for its enlightened approach to equality within its ranks and to better representation of its female membership in parliamentary terms. My grateful thanks go too to my friends and colleagues in the trade union movement for their guidance and encouragement. I am especially proud that the Australian Council of Trade Unions adopted last week the humane, progressive and widely accepted position on abortion proposed by its women's committee, proving conclusively that, even though the ACTU is and will be for some time a thoroughly male dominated institution, it can listen and respond to what women workers are saying.

SPEECH.PARA: In travelling the many kilometres from one side of this continent to the other I have frequently considered the effects upon Australians generally of isolation in its many forms. The scattering of a relatively small population over a very large territory obviously entails heavy costs in transport and communications and less quantifiable costs in insularity, often expressed as State rivalry and acrimony, verging lately on open warfare as Fraser federalism forces State governments into policies for which someone must be blamed. Another effect of isolation of which I have become acutely aware over the past seven years as a trade union official is the low level of expectation of the majority of Australian workers, who have no knowledge of labour standards which are considered a matter of course in most comparable industrialised societies. For example, in Australia managerial prerogative is alive and well and in many instances is still trying to impose nineteenth century solutions on twentieth century problems. Those ancient philosophies are aided and abetted by a no less anachronistic Federal Government and some State governments, especially those which can only be perpetuated by gerrymandered electorates.

Despite international conventions which have been in force for decades, we in the trade union movement have been forced to mount full scale cases in which to achieve relatively minor entitlements, such as unpaid maternity leave for privately employed workers. The principle involved is that no worker should be sacked simply because of a protracted inability to work, a principle adopted by the House of Lords a century ago. This is enshrined in the labour laws of most European countries, but the notion still shocks Australians-workers and bosses alike. Job security is a myth for the majority of Australian workers employed on a weekly contract regardless of perhaps decades of loyal service.

There is no such thing as a permanent job, according to a spokesman for the Australian Confederation of Industry speaking at a conference on sharing out the work at the Australian National University in July 1979. There is no such thing as a decent length of contract either for most Australian workers, unlike their European counterparts. Equal remuneration for workers of equal value has, one could justifiably assume, become a fact of industrial life, but the isolationists of the Western Australian Industrial Commission have vigorously avoided such equity by persisting with a token margin of $3.60 in order to establish a Western Australian male minimum wage, which is just slightly in excess of the State female and the national adult minimum wage, thus rating for Western Australia a special, unflattering footnote in the publications of the International Labour Organisation.

Workers everywhere should have been heartened by the achievements of the super-isolated workers previously employed by the late unlamented British Phosphate Commission on Christmas Island in the Indian Ocean. Having struggled against amazing odds to establish a union, the workers were pitted against the most entrenched colonial-style exploitative employers that it is possible to imagine. 'Repugnant' and 'outmoded' were amongst the criticisms of Commissioner Sweetland, who was appointed to investigate the phosphate industry upon which the island is utterly dependent. Totally united and intelligently led, the workers have learned to use their industrial strength and have also become aware of the force of international opinion in their altogether justifiable fight for parity with Australian wages and working conditions. Their living conditions are not so easily raised to comparable mainland mining town standard, but the struggle continues. The women who work on the island-like all the other wages workers they are Chinese or Malay-might have been expected to await passively their turn but, recognising their own worth, they have declined to be set aside and have insisted that their claims have equal priority. I admire them. I admire their courage, and tenacity, and I value their friendship. It is not necessary to maroon people on a tropical island in order to isolate them. This and previous Fraser Government Budgets have clearly shown this to be true.

The young seeking employment, households on low incomes, the chronically unwell, those on pensions, single parents, the handicapped and the homeless are progressively being more effectively shelved, their real choices minimised and their existence made precarious, too many of them are just one week's wage or one welfare cheque off destitution. I am eagerly awaiting the results of a current study by the Institute of Family Studies in which preliminary data indicates very tight family budgets, high use of hire purchase and personal loans and the impact of rising home interest rates. The study will give, according to the recent annual report of the Institute, a clearer picture of the economic circumstances of families as they vary across the life cycle and as they are affected by the economic climate. I believe there are some nasty shock awaiting those who believe that most Australians are comfortably situated.

There is no doubt in my mind that the isolation about which I am speaking-this deprivation of a sense of community-is a heartless and deliberate ploy by a Government determined to maintain privilege and wealth in the hands of a few at the expense of the masses. Why else would the relatively inexpensive Community Youth Support Scheme have been axed, except that it was providing a focus for otherwise aimless and directionless young people? Let me read a letter from a young Western Australian. I dearly wish that it could be reproduced in facsimile so that it would be obvious to all that writing this letter was a prodigious effort. He said:

I came to our local CYSS four years ago with my friends. I was an irresponsible, law-breaking youth. The group decided CYSS was somewhere we could go without too much hassle. It was the only link between us and government departments like Social Security.

I continued my involvement with CYSS for three years. The faith and support of the project officers, when other government departments gave up on me, helped me gradually change my antisocial behaviour. They supported me when I went to court, and made me more aware of myself. I started learning to read and write again after eight years of school failed to teach me how to do either. CYSS project officers were the only government workers I could communicate with.

CYSS never changed me to fit society, but helped me to survive in society. They found me a job which I have had for over a year now. I am hoping to start my own business, which I could never have dreamed of doing 12 months ago.
There is no government department that can achieve what CYSS has done for me and others like me. There is real need in the community for CYSS. Can anything else replace it?
A young woman from the same suburb writes graphically of her feelings. She states:

With CYSS you have always got somewhere to go, and you are not stuck in your flat climbing the walls. CYSS is also a place that you don't have to go . . . You go because you want to go. When you are hungry cold and are short of money you can come to CYSS and sit near the fire and keep warm and the money you get for bus fares you can buy food with. The closing down of such schemes is to me and other people one of the biggest mistakes that the present Government has made. Subsequently, it seems to me that the present Government does not care about unemployed people.

These are the people who, with Aborigines and migrants, are so easily disenfranchised and on whose behalf the Australian Labor Party sought to have a single electoral roll introduced in Western Australia. The resentment of these people is running high. The Government must be banking on all the fight being knocked out of them before the next Federal election. The Federal Government seems to be shrugging off its responsibilities at every possible opportunity, despite the fact that, like the Community Youth Support Scheme, it costs very little to provide shelter and support for those in need. Some of my colleagues seemed to be stunned recently when the cost of reasonably satisfactory accommodation, care and counselling for homeless young people was estimated at about $100 a head a week. The social cost of not providing for such needs, when they are required, is of course immeasurably greater. Some indication can be gained from the fact that institutional care in prison or hospital will certainly cost more than $100 a day, not to mention the human misery, degradation and alienation which so often accompanies the deprivation which we now see developing. The following are the words of a worker in the field:

The young people catered for are a very mixed lot. Their mutual meeting ground, both physically and psychologically is the CYSS house, a retreat, a starting point, or just a place for relaxation. Since the Budget announcement, I have watched these young people withdraw into tight little balls of despair. 'Where do we go now' is the overwhelming question. With backgrounds or broken homes, overbearing parents, familial alcoholism, or single rooms, just where will they go? Even the brightest of young people using CYSS appear to have experienced some form of familial or social distress. Will they now be discarded until they reach the point of emotional disablement requiring the services of yet another, more expensive government agency?

Women as workers and as recipients of welfare are particularly vulnerable in this present type of economic climate to exploitation on the one hand and to the lack of support for themselves and their families on the other. Women from low income households have always had to earn extra money to keep their families out of poverty. The significant change over the last decade or two has been the institutionalisation and commerciatisation of much of women's traditional work, along with the expansion of those industries which have customarily employed women. Despite the best efforts of the trade union movement it is still very easy to exploit women through blackmail-no milder term will suffice-as is happening in an ever-expanding range of caring occupations providing essential services. Family planning, family day care, child care, youth hostels, women's refuges, sexual assault counselling, Aboriginal and women's health services and domiciliary care are more and more dependent upon workers who are forced into accepting less than award wages, working overtime under stress without extra pay, and even in some cases donating back part of their wages in order to keep the facilities functioning. Of course we believe that communities should be involved in identifying their own needs and in providing solutions to those needs. But the day to day organisation of services such as those to which I have referred must be undertaken by appropriately qualified people working under proper industrial conditions. Exploitation based on the vulnerability of the client is insupportable and probably illegal in many cases and, in the sense that it is being condoned by both State and Federal governments, scandalous.

Health and education policies have grave implications for women. Nurses and other hospital workers all over the nation are working short-handed and under pressure, desperately trying to maintain high standards of care and cleanliness. Women teachers are insecure and are under much the same stress. The Victorian Council of Academic Staff Associations predicts a loss of 9,000 teacher training places for female school leavers in 1984, and the same picture is mirrored across the nation.

Children's services as a source of employment and as a source of family support have failed to expand to fill the needs of working parents and of house-bound mothers, adding to the vicitims of the Budget. As health and welfare services become less accessible it is wives, mothers, sisters and daughters who may have no choice but to give up their careers to subsidise society with their unpaid care of the aged and the handicapped at home, a sacrifice rarely required of husbands, fathers, brothers or sons. To add an even greater imposition upon families already struggling, legitimate industrial action, taken in the vast majority of cases in order to maintain minimum living standards, is to be punished by depriving the wives of striking workers of eligibility for unemployment benefits. The same deprivation will apply to the wives of those unemployed workers who fall foul of arbitrarily applied work tests. What a way to solve industrial and social problems, to declare guilt by association, without trial, and to impose a penalty of starvation.

Another effect, and cause too, of isolation, is the guilt imposed on so many people, especially women, by circumstances which are largely beyond their capacity to control. Blaming the victim is not a new way of avoiding social responsibility, but we have seen it employed with sickening regularity during the last few years. Honourable senators opposite who evince obsession with well-being from the moment of conception would be far more convincing if they aligned themselves with policies such as those of the Labor Party. We seek a society in which no woman who wishes to bear a child is prevented from doing so, or is forced into having a pregnancy terminated because of social or economic circumstances such as those pertaining to very many Australians now in what would previously have been considered their reproductive years.

I believe that the cumulative effect of the Fraser Government's economic policies is proving the greatest and most effective contraceptive of all times. How can a woman responsibly become pregnant or responsibly allow an unplanned pregnancy to proceed to term when the household income, depleted by unexpectedly high mortgage repayments, savage State charges, arbitrary health insurance, escalating income taxation and the crippling costs of keeping a vehicle on the road, is barely or less than adequate to clothe and feed the existing members of that household, and unemployment is a grim and continuing possibility. Moralising and punitive legislation are not the answers to such problems. We can try, but we cannot force women to have babies, short of unspeakable duress. Moreover, unwanted pregnancy is not a matter of class nor a respecter of persons, as some have recently argued. Why do not such people who adopt such a moralising stance throw their weight behind those who work, as we do, for more equitable distribution of this wealthy country's resources, decent and affordable housing, universal education and health care, humane and accessible social security and a nuclear free future?

Finally, I wish to refer to an alarming discovery which I have recently made. Seeking to better inform myself as preparation for this, my fifth career, I spent some time in studying a slim volume entitled Liberal Thinking jointly authored by C. J. Puplick and R. J. Southey, published by the Macmillan Co. of Australia, and dated 1980. I was particularly concerned to try to comprehend just what approach was currently being taken by the Liberal Party to the subject of human rights, as I had been aware over the years of considerable confusion among their ranks about whether any such animal even existed. Indeed, in Western Australia, we have been continually confronted by a philosophy, if I can exalt it to such status, that rights of association, for example, are but figments of our fevered imaginations. I was not enormously surprised, in studying this slender publication to which I have referred, to discover inconsistencies and contradictions. I will not be so impolite as to expose them on this occasion. I was amazed, however, to discover at the end of a tortuous argument the conclusion:
That the only right which exists in the Liberal philosophy without qualification is to be treated like a man.

Which man, may I ask? Do we have a choice? Is it the man who can make quick millions, tax free, on the stock market, or is it the man who is black, homeless, hounded and jobless, without even a vote? I have a distinct impression that I am not the only Australian woman who eagerly awaits answers to these questions. Perhaps all will be revealed as my term in the Senate proceeds. Perhaps the isolation about which I have been speaking will be resolved only when all politicians and all political parties are speaking, writing, and genuinely working not for man but for humanity. I thank the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX AMENDMENT BILLS (Nos 1-9) 1981SALES TAX AMENDMENT BILLS (Nos 1A-9A) 1981SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 September, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move the following amendment to the second reading of these 19 Bills:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of motion add', but the Senate considers that the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) 1981 should be amended so as to exempt from the new 2 1/2 per cent tax:
(i) books, newspapers and other information publications;
(ii) building materials for the construction of private dwellings;
(iii) goods which effect the cost of food; and
(iv) clothing and footwear.'.

In moving the amendment, I reiterate that the position of the Australian Democrats on this series of sales tax Bills remains clear. We do not support the effort of the Australian Labor Party to throw out the total package of sales tax legislation which we see as a blocking manoeuvre, if not the same at least similar and of the same ilk as those things which happened in 1974 and 1975 which caused double dissolutions of this Parliament. We do not support the Australian Labor Party in trying to prevent increases in the sales tax on luxuries. We believe that a person who can afford gold plated cutlery, diamond jewellery, fur coats and a new yacht can also afford to pay sales tax on those things. We would rather money came from those taxes on luxuries than from tax paid by Australian families. We are amazed at the simplistic view the Australian Labor Party takes of this situation. I think all sensible people know that money which government does not get one way, it gets in another. I would have thought that my colleagues on this side of the chamber in the Australian Labor Party would know that well enough. I am sure very few Australians are so naive that they do not know that.

Our policy, adopted by secret written ballot of all Australian Democrat members throughout Australia, makes it plain that we support a general move away from indirect tax. That is a policy I commend to the members of the Australian Labor Party. They have often enough said that income tax in this country is too high. So it is. It is better that there be a move away from income tax to indirect taxation. I would have thought that even Senator Evans might appreciate the point that income tax is a compulsory tax in the sense that everybody pays it on their incomes whether they wish to or not. However, sales tax is not a compulsory tax; it is a matter of choice. It is a matter of what a person wants to spend. If Senator Evans wants to buy a fur coat, he is perfectly entitled to do so. I only hope he does not wear it in here. If he does buy such a coat, let him pay the sales tax on it. I am being serious about this. I am not urging the honourable senator to buy a fur coat but urging upon him the principle that if he elects to do that, he elects also to pay the tax, whereas a battler whose overtime payments are taxed has no choice about that. That is very much the crux of this debate. We support that general move away from indirect tax. It is part of our policy, a ballot having been taken of our members after serious consideration of a position paper and debate in our journal. It is a form of policy making which I believe no other political party in this country, and possibly the world, has. It takes into account the views of many thousands of Australians and expresses them directly. That is something we should look at and consider as being of importance.

Incurring sales tax should be a matter of choice for people. I emphasise that point. That is why the Australian Democrats are opposed-it is our declared and published policy to be so opposed-to the sales tax on the necessities of life, which the Government proposes to introduce from the end of this year. I grant that it is not always possible-in fact, it is very difficult-to say what are the necessities of life. People's needs vary considerably. One can look at the matter only from the point of view of saying that there are some things that every person must have, that are essential. They must have shoes and clothing for their children and roofs over their heads. The Australian Democrats would include as necessities in a civilised society books, newspapers and informational magazines-the ordinary means of culture and education. I am sure Senator Evans and members of the Labor Party would be the first to agree with me on that. If that is not the case, I have no doubt he will say so later. The sales tax on wrapping materials might also affect the cost of food and should be exempt from this tax. However, the Government is actually proposing to tax all these things. The new taxes on the necessities of life, which come into effect on 1 January next, are dangerous and iniquitous. Those are strong words but I, and the Australian Democrats, think they are well advised. They are iniquitous because a flat tax will be imposed on people regardless of their ability to pay. It will be placed on items such as the shoes their children must wear and the clothing that everybody must have on their backs.

This new and, as I have said, iniquitous tax may well owe its origins-I wonder about this-to the flat income tax concept originating in certain remote areas of the National Country Party. Those who remember last year's election campaign would know that this idea of a flat tax was in vogue at one stage, among some people, regardless of income. But it was not in vogue for long. I commend this country's Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), he being one of those who said it would be a very bad, unfair and iniquitous tax and that it should not come about because it would simply mean that there was such a tax on everybody regardless of ability to pay. I question the consistency of the Prime Minister and the Liberal Party because, having taken that stand, they have now brought forward this new sales tax on necessities. I think Senator Missen will agree that it is basically the same sort of principle being applied in another way. That is why there is this tremendous feeling in the community about it. That feeling-which we will all know about soon if we do not know about it already-is that these taxes should not be imposed on 1 January but the Government, in its wisdom, should consider the matter again. I do not say 'in its wisdom' cynically; I think it would be a wise and statesman-like decision for the Government to reconsider and decide that this is a new false direction for our country which we should avoid at all costs. Let us look at other areas of taxation, but please do not get involved in this dangerous principle of imposing sales taxes on people regardless of their ability to pay.

It is a fact that this new tax on necessities seems very small at the moment. It is a mere 2 1/2 per cent. However, business leaders have already warned that because this figure will be applied at the wholesale level, the increases at the retail level will be very much higher. Most families are extremely ill-equipped to bear this increased cost on top of all the other things which have been done to them in this society over the last year or so. I refer to rising interest rates, the fact that they are now compelled to provide themselves with medical insurance, and things of that kind. Therefore, these taxes have an added importance because they are in a very real sense the straw that might break the camel's back. This is the one thing which will add to families' costs-unnecessarily-to an enormous extent.

I would like to mention briefly the most iniquitous of all these taxes-that which would apply a 2 1/2 per cent sales tax to building materials used in houses. Surely it is obvious that young families and people getting married now are having a hard enough run as it is getting a house. Their problems of getting mortgage money together are great enough; it is even more difficult to pay the enormous interest rates demanded of them. What does the Government propose? It proposes to add to that burden another $500 to $1,000 on the cost of a house. When we query members of the Government about that, they say it is only a fraction of what would have been added to the value of a house in a year because of inflation-as if in some way that justifies the belief that two wrongs make a right. Of course, two wrongs do not make a right. The fact that inflation is adding to the costs of these people should be a reason for the Government not to impose that additional burden, not a reason for it to do so. I will be interested to hear the comments of the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) on that point later in this debate.

Perhaps even more dangerous and difficult is the precedent set by the introduction of this tax. This 2 1/2 per cent sales tax is very much the thin end of the wedge. The Australian Democrats suspect it is the beginning of a new tax which eventually will be introduced to milk in money as the crude oil levy disappears. As most Australians who go to petrol stations to fill up their cars would know, we are being clipped pretty hard right now on the basis that we should be paying the same amount for our petrol as we would had we needed to import it all. That is a reasonable enough proposition in a conservational sense but as time goes on and the production from our Bass Strait oil wells goes down the Government will have available less and less money, until the time comes when the Bass Strait crude has all gone and the Government will have none of that money. The Government feels, I suppose properly enough, that it has to replace that money. The Australian Democrats suggest that the Government look at reasonable economies-for instance adding to the present Parliament House rather than going on with the monster being built on Capital Hill. I note that only today there has been yet another increase in cost to nearly $400m-in spite of all the undertakings given on both sides of this House, by the Labor party and the Liberal party, that this would never happen. I confidently predict to all honourable senators, as I have done before-I did it two years ago and last year-that before that building is completed it will cost more than $1 billion.

If the Government is looking for economies, this is the place to start. Why not realise that the people of this country have quite enough to put up with now. They have quite enough burdens without adding to them and spending the money in a mad rage of building all over Canberra. It is analogous to the Khmer kings who crippled their society in Cambodia with an insane urge to build monuments to themselves. The point we are trying to make is that this tax could be increased year by year-no doubt it will be if the Government is allowed to get away with it-until it destroys the very basis of family life in this country. It will allow the rich to batter, without restraint, the less well off. That is what it is all about.

This sinister new tax-the word 'sinister' is certainly no overstatement-shows very nakedly the view of society held by the extreme right wing of the Government parties. I do not believe that it can possibly be supported by all senators and members of the House of Representatives who are members of the Liberal Party or the National Country Party. I cannot believe that all those people are sufficiently cynical and evil as to wish this tax on people. Those who do not support it have a clear duty to say so now. If those people have any sense of responsibility at all to the people who elected them and the people they represent they should say that. Certainly their constituents are saying that to them and they know that as well as I do. Of course, they will go on doing so.

Certainly, these new taxes must be opposed by all Australians to their utmost ability. When the time comes, they must oppose them in the ballot box at a general election. I suggest that that would be the time when the Government could be taught a lesson if it goes on with this completely anti-social type of behaviour. The Prime Minister may in his wisdom and in the fullness of time elect to hold that election at any time. We do not know what will happen over the next year or so and it will be up to the Prime Minister to decide what he is going to do if he finds that certain things happen in this chamber.

This new tax on children's school shoes, on clothes, on building materials, on the books school and university students must use and on the means of free communication is what we now wish to see eliminated. We ask the Senate to support this amendment to the motion for the second reading so that this Bill will be brought back to the attention of the House of Representatives in a forcible form. The Government will understand that at least this House of the Parliament does not go along with this appalling situation which is to apply to 1 January. At a later stage in this debate, in the Committee stage, I shall be moving amendments which will spell out in detail what is pre-stated in this amendment that we are proposing to the motion for the second reading of this Bill.

That amendment will be in the form of a request by message to the House of Representatives. Why make requests? This is because the Australian Constitution does not allow the Senate to amend such money Bills. We can only request. I suggest that this is largely a matter of words, of semantics and of form. The fact remains that, whatever way it is done, the full weight of the authority of this chamber can be brought to bear on the House of Representatives and the Government combined with the very considerable pressures being exerted by the electorate over this matter. Many people in the electorate have been in touch with me about this matter. There is no doubt in my mind that they will continue these pressures for as long as it is necessary in order to remove these iniquitous taxes or until the next general election when, I suggest, the problem might solve itself if it has not been solved beforehand. If the Government refuses the requests which we put forward in this chamber and the community can draw their own conclusions and be guided in their future actions towards the Government as a result.

I now turn to another point. It is a very vexed matter which has taken a certain amount of time during this debate on these sales tax Bills. Should the Australian Democrats eventually use their vote in the Senate to compel the Government to make these changes? It has been said that this should happen. The Australian Democrats senators are five people in this place who were elected by the people of Australia on a policy of moderation and restraint when it comes to tampering with money bills. Last year during our election campaign our senators, who have now been elected, publicly announced that they had signed the statutory declaration which reads:

That I personally subscribe to and endorse without reservation of any kind the publicly announced policy of the Australian Democrats, as stated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, the Honourable Senator D. L. Chipp--
May he prosper-

that the Australian Democrats, if gaining a position of 'balance of power' in the Senate would not use their voting numbers in such a way as to cause the blocking of supply or money bills in a manner which would prevent the majority party in the House of Representatives from governing.
Beyond that, the declaration went on to state:

That for all purposes and without reservation of any kind, I hereby declare that if elected to the Senate I shall not cast my vote as a Senator in a manner which would be contrary to the policy of the Australian Democrats as stated in Paragraph 3 hereof-
That was the previous paragraph I quoted-
and thus shall never during my tenure as a Senator contribute to or cause a situation which through blocking of supply or money Bills might bring down the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bring down the Government!
—Bring it down.

—I hear the hounds calling in the background. The Australian Democrats know that the Australian people do not want a repeat of the constitutional crisis of 1975 which was due to this vexed matter of the Senate blocking money Bills. Nor do the Australian people want any risk of that happening. They have made that abundantly plain to us and, I am sure, they are making it abundantly plain to the Labor Party. I think the view of the bulk of the electorate-if the Labor Party went to the trouble to go and consudt it-is that they would see any major tampering with the Budget, any major blocking of a Bill which substantially raises revenues for the Government or, indeed, a blocking of Supply or the appropriation Bills as possibly causing that constitutional crisis. This has been frequently canvassed in the newspapers in which it has been said that there is instability in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, Mr Hurford once said as part of the Labor Party's strange sort of ambivalent attitude towards these Bills that there was not really any intention at all to block the sales tax Bills. He said that what the Labor Party wanted was to persuade the business community to go to the Liberal Party and to join with the Labor Party in getting some sort of deal together whereby the Senate would not be able to vote on money Bills and would not be able to do in effect what the Labor Party is proposing to do now. I wonder how Byzantine one can get. That seems pretty Byzantine to me. However, the Labor Party knows best just what its real motivation is. At least three motivations have been suggested. I have given two of them. The third might well be that because of the way the polls are running at the moment they felt that if something happened they might have a good chance of getting back into government. They might well have done that. We will concede that.

I ask my friends in the Labor Party; If we had gone along with them hand in hand down the short nasty path back to November 1975, how would they have liked it if we had started meddling with their first Budget? What sort of a world would that have created for this country? What sort of political instability might it have created for the future? In other words, we feel that we have a duty to be of good faith towards the people who elected us to this place. Rightly or wrongly, we see ourselves as fulfilling that duty. I am aware that a certain discretion is possible. We have some room to move but we believe we owe it to the people to move with caution, whatever we do. If we were so rash as to exceed the mandate we have been given as a minority party we would very properly accept the rights of the people to say: 'You have exceeded the powers we gave you. You have done more than you said you would do, as we understood it, and you can take the consequences'. I am sure we would take the consequences.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you should resign without waiting for an election.

—Senator Evans may want to resign but I am quite happy. I feel I still have things to do. If he wants to resign he can resign but I assure the honourable senator that I have no intention of doing so. The risk would be not only a possible repeat of November 1975 but also perhaps several such repeats and possibly decades of political and economic instability, bitterness and disunity. The Australian Democrats are not prepared to subject the country to those risks. However, that does not mean that we will at no time take action on Bills which the Senate can amend in constitutional terms or fail to oppose the Government. The Government ought to take clear notice of this fact.

SPEECH.PARA: We have already given notice of the issues on which we would block Government moves. This happens regularly in other countries, and is a proper part of the process of democracy and the functions of this chamber. So, if a piece of legislation comes through and is changed in this chamber the Government has no call to scream and run and say that it wants a double dissolution or that it has no mandate to govern because that would be absolute nonsense. It would merely mean that one House of this Parliament decided, as it has every right to do having been voted to this place by the people, to make some sort of change to legislation. It happens all over the world all the time. So I hope the Government will not bring forward that sort of silly statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thrashing them with a feather.

—However, we will continue to be cautious-perhaps on some estimations-over-cautious. I hear people from this side of the chamber talking about feathers. I am sorry; the interjector is not the person I thought it was talking about feathers. Some people think we will be over-cautious with tax and supply Bills but we will continue to be cautious in our approach to those things. We admit that we are a new party. We do not have great experience in this place. I think that also makes it necessary for us to say to the Australian people that we are aware of our own inadequacies which we are doing our best to overcome. Our new senators are only inexperienced. I think honourable senators will find that the honourable senators sitting behind me have all the other qualities and they will rapidly become distinguished members of the Senate. Meanwhile, we have a certain responsibility to be careful about what we do. We will go on doing that without regard to anybody else's advice to us.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I suggest that the Government will have a heavy responsibility when our requests reach the House of Representatives. We have kept our word, although a single act of ours to vote against the motion for the second reading of the total package of sales tax Bills might indeed well destroy the Government, and well it knows it. If the Government were to elect to seek a double dissolution in, say, three months after, in terms of the Constitution, these Bills came back before the Senate and if the people were to vote in the way the opinion polls say they would, the Government would be in difficulties.

We have held our hand because we believe that what we are doing is right and proper and is what we have undertaken to do. We do not expect the Government to show us any sense of obligation; far from it. That is the last thing we would want from it. But we do believe that the Government has an obligation to look at the sales taxes on necessities and to think carefully again about them. We will not condone its failure to remove the sales taxes on necessities and we will continue our campaign against them for as long as is necessary, certainly up until the next election whenever that might be.

Finally, I have moved this amendment to the motion for the second reading of the sales tax Bills to make it abundantly clear at all stages of the consideration of the legislation that the Australian Democracts are opposed to the principle of sales tax on necessities. That is briefly our reason for moving the amendment at this time. I have looked at Standing Order 125, which was discussed earlier today. There is nothing in it and I think the Australian Labor Party has already realised that. I hope it will not bring forward that Standing Order as a red herring. These are not motions of which notice has been given. I think that covers the point.

TALK.START.PARA: —The furthest thing from our minds.

—I do not think it was this morning. However, a lot happens in a day. I honestly believe that the Labor Party has a clear duty to the people of Australia to support us in this amendment and to see that it is carried by the Senate. I think the failure of the Australian Labor Party to support our second reading amendment for the removal of sales tax on the necessities of life would be a clear abdication by that party of its moral principles. I cannot believe that the Australian Labor Party accepts that there should be sales taxes on such necessities. We are putting our proposal squarely in front of it for support. We will be most interested in seeing from the vote which is to come whether it is prepared to stand by its principles or whether it will shilly-shally dither and do all those other things that have been said so often in the debate on the sales tax Bills. I would have thought that the Labor Party would see itself as having a clear stake in the interests of the average Australian family, whose interests I think the Labor Party would be anxious to maintain. Those interests should be dear to it. I suggest that it can support them by voting with us on this amendment and seeing it being passed in the Senate. The Opposition has the power to do that. Let me make it quite plain at this stage that it is in its hands whether this amendment is passed by the Senate. If it fails, it will be on its head and it will be its responsibility. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

—Senator Mason, as the Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats, has moved an amendment to the motion that the Bills be read a second time. As Acting Leader of a recognised party in the Senate, I remind the Senate that he does not need a seconder to his amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Labor Party will not be supporting the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats, for very adequate reasons which I will attempt to state briefly, given the time constraints this evening. The first reason is that to support this amendment would be to water down the party's consistent and uncompromising opposition to all of these sales tax imposts on general economic and equity grounds. I intend to expand on that later. Secondly, this amendment is completely superfluous insofar as opportunities to achieve precisely the same objectives will arise in the Committee stage when more specific amendments are, I understand, to be moved by the Australian Democrats and will be supported by the Labor Party. During the Committee stage further amendments will be moved by the Labor Party to extend the list of goods to which the Australian Democrats are proposing that exempt status should continue. The Democrats are proposing that exempt status should continue to apply to some goods. The Labor Party will support that and, in addition, will move that that list be extended.

SPEECH.PARA: Moreover, there will be a third opportunity to oppose the Government's intentions in a more effective way when the Committee stage of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill comes up. In that instance, this chamber can actually amend the Bills instead of simply passing on requests to the House of Representatives. It is our intention to move a number of completely effective amendments when the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill reaches the Committee stage. The amendment which has been moved to the second reading motion by the Australian Democrats is completely superfluous and simply complicates the issue. That may well be the underlying intention.

I want to summarise again very briefly the reasons why the Labor Party has consistently and unequivocally opposed all of the sales tax imposts which have been proposed by the Government. We oppose them all because they are inflationary, inequitable and completely unnecessary. They are inflationary because they will add 1.1 per cent to the consumer price index. The Budget Papers state a figure of 0.75 per cent, which is a misrepresentation of the truth. The figure of 0.75 per cent is an estimate for the whole of 1981-82 over the whole of 1980-81. The correct figure by which these sales tax imposts alone will inflate the consumer price index is 1.1 per cent. That is the Treasury estimate for the June 1982 on June 1981 figure. This Government, which has professed for more than six years to have, as an overriding primary objective, bearing down on inflation, proposes taxes which will directly increase the consumer price index by more than one per cent and, when the indirect effects flow through, will probably increase the consumer price index by something like 2 per cent. We oppose it because it is inflationary. No informed, rational person can deny that it will be inflationary. We oppose the sales taxes on grounds of equity. They are inequitable because, in common with indirect taxes in general, they are regressive; that is, they fall proportionately more on the lower income groups than on the higher income groups. They are also unnecessary. They have always been unnecessary because the difference, so far as the Budget outcome for 1981-82 is concerned, between accepting or rejecting all of these Bills is that the domestic budget surplus, estimated to be $1.5 billion in round figures would, if these sales tax measures were rejected entirely, be reduced to $1 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you become the government will you abolish all sales tax? Would you care to give us that undertaking now?

—I am about to put these propositions to increase the domestic surplus in their contemporary economic context. It has been patently clear from the outset that this additional revenue which the Government seeks to raise this year is unnecessary insofar as its only effect on the Budget outcome would be to add to the domestic Budget surplus. In view of the disclosures or facts which have emerged since the Budget was presented, these additional imposts are not only unnecessary but also positively malevolent. The assumptions upon which the Budget was framed-that is, strong economic growth in the June quarter and a capital inflow in excess of last year's record $6.5 billion capital inflow-are now quite clearly unrealistic. On present indications, capital inflow is likely to fall far short of the Government's projected target of $7 billion and economic growth either was stalled in the June quarter or may even have become negative. The indications available so far are that the situation has not changed since the December quarter. In other words, instead of having an economy which is growing at least by the standards of the 1970s at quite a rapid rate, present evidence suggests that the economy is stalled, if not actually in reverse. Therefore the highly contractionary budget which the Government introduced one month ago is now even more inappropriate than it was at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make just a couple of other points. Firstly, the rejection of all of these sales tax Bills cannot in any reasonable way be compared to a rejection of Supply. The most obvious qualitative distinction between the two is that Supply Bills authorise the expenditure of money and that all of these Bills authorise the collection of money. So there is that important and vital qualitative difference.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you cannot collect money, you cannot spend it.

—That is not true, strictly speaking, but I will not go into that because of time constraints. Secondly, if Supply Bills or Appropriation Bills are rejected the ability of a government to pay its own employees and to pay social service recipients among other things is restricted or removed. These Bills do not have that effect. I repeat that the only effect on the current year's Budget outcome, flowing from the total rejection of all of these Bills, is that the domestic surplus will be reduced from $1.5 billion to $1 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: A far more appropriate analogy between these Bills and the previous experience-far more appropriate than the rejection of the Appropriation Bills in 1975-is the rejection by the Senate in 1974 of the Medibank levy Bill. In the Medibank case in 1974 and the present case a Senate rejection would have affected and will affect the magnitude of Government revenue raising. In neither case would such action affect the ability of a government to remain in office, to pay its own employees and to meet its day-to-day and essential requirements. However, the analogy is not completely appropriate insofar as the Senate, by rejecting the Medibank levy Bills, in 1974, stopped the then Labor Government from keeping an explicit electoral promise which preceded the 1974 double dissolution and upon which the Labor Government was re-elected. On the contrary, what the Labor Party seeks to do now is to force the Government to keep its pre-election promises not to introduce indirect taxation. I refer to pre- and post-election promises. In particular I refer to a post-election promise as late as 12 March 1981 in which the Treasurer (Mr Howard), in a major statement to the House of Representatives on the question of indirect taxation, said:
Throughout its consideration of this issue-
That is the issue of indirect taxation or the broadening of the indirect tax base-
the Government remained firmly of the view that if a shift towards greater emphasis on indirect taxation were to occur, it should be accompanied by a noticeable reduction in personal income tax.

We have with these Bills a proposition both to broaden and deepen the reliance upon indirect taxation accompanied not by a noticeable reduction in personal income tax but on the contrary by a massive 22 per cent increase in personal income tax from pay-as-you-earn taxpayers. The Labor Party's attitude to all of these Bills, on macro-economic grounds and on equity grounds and all grounds of moral principle-what the Democrats leader used to refer to as 'keeping the Bs honest'-is that all of them should be rejected. They are inflationary, inequitable, unnecessary and/or malevolent. For all of those reasons and the fact that there will be an opportunity later in the debate on these Bills during the Committee stage more effectively to do what the Democrats seek to do, or claim they seek to do with their second reading amendment, the Labor Party will not support the second reading amendment proposed by Senator Mason. However, I want to make it perfectly clear that we will support and add to measures in the Committee stage which will have precisely the same objective but which will pursue that objective in a more effective way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — On Monday of this week I went to sunny Queensland-it was raining at the time-to address a meeting.
—Did you take your passport?
