I would like to read to the Senate the resolution of that meeting which I think was very well worded and framed and which expressed very clearly and appropriately the feeling of the people of Queensland and the people of Australia in respect of the matters that are currently before us. The resolution stated:

SPEECH.PARA: This meeting condemns the Federal Government's sales tax measures, particularly the extension of sales tax onto necessities of life such as clothing, footwear, house, building materials and its tax on educational books. Australian families are beginning to realise the impact these measures will have on their cost of living. Whilst the Federal Government deserves credit for its family allowance increases for larger families, these increases will not go to all families and do not make up for the lost purchasing power of family allowances since 1976 and will continue to be eroded by cost of living increases inflamed by the sales tax measures. We note that the Federal Government is attempting to substantially broaden the base of indirect taxation on commodities despite its promise not to do so without compensating reduction of direct taxes such as income tax. This meeting protests at the unconventional manner in which the measure to extend sales tax to previously exempted necessities of life is being forced onto the parliament by the Government. We wholeheartedly support the moves being made to prevent the Government's attempt to circumvent the legitimate powers of the Senate to review legislation in the interests of the community. We congratulate those members of Federal Parliament who are prepared to make a stand on this issue and in particular we are determined to express our views to Government members in writing and by petition so that this unjust and inflationary indirect tax to the necessities of life is finally rejected outright.

That meeting was organised by a wide variety of groups which included the Women's Action Group, the Women's Action Alliance, the Queensland Country Women's Association, the Taxpayers' Association of Queensland, the Queensland Confederation of Industry Ltd, the Master Builders' Association, the retail traders, Parents Without Partners, the Civilian Widows Association and the Book Publishers Association. There are no votes for me in Queensland, but I thought that it would be appropriate for me to accept that invitation because of the initiative taken by these people. I was glad that I did so.

I believe that the overwhelming response of the people present at that meeting reflected the growing response to this legislation throughout the length and breadth of Australia. I can see it in my own State of Tasmania, where this issue is becoming a very important one indeed. Of course, the question of taxation and how taxation is to be levied and collected is one of the most important issues in a democracy such as Australia. A breadwinner on average weekly earnings, having paid income tax, has only thereby paid 50 per cent of the total tax that he or she will pay in one year. The move towards greater reliance on sales tax is regressive in that it falls heaviest on low income earners. By and large, their outlay is greater than is that of the higher income group. Treasurer Howard would advance, as a reason for extending the base of commodity taxes, the problem of tax avoidance. My opinion-it ought to be his also; probably it is-is that tax avoidance ought to be met head on and measures introduced substantially to ensure that there is little or no tax avoidance.

We have before us three measures. The first comprises Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1 to 9), which increases taxes on already taxed goods. The second comprises Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) which apply taxes to goods now exempted under the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act. The third amends that Act to do away with certain anomalies. The effect of these three measures is to increase this year the sales tax revenues of the Government by 38.6 per cent-at a time when income tax will increase by 22 per cent. The question arises: Why is the Government doing this when it clearly indicated that it would not broaden significantly the basis of commodity taxes unless it provided an offsetting relief in regard to income or direct taxes. I need not read page 18 of the Treasurer's Budget Speech on the subject. I cannot find it but I know it by heart. He stated clearly at that point that he was changing the mix in favour of the indirect area to provide the potential for desirable reductions in direct taxes, particularly income taxes. However, now that we are faced with these Bills he has not told us how he will reduce direct taxes. He is asking the Parliament to buy a pig in a poke and I, for one, will not accept that situation until the position is perfectly clarified for me and for the Parliament. Let us consider the situation with which we are confronted. The sales tax issue has taken the Australian Parliament into the highways and byways of the Constitution. It has taken the Senate into an examination of its Standing Orders, into an examination of previous legislation, and into a consideration of ancient legal maxims in Latin. One of these, as Senator Evans has pointed out, is leges posteriores, which means that Acts which passed subsequent to previous Acts, insofar as previous Acts are inconsistent with subsequent Acts, have no effect. Is that not correct?

TALK.START.PARA: —Your translation is better than your pronounciation.

—All of this is pretty confusing to the average Australian, let alone the average senator, but the further one delves into the subject the more it becomes apparent that just about every consumer and wage earner will be affected. To give a few examples, the 1A to 9A group of Bills relate to overalls, babies' nappies, gloves, hats, footwear, household drapery and soft furnishings-including bedspreads, loose furniture covers, mattress covers and curtains-towels, bunny rugs, yarns for knitting, sewing and tapestry, blankets, novels, textbooks and even knitting books. I have heard it claimed by one authoritative source that the extension of sales tax to items such as timber, timber frames, bricks, lime, concrete, cement, bolts, door frames and so on will add an extra $500 to the overall construction cost of the average dwelling. SPEECH.PARA: With respect, I believe that a lot of nonsense has been talked about constitutional crises. No Treasurer worth his salt will make a generalisation in the Budget without knowing precisely what it means and what he and the Government will do at a later stage. I say to honourable senators: Do not let them keep that to themselves; let them bring the Senate and the people of Australia into their confidence. It is the uniqueness of the manner in which these Bills have been brought before the Senate that has caused a great deal of comment. Of course, I refer again to that decision taken in Brisbane where it was stated:
This meeting protests at the unconventional manner in which the measure to extend sales tax to previously exempted necessities of life is being forced on to the Parliament by the Government.

That statement was made after it was noted that the Federal Government was attempting to broaden the base of taxation substantially. I could not have put that motion into better words had I framed it myself. It is unique. Senator Guilfoyle in answer to a question of mine did admit that the manner in which these Bills have been phrased is unique-so unique in fact that it is the first time they have been framed in such a manner since the first sales tax Bill came into the Parliament in 1930. If honourable senators quibble about that, I have the Bills here in my hand. I have the first sales tax Bill which goes back to 1930. They are pretty mouldy at the present moment. Act No. 26 of 1930 is the Sales Tax Act (No. 1) on the one hand and the machinery provisions, Sales Tax Exemptions Amendment, on the other hand.

The situation is that where previously the Government sought to impose a tax on already exempted items, it first introduced an amendment to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act. Now as the Government knows, those proposed laws are amendable. Had the Government attempted to do so on this occasion that Bill would have been amended; no risk about it. We have only to go to the Government's own explanatory notes to the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1-9) and to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill to see that what I am saying is perfectly correct. In the explanatory notes the Government stated:
Because of constitutional considerations,--
This is in the Explanatory Memorandum-

the sales tax legislation is contained in a number of separate Acts. There are nine Sales Tax Acts which specify the rates at which tax is payable and each Sales Tax Act has a complementary Sales Tax Assessment Act providing the machinery for assessment, collection and administration of the tax imposed by the related Sales Tax Act. The subjects of taxation and the various Assessment Acts and Rates Acts are set out in the following table--

In the explanatory notes the Acts are set out from the Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1) and Sales Tax Act (No. 1) to the Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 2) and Sales Tax Act (No. 2) and so on down to Sales Tax Act (No. 9). Why is this so? It is because of constitutional considerations. What did the Government do on this occasion? In relation to Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) what did it do? It included in the rates Act-that is the Sales Tax Act-machinery provisions; indeed, it included amendments to the Sales Tax Assessment Act. In effect, it is amending the Sales Tax Assessment Act and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act. Mr Deputy President, I was of half a mind to call the attention of the Parliament to section 55 of the Constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us do that.
—I will do so since I have been invited to do so. Section 55 of the Constitution states:

SPEECH.PARA: Laws imposing taxation shall deal only with the imposition of taxation, and any provision therein dealing with any other matter shall be of no effect.

Clearly, Bills Nos 1A to 9A deal with other matters. They deal with Bills which are amendable. The Government's drafting of these pieces of legislation attempts to thwart the Senate in the proper exercise of its powers. Indeed, if it were not contrary to the conventions of this Senate, I would feel tempted to ask the President of the Senate to rule the Bills out of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Oh, no, Senator Colston; the situation in regard to that particular matter is that in fact we are dealing with proposed laws. We are not dealing with an Act of Parliament until the proposed laws are assented to. I hope that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) is listening because when my contingent notice of motion to split the Bills comes into operation he ought to read page 129 of Odgers's Australian Senate Practice which indicates quite clearly that the President has never ruled on the constitutionality or otherwise of a proposed law. Also, he has never ruled on the Standing Orders, as I read the situation, and on how the Senate ought to deal with those sorts of proposed laws having regard to constitutional interpretation. I hope the Attorney-General is listening. Mr Deputy President, I do not invite you so to rule.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, the Government is out of order bringing in these Bills in the way it has. Including other matters in laws proposing taxation is contrary to section 55 of the Constitution. My foreshadowed move is designed to unravel the knot that the Government has tied in order to thwart the proper exercise of the Senate's powers. I appreciate that a flaw in my original notice of motion has been pointed out by Senator Evans. It was not an insubstantial flaw, I must admit. However, it was a flaw. It was a bit like the subject matter which was not referred to by that hypothetical reporter who asked Mrs Lincoln outside the Ford Theatre in Washington: 'And apart from that, Mrs Lincoln, how did you enjoy the play?'. It was rather consequential and I appreciate his bringing my attention to it. However, that has now been overcome, the contingent notice of motion is there. I advise the Senate now that I propose to withdraw that contingent notice of motion when it comes up and I will be supporting the proposed amendment to the second reading in the belief that half a loaf is better than none. However, in short, I believe that we should grasp the nettle now, oppose the Bills outright and allow the Treasurer to explain to the people just what he proposes in offsetting reductions in direct taxes for the impost that he is now attempting to place on the people in indirect taxing measures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt at all that we are debating Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1 to 9) 1981, Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A)1981 and Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1981, but there does seem to be some doubt about whether we are debating money Bills. It seems to me that some honourable senators have difficulty in recognising a money Bill when they see it. I can only say that these Bills form an integral part of the Budget strategy and are essential to the implementation of the Budget. From time to time speakers in this debate have referred to the question of whether these sales tax Bills are or are not appropriation Bills. Of course they are not appropriation Bills; but they are required so that the proposals contained in the appropriation Bills may be covered.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of matters were raised by honourable senators during the debate. I think some of them should receive a response at this time; perhaps others can receive a response during the Committee stage. Senator Walsh, in opening the debate for the Opposition a week or so ago, alleged that a form of trickery had been used in the Budget Papers, which referred to a three-quarters of a percentage point rise in the consumer price index attributable to proposed higher Commonwealth indirect taxes. I think the same point was raised by Senator Walsh in a question today. The Budget documentation refers to the effect of sales tax measures on the CPI in 1981-82. At two points-at page 55 and at page 60 of Statement No. 2 in Budget Paper No. 1. The following appears at page 55:
Stated briefly, the outlook for 1981-82 is for:

a rise of around 10 3/4 per cent in the Consumer Price Index, of which three quarters of a percentage point would be attributable to changed health care arrangements and a similar amount to higher Commonwealth indirect taxes;
The following is stated at page 60:

The changed arrangements for health care, which come into effect on 1 September 1981, are estimated to add about three-quarters of a percentage point to the overall increase in the Consumer Price Index . . . in 1981-82. The increases in indirect taxes announced in the Budget are estimated to add another three-quarters of a percentage point.

Senator Walsh correctly noted that the three-quarters of a percentage point referred to the effect on a year to year comparison; that is, the effect on the CPI for 1981-82 as a whole compared with that for 1980-81 as a whole. He went on to suggest that there seemed to be trickery in presenting the figures in that way and that a more conventional presentation would show the increase between the June quarter of 1981 and the June quarter of 1982, which he suggested would amount to 1.1 per cent and not 0.75 per cent.

The presentation in the Budget Papers did not involve any trickery as it was quite clear that a year on year comparison was involved in the figures presented. Nor is it true that a June to June comparison would be the conventional presentation, with the year on year comparison being unconventional. The two types of presentation convey different information and bring out certain facts which it may be important to show for comparisons that may wish to be drawn. Both forms of presentation could be right for their particular purposes.

In the part of the documentation where three-quarters of a percentage point appeared a number of year on year comparisons were made of various aggregates, such as incomes and expenditures, and similar comparisons were made for price changes. The sales tax measures are estimated to have a direct effect of around one per cent on the consumer price index, spread primarily between the December quarter of 1981 and the March quarter of 1982. Consequently, the June on June effect would be about one per cent. Because there is no effect on the September quarter for 1981 and because the 1 January measures do not affect the December quarter, the average effect on the year as a whole and therefore the estimated year on year effect is somewhat less than one per cent and was estimated at three-quarters of a percentage point in the Budget Papers.

Senator Walsh, in his earlier speech, also claimed that the Government had welshed on the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) of 12 March 1981. I refer only briefly to that by stating that the statement by the Treasurer set out arguments in favour of a change in the tax mix. Notwithstanding the merits of the arguments, the Government decided that it was not appropriate at that time to embark on the much different course of introducing, say, a retail turnover tax or of otherwise placing significantly greater reliance on very broadly based indirect taxes. That decision did not rule out smaller adjustments being made within the present system. There is no question of the Government having welshed on the Treasurer's statement of 12 March 1981 because that statement made it clear that there is advantage in making changes to the mix of indirect and direct taxes with a view to achieving desirable reductions in direct taxes, particularly personal income tax, as economic and budgetary conditions permit. The changes to operate from 1 January 1982 are of the modest character; I say modest in comparison with what might have been envisaged in the discussion of direct and indirect taxes held in March of this year.

Senator Walsh and also Senator Jessop said that there was confusion in the Australian Taxation Office in relation to the sales tax changes announced in the Budget and that the Taxation Office had not been briefed on the Government's proposals and, therefore, was unable to deal with the public's inquiries immediately following the presentation of the Budget. I am advised that that was not the case, that all capital city offices of the Taxation Office had available to hand to the public printed material which set out the changes to come into effect from 19 August 1981. Special facilities were provided to handle the phone calls made to each of those offices. I am advised also that the officers of the Taxation Office in each State were specially briefed on Budget night in respect of the changes announced in the Budget Speech and that additional officers were specially briefed on the morning of 19 August. Those officers had copies of the Bills and explanatory memorandums available to them at that time and they maintained contact with the Commissioner's office in Canberra in relation to any problems that developed.

When major changes are made to a law such as the sales tax law, it is inevitable that some confusion will arise because of misinformation disseminated through the media and in other ways and by persons with particular points of view. The Government recognises that changes such as those announced will bring temporary dislocation while businesses alter systems to adjust for the changes. That is an inevitable but traditional feature of the sales tax system. However, the allegations that the officers of the Taxation Office were not briefed are emphatically denied by the Commissioner of Taxation. Because the Bills relating to the changes to occur with effect from 1 January 1982 had not been introduced into the Parliament, it was not appropriate for the Taxation Office to give advice other that in the terms of the Treasurer's announcement of those proposals. I am informed that since the Bills have been introduced the Taxation Office has been giving more specific advice to inquirers and again plans to take special measures to assist members of the taxpaying public with any difficulties they may have in comprehending the changes that have been made.

Senator Walsh gave three examples of what he thought illustrated the alleged confusion. The first example involved a retailer and wholesaler of motor vehicle parts, the second involved registration for sales tax of persons not previously registered and the third involved a retail butchery selling a bullock's liver. I have been given answers to the queries raised by Senator Walsh and perhaps they ought to be stated so that the record will be complete for people who have an interest in particular matters. The problems envisaged by Senator Walsh do not arise in practice.

The answers to the matters raised are, firstly, that the relatively small number of retailers of motor vehicle parts who also make some wholesale sales differ from normal sales taxpayers because they carry tax paid trading stock rather than tax free trading stock, as is the case with wholesalers. When they sell goods by wholesale at 17.5 per cent they claim rebates in monthly returns of tax paid on those goods sold by wholesale. They need to know which goods have had tax paid on them at 15 per cent and which goods have had tax paid on them at 17.5 per cent to claim correctly the rebates.

However, at least 85 per cent of all retailer/ wholesalers of motor spare parts have a rebate system approved by the Taxation Office whereby a formula is used to calculate the amount claimed as a rebate, the figure being approved by the Taxation Office. This system avoids the necessity for the taxpayer to maintain extensive stock records to identify the tax paid on specific goods. The percentage rate fixed for a particular taxpayer is reviewed from time to time to ensure that it is supported by the facts. Because of this system it is not necessary for such taxpayers to tax stock as at 19 August 1981, although it is open for them to do so if they wish. I am advised that the Taxation Office does not require such persons to take stock, as has been alleged. I should add that the situation in question is not a common feature for taxpayers and applies only to a relatively small number of taxpayers.

The second question referred to the liability of manufacturers and wholesale merchants to register for sales tax purposes. The response to that is that the liability to register is all embracing, irrespective of whether taxable or non-taxable sales are made. The Commissioner of Taxation may dispense with registrations where only non-taxable sales are made, but that dispensation becomes ineffective if taxable sales are made. Pending the passage of the present Bills into law, the Commissioner is registering persons who apply for registration in anticipation of the Bills becoming law, but is not seeking in any way to enforce the obligation to register in respect of persons who will become liable to pay sales tax only because of these Bills. Upon the Bills becoming law, the Commissioner will take administrative steps to remind persons who have not registered of their obligations.

As to penalties, Parliament is presumed not to legislate retrospectively in relation to penal provisions of a law unless there is a clear intention to do so. There is no such intention in these Bills. Therefore, I am advised that any possible penalty liability can arise only in relation to acts and omissions occurring after the Bills pass into law. The obligation to account for sales tax will operate from 19 August 1981.

I turn now to Senator Walsh's example of a butcher selling a bullock's liver. Where a retail butcher sells meat for human consumption that meat is exempt from sales tax. It is irrelevant that the customer may feed that meat or some of it to domestic pets. If, however, a retail butcher puts meat up for sale for animals kept as domestic pets then, subject to two qualifications, that meat will be subject to sales tax. Let me give the qualifications. Firstly, prepared pet food, whether fresh or otherwise, purchased by the retail butcher from the wholesaler will be liable for sales tax at the time it is sold to the butcher. That is because the tax is basically a wholesale sales tax. Secondly, where the pet food is manufactured by the butcher and the amount of sales tax which would be payable by him is not or would not be in excess of $250 per annum, then that pet food is exempt from sales tax. This is a long-standing exemption applicable to businesses with low taxable sales and is found in item 103 of the First Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act.

Senator Jessop raised a number of issues, some of which were along the same lines as those raised by Senator Walsh. Senator Jessop was concerned at the nature of the advice which was tendered to the Government. Given that Budget changes cannot be bruited abroad until they are announced on Budget night, it is not correct to say that the Government relies entirely on the bureaucracy. Advice is given from time to time to the Government from various quarters. That advice is accumulated for consideration in formulating the Budget so that inputs come from many different sources. That was the case with the sales tax changes. Many of the corrections of anomalies and inconsistencies arose out of representations from interested parties, some extending over significant periods. Those representations were weighed up in the light of other inquiries made in formulating the Budget and reflect those industry representations in many cases. Other changes reflect anomalies which have been the subject of adverse comment in the media and other places, in some cases, for years.

Senator Jessop also raised the case of certain retailers who were refusing to pay the additional sales tax until the Bills become law. I respond by saying that while it is good business sense for a wholesaler to charge sales tax at the proposed rate of tax from 19 August 1981, it is correct that a retailer is not liable at present to pay the extra tax. The Commissioner of Taxation will not be taking any action to require payment of that extra tax until the Bills become law. Therefore, there is nothing more than a question of business prudence and good sense on the part of the wholesalers. They will become liable to pay the new rates with effect from 19 August 1981 when the Bills become law, and will thereby also have the right to recover the additional tax from their customers within the terms of the sales tax law. I think that perhaps explains the position that was raised by Senator Jessop.

A number of other matters were raised by Senator Jessop on which he had received representations and which he wished to bring before the Senate. I have answers to the specific questions that he raised. Glace fruit is to be taxed at 17.5 per cent with effect from 19 August. This has always been quite clear. I do not know how it could have been thought to be taxable at 2 1/2 per cent from 1 January 1982. Another matter raised was kangaroo meat. If it is sold as food for animals kept as domestic pets it is to be taxed at 17.5 per cent. Bird seed is exempt from sales tax and will remain so. The suggestion that certain bird seed is now to be taxed at 2 1/2 per cent has no foundation . The Government well recognises the problems of certain persons who may have arranged to purchase goods which were previously exempt from tax but which are now to be taxed or goods which are to be taxed at a higher rate. This is a feature of changes in the sales tax law and also in the customs tariff. The reverse applies to persons who purchase goods immediately before the rate reductions. Whilst the Government has some sympathy for persons who find themselves in these situations, the sales tax liability question arises on the date on which the sale of goods takes place and not when the order is placed or when a deposit or part payment has been made. The question of when the goods are sold is a question of fact to be resolved in accordance with the law relating to the sale of goods.

Another matter raised referred to building materials. The response to that question is as follows: The proposal to tax building materials has aroused a lot of comment as to how much the price of houses will go up because of the rate of tax. I am advised that based on the assumption that the cost of a house can be equally divided between labour costs and builders profit on the one hand and the cost of materials on the other hand, an average house costing $40,000 to build will include around $400 sales tax. It follows, of course, that more expensive houses will include a larger amount of sales tax in their cost.

Senator Jessop was also concerned that there was some retrospectivity in the legislation. Whilst I understand the point that Senator Jessop is making about retrospectivity, I must say that the Bills to come into effect on 19 August are not only in accord with the traditional practice for sales tax rates and classification changes but also comply with the procedure adopted by the Government when making amendments to the income tax law. To do otherwise would be to allow time for manipulation of stocks to avoid for some time at least announced prospective increases. Because of the much wider ramifications of the proposals which are to come into effect on 1 January the Government decided that prior notice was necessary for these matters to be understood and for the work to be done to put those into effect. A large number of firms will have to register for sales tax purposes and make appropriate accounting and other administrative changes. The Taxation Office also needs time to prepare for a significantly increased flow of sales tax work arising from these changes. Another matter raised by Senator Jessop related to the case of a pharmaceutical supplier in South Australia. Senator Jessop advised the Senate that he had taken up this matter with the Treasurer. The Treasurer's response to Senator Jessop on that matter was incorporated in Hansard. I think I need not add anything further to that.

Senator Evans, in the course of his speech, stated that the packaging of foodstuffs is now to be taxed. I am advised by the Commissioner of Taxation that this is not so. Packaging for use in marketing exempt goods, which includes foodstuffs, remains exempt under items 91 to 93 of the First Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act. This means that the inner and outer packaging for foodstuffs will remain exempt from tax, but courtesy or security wrappings by retail stores will become taxable. If I might illustrate this with an example. The waxed paper liner and the cardboard carton for a packet of cornflakes will remain exempt from tax, but the brown paper bag into which that package is placed in the retail store will be taxable at 2 1/2 per cent.

Senator Evans referred to the matter of freight charges incurred by wholesale merchants in country areas. This is admittedly a vexed problem which has been considered many times over the years. The Asprey Taxation Review Committee considered the problem but decided not to recommend any change. The problem arises equally where goods are sold between capital cities as it does where goods are sold between a capital city and rural areas. If freight charges were simply removed out of the price for which the goods were sold at the last wholesale price, decentralised industries would then be put at a disadvantage because their freight costs are found in the cost of their raw materials rather than the sale of the finished products in the country areas. If one were to consider alternatives, the first point to note is that total exclusion seems administratively impracticable for businesses. Raw materials go through several stages of processing. The amount of freight incurred each time the goods changed hands would not be known to the final wholesaler who pays the tax unless invoicing became very complex. Every freight charge would need to be recorded from the ground up and shown in all documents relating to subsequent stages of processing and manufacture and later dissected between taxable and non-taxable goods. Businesses could hardly be expected to accept the burden of recording, even in a computer age. If something along those lines were attempted, there would be considerable additional costs in keeping the necessary records, and when these were allowed to flow on to selling prices, any savings in sales tax from the move would be somewhat more limited than expected. It is not at all clear that such a scheme would in fact benefit rural dwellers and industry.

Another point raised by Senator Evans was that there has been no attempt to confine the impact of the measures to luxuries and to keep them off necessities. Sales tax has never been confined to luxuries, but already extends to a range of other goods. In broadening its base, it is obviously essential to cover an even wider range of non-luxury goods. There is a strong case to broaden the base of indirect taxes to a significant extent. That will leave the potential for further income tax reductions in future as economic and budgetary conditions permit. It will also help to reduce the weight of indirect taxes which a handful of commodities have to bear. The excisable goods and sales tax on motor vehicles have accounted for three-quarters of the Commonwealth's indirect tax revenue for some years. In order to meet these objectives, it is necessary for the broadening of the base of indirect taxes to be large enough to have a substantial revenue effect.

Senator Evans and Senator Walsh and I think others, have said that the sales tax measures are inflationary. In preparing the Budget the Government in fact gave priority to containing and reducing inflation. It is misreading the situation to suggest that if the sales tax component of the increase in the consumer price index were removed, inflation would be just that much less. The Budget surplus or deficit would be worsened and that could have its own inflationary consequences. There are much larger things than the indirect tax component of the CPI giving rise to the inflation problem. By far the largest influence on the CPI will be the mounting wage pressures. The relatively small effects of the sales tax measure should not be allowed to distract attention from that fact and other economic facts. The immediate effects of the sales tax measures on the CPI will be offset over the longer term by the beneficial effects on inflation of reductions in the size of the Budget deficit and the easing of pressures on interest rates.

A number of questions were raised which related to books, magazines and newspapers. Perhaps two points ought to be made fairly briefly. The first is that it is common in European countries to impose a value added tax on books and magazines, and for the information of honourable senators I cite some examples of the VAT imposed by various countries. In Austria it is 8 per cent at a reduced rate and in Belgium it is 6 per cent. In Denmark, newspapers and periodicals are exempt but without credits for the tax that is charged on supplies that go into their making. Books are taxed at 22 per cent. In France it is 7 per cent, in West Germany it is 6.5 per cent, in Ireland it is 10 per cent and in the Netherlands it is 4 per cent. In Sweden, newspapers and periodicals are exempt with credits for inputs, but books are taxed at 19 per cent. Norway and the United Kingdom do not impose VAT and allow credits for inputs. There is therefore no basis for the claim that Australia is the only country in the Western world to impose a tax on books, magazines and newspapers.

The only other point that I ought to make, I think, is that Senator Ryan claimed that the Government was acting contrary to a United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation agreement. I understand that she was referring to the Florence agreement on the importation of educational, scientific and cultural materials. Australia is not a signatory to that agreement but the Government has stated previously that it subscribes to its principles. The present proposal to tax books, magazines and newspapers is not in conflict with that agreement. Article I of the agreement makes it clear that a contracting State undertakes not to impose Customs duties or other charges on or in connection with the importation of books and publications. The agreement expressly provides that the prohibition against charges on importation does not prevent a contracting state from imposing internal taxes at the time of importation where such taxes also apply to like domestic products. Australia taxed imported newspapers at the general rate of tax between 1930 and 1967 and I am advised that the present proposal does not offend that agreement.

We have had some speeches made this evening. In one of them Senator Mason moved the amendment with regard to his party's attitude. With regard to that I would have to say of course that we do not accept the amendment that has been put forward by the Australian Democrats. There is a need to broaden the base of the sales tax to reduce the weight of indirect taxes on a handful of commodities. To achieve that, the broadening of the base needs to be large enough to have a substantial revenue effect. That was what was attempted in this particular proposal in the Budget, and if special pleading had led the Government to keep the sales tax off the new categories of goods, the effect would have been negligible or else it would have meant very great increases on existing commodities which are taxed. The proposals that have been put forward in this Budget to raise sales tax on the variety of goods that have been shown were ones that were carefully considered and ones which are, as I said earlier, an integral part of the Budget. Senator Harradine has made comments with regard to his own attitude on this matter. Perhaps I ought to say that some of the matters that were referred to by him as constitutional requirements could have a brief comment along the lines that the constitutional requirements are that the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Income Tax (Rates) Act be separate, not the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act. The other thing that ought to be said too, with regard--

TALK.START.PARA: —But you are amending the Assessment Act in this Bill, are you not?

—There are a number of Bills before the Senate. There are other indirect taxes, too, which already apply in this country in fairly large terms and they are just as great. Perhaps if we were to try to analyse the way in which we collect the revenue that is required we would see that traditional excises and the crude oil levy are estimated to increase much less than sales tax in 1981-82, and the Budget estimate of the combined increase in those three areas, that is sales tax, the excises and the crude oil levy, is for a 15.5 per cent increase this year compared with a 16.2 per cent increase last year.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been said on many different occasions the purpose of this Budget was to make as low a demand from the public sector on the loan market, on the borrowing requirements of Australia, and many of the measures that are contained in the Budget are designed to do just that. One of those measures is, of course, to raise the revenue from the sources that we have from personal tax and from the indirect taxes, to achieve what we have as the outcome of this Budget. Senator Siddons seemed to be in no doubt as to whether these are money Bills or Bills that raise revenue for the Government. I noted the comments he made when seconding the motion moved by Senator Mason.

A number of complex matters are before the Senate and, having dealt with the specific requirements of honourable senators made in their speeches, I commend these Bills to the Senate and hope that they have an early passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to withdraw contingent notice of motion No. 8 standing in my name. I will reinstate it at a subsequent stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; contingent notice of motion withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Harradine moving the following motion:

That the Senate declares that any decision by the Senate to make request to the House of Representatives for amendment of the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) 1981 does not indicate that the Senate considers that all of the provisions of those Bills are properly included in Bills imposing taxation.

I move for the suspension of Standing Orders so as to enable me to move that motion. It is difficult for me to advance reasons for the suspension of Standing Orders without canvassing the proposition which I will seek to move following Standing Orders having been suspended. In my view it is necessary for this motion to be accepted by the Senate so as not to allow people to run away with the idea that in moving requests at the second reading stage of consideration of these Bills, as has been indicated, we thereby regard that set of Bills as being properly drawn. The position is set out quite clearly in section 53 of the Constitution which provides:

The Senate may at any stage return to the House of Representatives any proposed law which the Senate may not amend, requesting, by message, the omission or amendment of any items or provisions therein.

Mr Deputy President, you will recall that I have outlined to the Senate and to the people of Australia the viewpoint that is held by, I think, everyone on this side of the House and admitted by the Government, and that is that Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) 1981 are drafted in a most unique fashion; indeed, so unique that they come before us in a manner in which they have not come before the Senate since 1930-that is to say, in the past 51 years. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle in her reply to the second reading debate admitted, in fact, that amendments to assessment Acts should not be included in Bills imposing taxation. If one has a look at the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) there is an amendment in effect to the Sales Tax Assessment Act. Therefore, it is reasonable for this Senate to suspend Standing Orders so as to debate the proposition that agreeing with the requests, as we are likely to do, does not indicate that the Senate considers that all of the provisions of those Bills are properly included in Bills imposing taxation.

It may be claimed by the Government that in so doing it is considered by me or some other people who may vote for that proposition that we do not regard such a Bill as a Bill properly drafted in accordance with section 53 of the Constitution. The Government may then say that under section 53 those Bills-that is, Bills imposing taxation, et cetera-are the ones concerning which there can be requests made to the House of Representatives. That would be an adequate statement so far as it went. The a fortiori argument is that if we can send requests to the House of Representatives about Bills imposing taxation we can send requests to the House of Representatives about any Bills whatsoever. In fact, one finds that this is implied in section 57 of the Constitution which deals with disagreement between the Houses. That section reads:

If the House of Representatives passes any proposed law, and the Senate rejects or fails to pass it, or passes it with amendments to which the House of Representatives will not agree, and if after an interval of three months the House of Representatives, in the same or the next session, again passes the proposed law with or without any amendments which have been made, suggested, or agreed to by the Senate . . .

That is talking about any law whatsoever-not just laws imposing taxation but any laws whatsoever. It is stated in this section that suggestions can be made to those laws. It may be claimed by the Government that a suggestion is not a request within the meaning of the Constitution. In my view, of course, a suggestion is a request. What is to happen with the suggestions that are made? Are they to remain in an atmosphere of suspended animation? Are we going to set up a suggestion box in the middle of Kings Hall into which these suggestions will be popped and cleared out, for example, by the Secretary to the Joint House Department and we will be given a bonus every now and again? Of course not. Suggestions are in fact requests. If the argument advanced by the Government is that the suggestions, as envisaged, are not requests, it falls to the ground. For all those reasons, I think it is essential for the Senate to suspend Standing Orders and clear the decks, as it were, for me and for other senators to vote honourably for requests.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak briefly in support of Senator Harradine's motion. This may be the place, but I do not think it is quite the time, to be debating in any detail in the context of either this procedural motion or the substantive motion which might follow it the various fascinating questions Senator Harradine has raised both tonight and in the course of his previous correspondence on this matter. I rise simply to state the attitude of members of the Opposition to the substantive point underlying Senator Harradine's motion, which is in essence that, although we believe there are quite formidable constitutional, legal and procedural difficulties confronting the kind of exercise involved in splitting the sales tax legislation before us in the way contemplated by Senator Harradine, we believe that important matters are raised by the various contentions that have been made the subject matter of public debate and parliamentary debate tonight and we believe the Senate ought to retain the option to debate the matters raised by Senator Harradine in more detail at a more appropriate time in the course of the debate on this legislation. For those reasons, we support the substantive proposition that Senator Harradine proposes to move, which makes it clear that the Senate closes off no options in any respect by treating the Bills as a whole, for the moment anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Ordered that consideration of Senator Harradine's proposed motion be made an order of the day for a later hour this day.

TALKER.NAME: Senator PETER BAUME
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Acting Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Honourable senators will be aware that on 1 September this year new health funding arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States came into force. Under these arrangements annual grants are paid to each state pursuant to the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act 1981 for the provision of health services by the States. The grants include an amount towards the cost to the hospitals of supplying pharmaceuticals to all patients. The amount is related to the expenditure by States for pharmaceuticals under the previous hospital cost sharing agreements, which in most States expired on 30 June this year, with continuation of the arrangements, without formal agreements until 31 August to synchronise with the new health insurance which came into effect on 1 September.

SPEECH.PARA: The States are being funded for pharmaceuticals under the new arrangements to the extent that can be justified by past experience. Within the National Health Act there is an alternative provision whereby hospital authorities could be reimbursed for their expenditure on pharmaceutical benefits. Section 94 authorises the approval of hospital authorities to supply pharmaceutical benefits, and those authorities are entitled to a reimbursement at a level determined by the Minister under section 99. This arrangement operated until the commencement of the Commonwealth-State cost sharing agreements in 1975. Under those agreements, States had agreed not to claim under secton 99. In States where those agreements are no longer in force it is now open to those hospitals which have been approved again to claim reimbursement. This is inconsistent with the Government's policy and, if taken advantage of, in the Governments view would represent a duplication of funding as regards pharmaceutical benefits.

When the Act was originally drafted no provision was made for such an eventuality, and approvals of hospitals to dispense pharmaceutical benefits cannot be revoked in such circumstances. In order to avoid any excess payment by the Commonwealth, the Government intends to amend the National Health Act at the earliest opportunity to empower the Minister to revoke the approvals. The amendment will allow revocation from today. The purpose of this statement is to make it clear to all concerned that existing approvals of recognised public hospitals under section 94 of the National Health Act will be revoked from today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I have no intention of keeping the Senate for long. The statement by Senator Baume raises a technical matter which occurs because of the new health arrangements and the manner in which they were introduced into this Parliament. The new health arrangements were conceived in haste and were prepared without proper consideration by the Government. As a result, the Government finds itself in the difficult situation of having hospitals being able to provide their own pharmaceuticals and, therefore, claim payment from the Government under section 94 of the National Health Act. When changes are made to a scheme such as our national health scheme one would expect that the changes would be developed with care. One would have expected that the Government would have thought through all the likely results of such legislation and the drafting of such legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) admitted in the statement, when the Act was originally drafted no provision was made for the eventuality which has arisen. Five minutes before the time at which the motion is put that the House do adjourn the Minister made a statement to correct an error which should have been picked up when the national health changes were first made. We have no disagreement with this statement. We have no disagreement with the intent of the legislation. But we point out that the necessity for this statement merely demonstrates the lack of care, the haste and the lack of thinking through of the changes to the national health scheme. I predict that this will not be the last statement of this type made in this place.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australia Post: Fire in Mail Delivery Vehicle

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to raise a matter which has caused great concern to many residents in the town of Mount Gambier and surrounding districts of South Australia. I refer to a report of a vehicle carrying mail from Adelaide to Mount Gambier which caught fire at Meningie at 3 a.m. this morning. Only seven bags of mail were saved. I raise this matter this evening in the expectation that the Senate will be informed tomorrow of the full details of the fire. In particular I would like to know, firstly, what was the cause of the fire; secondly, was the vehicle transporting the mail owned and operated by Australia Post; thirdly, if not, what is the name of the mail contractor; fourthly, was mail and goods in the sole charge of Australia Post the only freight being carried by the contractor; fifthly, if not, what other types of goods were on the vehicle at the time of the fire; sixthly, were any of these goods of an inflammable nature; and seventhly, what, if any, precautions are insisted upon by Australia Post to ensure the safe carriage of goods entrusted to it?

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) who is in charge of the House tonight takes note of the matters I have raised. As I said in my opening remarks, I hope that he brings in a full report to the Senate tomorrow. There are many people in Mount Gambier and the surrounding districts tonight who are wondering what has happened to the very valuable goods which they entrusted to the care of Australia Post in Adelaide for carriage to the south-east of South Australia. It is most important that this matter be resolved as soon as possible and that some statement be made by the Government on the matter. I will leave it at that in the hope that tomorrow we will get a full statement in the Senate of the cause of the fire and answers to the questions which I have posed tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a little information on the matter raised by Senator McLaren which I will make known now. I cannot answer all of the questions. For example, I do not have the name of the contractor and I am not certain whether there was any inflammable freight in the van. I understand that a road mail contractor van, which was not an Australia Post van, was on a run last night from Adelaide to Mount Gambier. The van left Adelaide last night and about 13 miles from Meningie the driver smelled burning in the van. The driver detected a small fire in the rear of the engine and used his extinguisher. However fire got out of control and the van was destroyed.

SPEECH.PARA: The van was carrying 96 bags of mail copies of the Adelaide News paper and other articles. I cannot give the honourable senator details of what the other articles were but I will try to obtain that information. All the contents were destroyed with the exception of about 300 letters. Those letters will be delivered, I am advised, within the next couple of days-perhaps slightly charred. Australia Post has investigators on the scene. I am advised that it is satisfied that the van met all Australia Post safety requirements. I understand that that does not answer all the honourable senator's questions. I will refer the unanswered parts to my colleague and attempt to obtain more information for the honourable senator as soon as I can do so.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 12 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Attorney-General seen, or is he otherwise aware of the statement in the joint Press release dated 18 March 1981 of Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd and Mary Kathleen Uranium Limited that the companies' settlement agreement with Westinghouse Electric Corporation in relation to the Westinghouse uranium cartel litigation 'is conditional on the completion of certain additional steps, including the obtaining of certain Government consents'.
(2) Has the consent of the Australian Government been sought in relation to that settlement.
(3) If so, (a) when was it sought; (b) has it been given; and (c) on what terms was the consent sought and given.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. I understand that the Government consents referred to in the statement did not relate to any consent by the Australian Government but to the Governments of Canada and South Africa in relation to the supply of uranium under the settlement.

(2) and (3) The Australian companies involved in the settlement of the Westinghouse proceedings informed the Government that, should they decide to enter into the settlement agreement, they intended to apply to the Reserve Bank of Australia for approval under the Banking (Foreign Exchange) Regulations for the movement of funds to enable the terms of the settlement to be carried out.

The Australian Government indicated to the companies that it would not object to the granting of such foreign exchange approval, if the proposed settlement satisfied certain national interest considerations. These were that:
(i) provisions be included in the settlement agreement-

requiring that the final judgment on issues of liability given against the Australian companies on 3 January 1979, and the preliminary injunction given in favour of Westinghouse Electric Corporation against the Australian companies on 24 January 1979, be vacated:
that there should be no implication from the settlement of wrong-doing on the part of the Australian companies:

that the settlement of the proceedings should not be construed as a waiver by the Australian companies of their jurisdictional objections to the proceedings or as a submission to the jurisdiction to the Courts of the United States: and

(ii) none of the uranium to be supplied under the terms of the settlement agreement (which in addition to the Australian companies included other defendants in the Westinghouse suit) would come from Australia or Namibia or be supplied by an Australian company.

The Government, upon being satisfied that these conditions had been met, indicated to the Australian companies, Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd, Mary Kathleen Uranium Limited and Pancontinental Mining Limited on 16 March 1981 that it would not object to the granting of approval by the Reserve Bank pursuant to the Banking (Foreign Exchange) Regulations to any application made by those companies to the Reserve Bank for the movement of funds to enable the terms of settlement to be carried out.
Queensland Mines Limited which subsequently decided to participate in the settlement agreement of 17 March 1981 was also informed of the Government's attitude prior to that decision.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Given the present difficulty facing those seeking employment in country areas can the Minister for Transport justify the decision to contract future road work on national highways by tender.
(2) What future arrangements will be made for:
(a) the hundreds of local workers who will be thrown into unemployment as a direct result of this decision; and
(b) the millions of dollars worth of heavy machinery which will now be idle.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator McClelland's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Section 24 of the Roads Grants Act 1981 requires that only national roads construction work be put to tender. It is the Government's policy to obtain the best value from the money it spends on roads. We believe that only by fostering a competitive environment can the Government be satisfied that the best value for money is being achieved. As national highways are eligible for 100 per cent Commonwealth funding, it is the responsibility of the Government to obtain the best value for taxpayers' money spent on such roads.

(2) (a) and (b) The arrangements for any redeployment of staff and plant resulting from the requirement that national highway construction works be put to tender are a matter for individual councils. The claim that hundreds of local council workers will be thrown into unemployment and millions of dollars worth of heavy machinery will be idle is pure speculation, especially when it is realised that councils are free to tender for national road construction projects and there is the possibility to redeploy staff and heavy machinery from national highway construction to maintenance work and projects on arterial and local roads.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have representations been received by the Minister for Transport from the Royal Federation of Aero Clubs of Australia expressing concern at proposed increases in Government charges recommended in a report entitled 'The General Aviation Study'.
(2) Was the report prepared by officers of the Department of Transport.
(3) What increases in charges were recommended.
(4) What action has the Government taken to date on the report and what further action is contemplated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Yes.

(3) The study report recommended a number of measures designed to increase the level of cost recovery for general aviation as a whole to that level associated with the recovery of short run incremental costs. On the 1977-78 data available to the study team, the level was approximately 34 per cent of allocated costs.
The measures recommended in the report were:
(i) an increase in air navigation charges of 25 per cent. This was not to be applied generally, and certain exceptions such as agricultural aviation were proposed,

(ii) the introduction of aircraft movement charges for general aviation, including gliding operations, at primary capital city airports, shared airports and general aviation airports, that is, at the 27 Commonwealth airports which are listed in Table 9.5 on page 173 of the study report. It was proposed that the movement charges would be $20 at primary airports, $10 at shared airports, and $4 at general aviation airports. It was not proposed that charges be imposed at Commonwealth airports not listed in the table. Movement charges were to be applied on the basis of a movement being either a take-off or a landing except for flying training operations involving circuits, where a touch and go operation should be treated as a single movement. Associated with these principal recommendations concerning charges, certain relatively minor measures were also recommended, namely,
(iii) the 50 per cent 'based away' refund or remission for all general aviation and the 15 per cent remission for agricultural aviation be abolished,

(iv) aircraft operating under permit be subject to lower air navigation charges to equate that achieved through the presently allowable 50 per cent reduction in air navigation charges by refunds or remissions,
(v) consideration be given to introducing air navigation charges for gliders to recover the costs associated with their use of airway services; and
(vi) a separate air navigation charges classification be introduced for the agricultural aviation sub-sector.

(4) On 16 July 1981 the Government announced that it had rejected the cost recovery recommendations of the general aviation study. It is intended that air navigation charges for general aviation will in future be considered each year in the Budget context, as has been done in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 August 1981 (Hansard, page 322) Senator Ryan asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, without notice, whether the Minister was prepared to instruct the Chief Australian Electoral Officer to make Commonwealth enrolment claim cards available at all polling booths for the forthcoming elections for the National Aboriginal Conference. I indicated that the Minister was not prepared to issue such an instruction. Senator Ryan then asked the following supplementary question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr President, does the Minister consider that by providing enrolment forms and information at booths the Chief Australian Electoral Officer would be acting within the provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act in the same way as he is acting when he sends enrolment forms to householders in urban areas, which those people are invited to fill out to maintain their position on the rolls?
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

There can be no suggestion that the provision of enrolment claim cards and enrolment entitlement information at National Aboriginal Conference polling booths is to be seen in the same light as the Australian Electoral Office sending enrolment claim cards through the mail inviting householders in urban areas to maintain their positions on the rolls. Generally speaking the Australian Electoral Office only sends cards to those whom it has reason to believe are subject to the compulsory enrolment provision of the Commonwealth Electoral Act.
On the question of simply having enrolment claim cards and enrolment information available at NAC polling booths the position is-
(a) cards could be made available;

(b) there is no enrolment information available in suitable form and in sufficient numbers that could be used to explain to Aboriginals their electoral rights-and in particular that enrolment on their part is voluntary;
(c) in fact the Australian Electoral Office while it conducts electoral education/information programs for Aboriginals does not solicit Aboriginal enrolment;
(d) on the other hand in respect of the NAC elections there is active encouragement for Aboriginals to attend and complete a voter card on polling day for that election;

(e) the active encouragement to participate in the NAC election and the presence of Commonwealth enrolment cards at NAC polling booths would no doubt lead to confusion in the minds of Aboriginals on the question whether they should enrol for Commonwealth electoral purposes. It could even be seen as a campaign by the Australian Electoral Office to enrol Aboriginals.

(f) furthermore, the polling officials engaged to conduct the NAC election are not officers of the Australian Electoral Office. In accordance with the procedures for the conduct of NAC elections they will, wherever possible, be Aboriginals. Many will be undertaking this activity for the first time and the Australian Electoral Office is endeavouring to keep procedures in the polling place as simple as possible.

(g) In any event the involvement of these polling officials in the NAC election procedures will not leave them with any time to explain to Aboriginals the differences between paricipating in NAC and Commonwealth elections or that for Commonwealth elections, enrolment was a purely voluntary act on their part.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the adjournment debate on 20 August, (Hansard, page 211) Senator Colston raised a number of questions regarding the establishment of Trans Australia Airlines as a public company and TAA groundstaff superannuation. His questions sought clarification of a response provided by the Minister for Transport to earlier questions on these matters.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following additional information:

With regard to the possible sale of equity in TAA, as has been repeatedly made clear the Government has made no decision on such a sale and will not consider the matter again until after the consultants have reported and the Parliament has had the opportunity to debate that report. Therefore such issues as priority in the allocation of equity to TAA staff have not been addressed. The consultant has not yet been appointed but it is anticipated that interested parties will be invited to make submissions shortly. As stated by the Minister for Transport on earlier occasions, the consultant will be required to report before 30 June 1982.

The question of the establishment of TAA as a public company is quite separate from changes to the superannuation arrangements applying to TAA. As to the first of these questions, I repeat that the legislation to transfer TAA's operations to a public company provided for the transfer of all staff on the same terms and conditions as applied to them when employed by the Australian National Airlines Commission. Changes to the TAA superannuation arrangements had been in train for some time prior to the decision to change the status of TAA. In fact, TAA's 1979-80 annual report referred to the superannuation proposals.

It was decided that the former arrangements whereby TAA groundstaff and flight engineers were permitted to join the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme were no longer appropriate. Rather, it was considered that TAA superannuation arrangements should follow the industry standard set by arrangements operated by Ansett Airlines of Australia for its staff.

With effect from 1 July 1980, no further TAA employees have been permitted to join the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme. TAA staff who joined that scheme prior to 1 July 1980 may continue their membership and they will not be obliged to join the new superannuation arrangements. However, should these employees wish to transfer to the new TAA superannuation plan they may at their option apply to transfer with full credit for their period of membership of the Commonwealth scheme. I emphasise that any such transfers will be at the option of the employees concerned.

The details of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme can be found in the Superannuation Act 1976. Broadly, it is a scheme where benefits on death or retirement are available as a pension, with an option to receive the employee-financed part of the benefit in lump sum form. The employer-financed part of the pension is not commutable and is therefore subject to post-retirement pension increases. The new superannuation plans for TAA ground staff are schemes that provide lump sum benefits of amounts related to the length of scheme membership and significant benefits on resignation prior to attaining retirement age.

The principal difference in the costs to TAA of the former and new superannuation arrangements is that as the new plans provide lump sum benefits on retirement there is no need to meet the cost of post-retirement pension increases. It is not possible at this stage to indicate the extent of future savings. Suffice to say that any reduction in costs to levels approaching those of its competitors will assist TAA's competitive position.

The new TAA groundstaff and flight engineer superannuation arrangements do not affect the other longer standing schemes for TAA pilots and flight attendants. These latter schemes already reflect airline industry standards.

The Australian Mutual Provident Society was selected to administer the new superannuation arrangements and provide investment services. I understand that the Society provides similar services to Ansett Airlines of Australia and has thus experience in the airline industry environment. It is correct that Sir Robert Law-Smith is a director of the AMP Society but the Government does not see any conflict of interest arising from this.
Over the years TAA has, with Government approval, borrowed amounts from its superannuation funds for general business purposes. No such borrowings were specifically for the Airbus purchases.

As to TAA's corporate structure, the establishment of TAA as a public company has not yet taken place. As set out in the Australian National Airlines Repeal Act 1981, TAA's operations will be transferred to a public company, specifically established for the purpose, on a day which has yet to be proclaimed. At present, TAA still operates as the Australian National Airlines Commission.

The provisions of the repeal Act quite carefully preserve as far as possible the terms and conditions of employment, including superannuation, enjoyed by TAA staff immediately prior to the transfer. Thus those employees who have transferred before that day to the new ground staff superannuation scheme will find their terms, conditions and entitlements maintained in accordance with the legislation after the transfer, as well as those who have continued their membership of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme.
